Scripture.Hexagram: 乾：元亨，利貞。

Lines.L1: 初九：潛龍，勿用。
Lines.L2: 九二：見龍在田，利見大人。
Lines.L3: 九三：君子終日乾乾，夕惕若，厲，无咎。
Lines.L4: 九四：或躍在淵，无咎。
Lines.L5: 九五：飛龍在天，利見大人。
Lines.L6: 上九：亢龍有悔。

Exegesis.Judgment: 大哉乾元，萬物資始，乃統天。雲行雨施，品物流形。大明始終，六位時成，時乘六龍以御天。乾道變化，各正性命，保合大和，乃利貞。首出庶物，萬國咸寧。

Imagery.Hexagram: 天行健，君子以自強不息。

Lines.L1: 潛龍勿用，陽在下也。
Lines.L2: 見龍在田，德施普也。
Lines.L3: 終日乾乾，反復道也。
Lines.L4: 或躍在淵，進无咎也。
Lines.L5: 飛龍在天，大人造也。
Lines.L6: 亢龍有悔，盈不可久也。

Scripture.Hexagram: 乾：元亨，利贞。

Lines.L1: 初九：潜龙，勿用。
Lines.L2: 九二：见龙在田，利见大人。
Lines.L3: 九三：君子终日乾乾，夕惕若，厉，无咎。
Lines.L4: 九四：或跃在渊，无咎。
Lines.L5: 九五：飞龙在天，利见大人。
Lines.L6: 上九：亢龙有悔。

Exegesis.Judgment: 大哉乾元，万物资始，乃统天。云行雨施，品物流形。大明始终，六位时成，时乘六龙以御天。乾道变化，各正性命，保合大和，乃利贞。首出庶物，万国咸宁。

Imagery.Hexagram: 天行健，君子以自强不息。

Lines.L1: 潜龙勿用，阳在下也。
Lines.L2: 见龙在田，德施普也。
Lines.L3: 终日乾乾，反复道也。
Lines.L4: 或跃在渊，进无咎也。
Lines.L5: 飞龙在天，大人造也。
Lines.L6: 亢龙有悔，盈不可久也。

Scripture.Hexagram:
THE CREATIVE works sublime success,
Furthering through perseverance.

Lines.L1:
Nine at the beginning means:
Hidden dragon. Do not act.
Lines.L2:
Nine in the second place means:
Dragon appearing in the field.
It furthers one to see the great man.
Lines.L3:
Nine in the third place means:
All day long the superior man is creatively active.
At nightfall his mind is still beset with cares.
Danger. No blame.
Lines.L4:
Nine in the fourth place means:
Wavering flight over the depths.
No blame.
Lines.L5:
Nine in the fifth place means:
Flying dragon in the heavens.
It furthers one to see the great man.
Lines.L6:
Nine at the top means:

Arrogant dragon will have cause to repent.

Exegesis.Judgment:
Great indeed is the sublimity of the Creative, to which all beings owe their beginning and which permeates all heaven.4
The clouds pass and the rain does its work, and all individual beings flow into their forms.
Because the holy man is clear as to the end and the beginning, as to the way in which each of the six stages completes itself in its own time, he mounts on them toward heaven as though on six dragons.
The way of the Creative works through change and transformation, so that each thing receives its true nature and destiny and comes into permanent accord with Great Harmony: this is what furthers and what perseveres.
He towers high above the multitude of beings, and all lands are united in peace.

Imagery.Hexagram:
The movement of heaven is full of power.
Thus the superior man makes himself strong and untiring.

Lines.L1:
Nine at the beginning:
a) Hidden dragon. Do not act.
b) “Hidden dragon. Do not act.” For the light-giving force is still below.
Lines.L2:
Nine in the second place:
a) Dragon appearing in the field.
It furthers one to see the great man
b) “Dragon appearing in the field.” Already the influence of character reaches far.
Lines.L3:
Nine in the third place:
a) All day long the superior man is creatively active. At nightfall his mind is still beset with cares. Danger. No blame.
b) “All day long the superior man is creatively active.”
One goes to and fro on the right path.
Lines.L4:
Nine in the fourth place:
a) Wavering flight over the depths. No blame.
b) “Wavering flight over the depths.” Advance is not a mistake.
Lines.L5:
Nine in the fifth place:
a) Flying dragon in the heavens. It furthers one to see the great man.
b) “Flying dragon in the heavens.” This shows the great man at work.
Lines.L6:
Nine at the top:
a) Arrogant dragon will have cause to repent.
b) “Arrogant dragon will have cause to repent.” For what is at the full cannot last.

Exegesis.Miscellaneous: THE CREATIVE is strong.

Scripture.Hexagram: Khien (represents) what is great and originating, penetrating, advantageous, correct and firm.

Lines.L1: 1. In the first (or lowest) NINE, undivided, (we see its subject as) the dragon lying hid (in the deep). It is not the time for active doing.
Lines.L2: 2. In the second NINE, undivided, (we see its subject as) the dragon appearing in the field. It will be advantageous to meet with the great man.
Lines.L3: 3. In the third NINE, undivided, (we see its subject as) the superior man active and vigilant all the day, and in the evening still careful and apprehensive. (The position is) dangerous, but there will be no mistake.
Lines.L4: 4. In the fourth NINE, undivided, (we see its subject as the dragon looking) as if he were leaping up, but still in the deep. There will be no mistake.
Lines.L5: 5. In the fifth NINE, undivided, (we see its subject as) the dragon on the wing in the sky. It will be advantageous to meet with the great man.
Lines.L6: 6. In the sixth (or topmost) NINE, undivided, (we see its subject as) the dragon exceeding the proper limits. There will be occasion for repentance.

Exegesis.Judgment:
I. 1. Vast is the 'great and originating (power)' indicated by Khien! All things owe to it their beginning:--it contains all the meaning belonging to (the name) heaven.
2. The clouds move and the rain is distributed; the various things appear in their developed forms.
3. (The sages) grandly understand (the connexion between) the end and the beginning, and how (the indications of) the six lines (in the hexagram) are accomplished, (each) in its season. (Accordingly) they mount (the carriage) drawn by those six dragons at the proper times, and drive through the sky.
4. The method of Khien is to change and transform, so that everything obtains its correct nature as appointed (by the mind of Heaven); and (thereafter the conditions of) great harmony are preserved in union. The result is 'what is advantageous, and correct and firm.
5. (The sage) appears aloft, high above all things, and the myriad states all enjoy repose.

Imagery.Hexagram: I. Heaven, in its motion, (gives the idea of) strength. The superior man, in accordance with this, nerves himself to ceaseless activity.

Lines.L1: 1. 'The dragon lies hid in the deep;--it is not the time for active doing:'--(this appears from) the strong and undivided line's being in the lowest place.
Lines.L2: 2. 'The dragon appears in the field:'--the diffusion of virtuous influence has been wide.
Lines.L3: 3. 'Active and vigilant all the day:'--(this refers to) the treading of the (proper) path over and over again.
Lines.L4: 4. 'He seems to be leaping up, but is still in the deep:'--if he advance, there will be no error.
Lines.L5: 5. 'The dragon is on the wing in the sky:'--the great man rouses himself to his work.
Lines.L6: 6. 'The dragon exceeds the proper limits;--there will be occasion for repentance:'--a state of fulness, that is, should not be indulged in long.7. 'The same NINE (undivided) is used' (in all the places of this hexagram), but the attribute of heaven (thereby denoted) should not (always) take the foremost place.

Exegesis.Miscellaneous: 1, 2. Strength in Khien, weakness in Khwăn we find.
Exegesis.Sequence: 1-3. When there were heaven and earth, then afterwards all things were produced. What fills up (the space) between heaven and earth are (those) all things. Hence (Khien and Khwăn) are followed by Kun. Kun denotes filling up.

Scripture.Hexagram: 坤：元亨，利牝馬之貞。君子有攸往，先迷後得主，利西南得朋，東北喪朋。安貞，吉。

Lines.L1: 初六：履霜，堅冰至。
Lines.L2: 六二：直，方，大，不習无不利。
Lines.L3: 六三：含章可貞。或從王事，无成有終。
Lines.L4: 六四：括囊；无咎，无譽。
Lines.L5: 六五：黃裳，元吉。
Lines.L6: 上六：龍戰于野，其血玄黃。

Exegesis.Judgment: 至哉坤元，萬物資生，乃順承天。坤厚載物，德合无疆。含弘光大，品物咸亨。牝馬地類，行地无疆，柔順利貞。君子攸行，先迷失道，後順得常。西南得朋，乃與類行；東北喪朋，乃終有慶。安貞之吉，應地无疆。

Imagery.Hexagram: 地勢坤，君子以厚德載物。

Lines.L1: 履霜堅冰，陰始凝也。馴致其道，至堅冰也。
Lines.L2: 六二之動，直以方也。不習无不利，地道光也。
Lines.L3: 含章可貞；以時發也。或從王事，知光大也。
Lines.L4: 括囊无咎，慎不害也。
Lines.L5: 黃裳元吉，文在中也。
Lines.L6: 戰龍於野，其道窮也。

Scripture.Hexagram: 坤：元亨，利牝马之贞。君子有攸往，先迷后得主，利西南得朋，东北丧朋。安贞，吉。

Lines.L1: 初六：履霜，坚冰至。
Lines.L2: 六二：直，方，大，不习无不利。
Lines.L3: 六三：含章可贞。或从王事，无成有终。
Lines.L4: 六四：括囊；无咎，无誉。
Lines.L5: 六五：黄裳，元吉。
Lines.L6: 上六：龙战于野，其血玄黄。

Exegesis.Judgment: 至哉坤元，万物资生，乃顺承天。坤厚载物，德合无疆。含弘光大，品物咸亨。牝马地类，行地无疆，柔顺利贞。君子攸行，先迷失道，后顺得常。西南得朋，乃与类行；东北丧朋，乃终有庆。安贞之吉，应地无疆。

Imagery.Hexagram: 地势坤，君子以厚德载物。

Lines.L1: 履霜坚冰，阴始凝也。驯致其道，至坚冰也。
Lines.L2: 六二之动，直以方也。不习无不利，地道光也。
Lines.L3: 含章可贞；以时发也。或从王事，知光大也。
Lines.L4: 括囊无咎，慎不害也。
Lines.L5: 黄裳元吉，文在中也。
Lines.L6: 战龙于野，其道穷也。

Scripture.Hexagram:
THE RECEPTIVE brings about sublime success,
Furthering through the perseverance of a mare.
If the superior man undertakes something and tries to lead,
He goes astray;
But if he follows, he finds guidance.
It is favorable to find friends in the west and south,
To forego friends in the east and north.
Quiet perseverance brings good fortune.

Lines.L1:
Six at the beginning means:
When there is hoarfrost underfoot,
Solid ice is not far off.
Lines.L2:
Six in the second place means:
Straight, square, great.
Without purpose,
Yet nothing remains unfurthered.
Lines.L3:
Six in the third place means:
Hidden lines.
One is able to remain persevering.
If by chance you are in the service of a king,
Seek not works, but bring to completion.
Lines.L4:
Six in the fourth place means:
A tied-up sack. No blame, no praise.
Lines.L5:
Six in the fifth place means:
A yellow lower garment brings supreme good fortune.
Lines.L6:
Six at the top means:
Dragons fight in the meadow.
Their blood is black and yellow.

Exegesis.Judgment:
Perfect indeed is the sublimity of the Receptive. All beings owe their birth to it, because it receives the heavenly with devotion.
The Receptive in its riches carries all things. Its nature is in harmony with the boundless. It embraces everything in its breadth and illumines everything in its greatness. Through it, all individual beings attain success.
A mare belongs to the creatures of the earth; she roams the earth without bound. Yielding, devoted, furthering through perseverance: thus the superior man has a direction for his way of life.
Taking the lead brings confusion because one loses his way. Following with devotion—thus does one attain his permanent place.
In the west and south one finds friends, so that he proceeds with people of his own kind. In the east and north one must do without friends, so that he finally attains good fortune.
The good fortune of rest and perseverance depends on our being in accord with the boundless nature of the earth.

Imagery.Hexagram:
The earth’s condition is receptive devotion.
Thus the superior man who has breadth of character
Carries the outer world.

Lines.L1:
Six at the beginning:
a) When there is hoarfrost underfoot, solid ice is not far off.
b) “When there is hoarfrost underfoot, solid ice is not far off.” When the dark power begins to grow rigid and continues in this way, things reach the point of solid ice.2
Lines.L2:
Six in the second place:
a) Straight, square, great. Without purpose, yet nothing remains unfurthered
b) The movement of the six in the second place is straight and, because of this, square.
“Without purpose, yet nothing remains unfurthered”: for in the nature of the earth lies the light.
Lines.L3:
Six in the third place:
a) Hidden lines. One is able to remain persevering.
If by chance you are in the service of a king,
Seek not works, but bring to completion.
b) “Hidden lines. One is able to remain persevering.” One must let them shine forth at the right time.
“If by chance you are in the service of a king….“4 This shows that the light of wisdom is great.
Lines.L4:
Six in the fourth place:
a) A tied-up sack. No blame, no praise.
b) “A tied-up sack. No blame.” Through caution one remains free of harm.
Lines.L5:
Six in the fifth place:
a) A yellow lower garment brings supreme good fortune.
b) “A yellow lower garment brings supreme good fortune.” Beauty is within.
Lines.L6:
Six at the top:
a) Dragons fight in the meadow.
Their blood is black and yellow.
b) “Dragons fight in the meadow.” The way comes to an end.

Exegesis.Miscellaneous: THE RECEPTIVE is yielding.

Scripture.Hexagram: Khwăn (represents) what is great and originating, penetrating, advantageous, correct and having the firmness of a mare. When the superior man (here intended) has to make any movement, if he take the initiative, he will go astray; if he follow, he will find his (proper) lord. The advantageousness will be seen in his getting friends in the south-west, and losing friends in the north-east. If he rest in correctness and firmness, there will be good fortune.

Lines.L1: 1. In the first SIX, divided, (we see its subject) treading on hoarfrost. The strong ice will come (by and by).
Lines.L2: 2. The second SIX, divided, (shows the attribute of) being straight, square, and great. (Its operation), without repeated efforts, will be in every respect advantageous.
Lines.L3: 3. The third SIX, divided, (shows its subject) keeping his excellence under restraint, but firmly maintaining it. If he should have occasion to engage in the king's service, though he will not claim the success (for himself), he will bring affairs to a good issue.
Lines.L4: 4. The fourth SIX, divided, (shows the symbol of) a sack tied up. There will be no ground for blame or for praise.
Lines.L5: 5. The fifth SIX, divided, (shows) the yellow lower garment. There will be great good fortune.
Lines.L6: 6. The sixth SIX, divided (shows) dragons fighting in the wild. Their blood is purple and yellow.

Exegesis.Judgment:
II. 1. Complete is the 'great and originating (capacity)' indicated by Khwăn! All things owe to it their birth;--it receives obediently the influences of Heaven.
2. Khwăn, in its largeness, supports and contains all things. Its excellent capacity matches the unlimited power (of Khien). Its comprehension is wide, and its brightness great. The various things obtain (by it) their full development.
3. The mare is a creature of earthly kind. Its (power of) moving on the earth is without limit; it is mild and docile, advantageous and firm:--such is the course of the superior man.
4. 'If he take the initiative, he goes astray:'--he misses, that is, his proper course. 'If he follow,' he is docile, and gets into his regular (course). 'In the south-west he will get friends:'--he will be walking with those of his own class. 'In the north-east he will lose friends:'--but in the end there will be ground for congratulation.
5. 'The good fortune arising from resting in firmness' corresponds to the unlimited capacity of the earth.

Imagery.Hexagram: II. The (capacity and sustaining) power of the earth is what is denoted by Khwăn. The superior man, in accordance with this, with his large virtue supports (men and) things.

Lines.L1: 1. 'He is treading on hoarfrost;--the strong ice will come (by and by):'--the cold (air) has begun to take form. Allow it to go on quietly according to its nature, and (the hoarfrost) will come to strong ice.
Lines.L2: 2. The movement indicated by the second six, (divided),is 'from the straight (line) to the square.' '(Its operation), without repeated effort, in every way advantageous,' shows the brilliant result of the way of earth.
Lines.L3: 3. 'He keeps his excellence tinder restraint, but firmly maintains it:'--at the proper time he will manifest it. 'He may have occasion to engage in the king's service:--great is the glory of his wisdom.
Lines.L4: 4. 'A sack tied up;--there will be no error:'--this shows how, through carefulness, no injury will be received.
Lines.L5: 5. 'The Yellow lower-garment;--there will be great good fortune:'--this follows from that ornamental (colour's) being in the right and central place.
Lines.L6: 6. 'The dragons fight in the wild:--the (onward) course (indicated by Khwăn) is pursued to extremity.7. '(The lines are all weak and divided, as appears from) the use of the number SIX:--but (those who are thus represented) becoming perpetually correct and firm, there will thereby be a great consummation.

Exegesis.Miscellaneous: 1, 2. Strength in Khien, weakness in Khwăn we find.
Exegesis.Sequence: 1-3. When there were heaven and earth, then afterwards all things were produced. What fills up (the space) between heaven and earth are (those) all things. Hence (Khien and Khwăn) are followed by Kun. Kun denotes filling up.

Unicode.Name: Hexagram For Difficulty At The Beginning

Scripture.Hexagram: 屯：元亨，利貞，勿用有攸往，利建侯。

Lines.L1: 初九：磐桓；利居貞，利建侯。
Lines.L2: 六二：屯如邅如，乘馬班如。匪寇婚媾，女子貞不字，十年乃字。
Lines.L3: 六三：即鹿无虞，惟入于林中，君子幾不如舍，往吝。
Lines.L4: 六四：乘馬班如，求婚媾，往吉，无不利。
Lines.L5: 九五：屯其膏，小貞吉，大貞凶。
Lines.L6: 上六：乘馬班如，泣血漣如。

Exegesis.Judgment: 屯，剛柔始交而難生，動乎險中，大亨貞。雷雨之動滿盈，天造草昧，宜建侯而不寧。

Imagery.Hexagram: 雲，雷，屯；君子以經綸。

Lines.L1: 雖磐桓，志行正也。以貴下賤，大得民也。
Lines.L2: 六二之難，乘剛也。十年乃字，反常也。
Lines.L3: 即鹿无虞，以縱禽也。君子舍之，往吝窮也。
Lines.L4: 求而往，明也。
Lines.L5: 屯其膏，施未光也。
Lines.L6: 泣血漣如，何可長也。

Scripture.Hexagram: 屯：元亨，利贞，勿用有攸往，利建侯。

Lines.L1: 初九：磐桓；利居贞，利建侯。
Lines.L2: 六二：屯如邅如，乘马班如。匪寇婚媾，女子贞不字，十年乃字。
Lines.L3: 六三：即鹿无虞，惟入于林中，君子几不如舍，往吝。
Lines.L4: 六四：乘马班如，求婚媾，往吉，无不利。
Lines.L5: 九五：屯其膏，小贞吉，大贞凶。
Lines.L6: 上六：乘马班如，泣血涟如。

Exegesis.Judgment: 屯，刚柔始交而难生，动乎险中，大亨贞。雷雨之动满盈，天造草昧，宜建侯而不宁。

Imagery.Hexagram: 云，雷，屯；君子以经纶。

Lines.L1: 虽磐桓，志行正也。以贵下贱，大得民也。
Lines.L2: 六二之难，乘刚也。十年乃字，反常也。
Lines.L3: 即鹿无虞，以纵禽也。君子舍之，往吝穷也。
Lines.L4: 求而往，明也。
Lines.L5: 屯其膏，施未光也。
Lines.L6: 泣血涟如，何可长也。

Scripture.Hexagram:
Difficulty at the Beginning works supreme success,
Furthering through perseverance.
Nothing should be undertaken.
It furthers one to appoint helpers.

Lines.L1:
Nine at the beginning means:
Hesitation and hindrance.
It furthers one to remain persevering.
It furthers one to appoint helpers.
Lines.L2:
Six in the second place means:
Difficulties pile up.
Horse and wagon part.
He is not a robber;
He wants to woo when the time comes.
The maiden is chaste,
She does not pledge herself.
Ten years—then she pledges herself.
Lines.L3:
Six in the third place means:
Whoever hunts deer without the forester
Only loses his way in the forest.
The superior man understands the signs of the time
And prefers to desist.
To go on brings humiliation.
Lines.L4:
Six in the fourth place means:
Horse and wagon part.
Strive for union.
To go brings good fortune.
Everything acts to further.
Lines.L5:
Nine in the fifth place means:
Difficulties in blessing.
A little perseverance brings good fortune.
Great perseverance brings misfortune.
Lines.L6:
Six at the top means:
Horse and wagon part.
Bloody tears flow.

Exegesis.Judgment:
DIFFICULTY AT THE BEGINNING: the firm and the yielding unite for the first time, and the birth is difficult.
Movement in the midst of danger brings great success and perseverance.
The movement of thunder and rain fills the atmosphere. If chaos and darkness prevail while heaven is creating, it is fitting to appoint helpers, without being oneself thereby lulled to rest.

Imagery.Hexagram:
Clouds and thunder:
The image of Difficulty at the Beginning.
Thus the superior man
Brings order out of confusion.

Lines.L1:
Nine at the beginning:
a) Hesitation and hindrance.
It furthers one to remain persevering.
It furthers one to appoint helpers.
b) Although hesitation and hindrance still prevail, the aim of the work is nonetheless to carry out what is right. When an eminent man subordinates himself to his inferiors, he wins the hearts of all people.
Lines.L2:
Six in the second place:
a) Difficulties pile up.
Horse and wagon part.
He is not a robber;
He wants to woo when the time comes.
The maiden is chaste,
She does not pledge herself.
Ten years—then she pledges herself.
b) The difficulty of the six in the second place is that it rests upon a rigid line. Pledging herself after ten years means return to the general rule.
Lines.L3:
Six in the third place:
a) Whoever hunts deer without the forester
Only loses his way in the forest.
The superior man understands the signs of the time
And prefers to desist.
To go on brings humiliation.
b) “He hunts deer without the forester,” that is, he desires the game.
“The superior man understands the signs of the time and prefers to desist. To go on brings humiliation.”
It leads to failure.
Lines.L4:
Six in the fourth place:
a) Horse and wagon part.
Strive for union.
To go brings good fortune.
Everything acts to further.
b) To go only when bidden—this is clarity.
Lines.L5:
Nine in the fifth place:
a) Difficulties in blessing.
A little perseverance brings good fortune.
Great perseverance brings misfortune.
b) “Difficulties in blessing,” because the benefaction is not yet recognized.
Lines.L6:
Six at the top:
a) Horse and wagon part.
Bloody tears flow.
b) “Bloody tears flow.” How could one tarry long in this!

Exegesis.Miscellaneous: Chun is visible but has not yet lost its dwelling.
Exegesis.Sequence: After heaven and earth have come into existence, individual beings develop. It is these individual beings that fill the space between heaven and earth. Hence there follows the hexagram of DIFFICULTY AT THE BEGINNING. Difficulty at the beginning is the same as filling up.

Scripture.Hexagram: Kun (indicates that in the case which it presupposes) there will be great progress and success, and the advantage will come from being correct and firm. (But) any movement in advance should not be (lightly) undertaken. There will be advantage in appointing feudal princes.

Lines.L1: 1. The first NINE, undivided, shows the difficulty (its subject has) in advancing. It will be advantageous for him to abide correct and firm; advantageous (also) to be made a feudal ruler.
Lines.L2: 2. The second SIX, divided, shows (its subject) distressed and obliged to return; (even) the horses of her chariot (also) seem to be retreating. (But) not by a spoiler (is she assailed), but by one who seeks her to be his wife. The young lady maintains her firm correctness, and declines a union. After ten years she will be united, and have children.
Lines.L3: 3. The third SIX, divided, shows one following the deer without (the guidance of) the forester, and only finding himself in the midst of the forest. The superior man, acquainted with the secret risks, thinks it better to give up the chase. If he went forward, he would regret it.
Lines.L4: 4. The fourth SIX, divided, shows (its subject as a lady), the horses of whose chariot appear in retreat. She seeks, however, (the help of) him who seeks her to be his wife. Advance will be fortunate; all will turn out advantageously.
Lines.L5: 5. The fifth NINE, undivided, shows the difficulties in the way of (its subject's) dispensing the rich favours that might be expected from him. With firmness and correctness there will be good fortune in small things; (even) with them in great things there will be evil.
Lines.L6: 6. The topmost SIX, divided, shows (its subject) with the horses of his chariot obliged to retreat, and weeping tears of blood in streams.

Exegesis.Judgment:
III. 1. In Kun we have the strong (Khien) and the weak (Khwăn) commencing their intercourse, and difficulties arising.
2. Movement in the midst of peril gives rise to 'great progress and success, (through) firm correctness.'
3. By the action of the thunder and rain, (whichare symbols of Kăn and Khan), all (between heaven and earth) is filled up. But the condition of the time is full of irregularity and obscurity. Feudal princes should be established, but the feeling that rest and peace have been secured should not be indulged (even then).

Imagery.Hexagram: III. (The trigram representing) clouds and (that representing) thunder form Kun. The superior man, in accordance with this, (adjusts his measures of government) as in sorting the threads of the warp and woof.

Lines.L1: 1. Although 'there is a difficulty in advancing,' the mind (of the subject of the line) is set on doing what is correct. While noble, he humbles himself to the mean, and grandly gains the people.
Lines.L2: 2. The difficulty (to the subject of) the second six, (divided), arises from, its place over the undivided line below it. 'The union and children after ten years' shows things resuming their regular course.
Lines.L3: 3. 'One pursues the deer without the (guidance of the) forester:'--(he does so) in (his eagerness to) follow the game. 'The superior man gives up the chase, (knowing that) if he go forward he will regret it:'--he would be reduced to extremity.
Lines.L4: 4. 'Going forward after such a search (for a helper)' shows intelligence.
Lines.L5: 5. 'Difficulty is experienced (by the subject of the fifth line) in bestowing his rich favours:'--the extent to which they reach will not yet be conspicuous.
Lines.L6: 6. 'He weeps tears of blood in streams:'--how can the state (thus emblemed) continue long?

Exegesis.Sequence:
1-3. When there were heaven and earth, then afterwards all things were produced. What fills up (the space) between heaven and earth are (those) all things. Hence (Khien and Khwăn) are followed by Kun. Kun denotes filling up.
3-6. Kun is descriptive of things on their first production. When so produced, they are sure to be in an undeveloped condition. Hence Kun is followed by Măng. Măng is descriptive of what is undeveloped,--the young of creatures and things. These in that state require to be nourished. Hence Măng is followed by Hsü. Hsü is descriptive of the way in which meat and drink (come to be supplied). Over meat and drink there are sure to be contentions. Hence Hsü is followed by Sung.

Scripture.Hexagram: 蒙：亨。匪我求童蒙，童蒙求我。初筮告，再三瀆，瀆則不告。利貞。

Lines.L1: 初六：發蒙，利用刑人，用說桎梏，以往吝。
Lines.L2: 九二：包蒙吉；納婦吉；子克家。
Lines.L3: 六三：勿用取女；見金夫，不有躬，无攸利。
Lines.L4: 六四：困蒙，吝。
Lines.L5: 六五：童蒙，吉。
Lines.L6: 上九：擊蒙；不利為寇，利禦寇。

Exegesis.Judgment: 蒙，山下有險，險而止，蒙。蒙亨，以亨行時中也。匪我求童蒙，童蒙求我，志應也。初噬告，以剛中也。再三瀆，瀆則不告，瀆蒙也。蒙以養正，聖功也。

Imagery.Hexagram: 山下出泉，蒙；君子以果行育德。

Lines.L1: 利用刑人，以正法也。
Lines.L2: 子克家，剛柔接也。
Lines.L3: 勿用取女，行不順也。
Lines.L4: 困蒙之吝，獨遠實也。
Lines.L5: 童蒙之吉，順以巽也。
Lines.L6: 利用禦寇，上下順也。

Scripture.Hexagram: 蒙：亨。匪我求童蒙，童蒙求我。初筮告，再三渎，渎则不告。利贞。

Lines.L1: 初六：发蒙，利用刑人，用说桎梏，以往吝。
Lines.L2: 九二：包蒙吉；纳妇吉；子克家。
Lines.L3: 六三：勿用取女；见金夫，不有躬，无攸利。
Lines.L4: 六四：困蒙，吝。
Lines.L5: 六五：童蒙，吉。
Lines.L6: 上九：击蒙；不利为寇，利御寇。

Exegesis.Judgment: 蒙，山下有险，险而止，蒙。蒙亨，以亨行时中也。匪我求童蒙，童蒙求我，志应也。初噬告，以刚中也。再三渎，渎则不告，渎蒙也。蒙以养正，圣功也。

Imagery.Hexagram: 山下出泉，蒙；君子以果行育德。

Lines.L1: 利用刑人，以正法也。
Lines.L2: 子克家，刚柔接也。
Lines.L3: 勿用取女，行不顺也。
Lines.L4: 困蒙之吝，独远实也。
Lines.L5: 童蒙之吉，顺以巽也。
Lines.L6: 利用御寇，上下顺也。

Scripture.Hexagram:
YOUTHFUL FOLLY has success.
It is not I who seek the young fool;
The young fool seeks me.
At the first oracle I inform him.
If he asks two or three times, it is importunity.
If he importunes, I give him no information.
Perseverance furthers.

Lines.L1:
Six at the beginning means:
To make a fool develop
It furthers one to apply discipline.
The fetters should be removed.
To go on in this way brings humiliation.
Lines.L2:
Nine in the second place means:
To bear with fools in kindliness brings good fortune.
To know how to take women
Brings good fortune.
The son is capable of taking charge of the household.
Lines.L3:
Six in the third place means:
Take not a maiden who, when she sees a man of bronze,
Loses possession of herself.
Nothing furthers.
Lines.L4:
Six in the fourth place means:
Entangled folly brings humiliation.
Lines.L5:
Six in the fifth place means:
Childlike folly brings good fortune.
Lines.L6:
Nine at the top means:
In punishing folly
It does not further one
To commit transgressions.
The only thing that furthers
Is to prevent transgressions.

Exegesis.Judgment:
YOUTHFUL FOLLY shows danger at the foot of a mountain. Danger and standstill: this is folly.
“FOLLY has success.” One who succeeds hits upon the right time for his undertaking.
“It is not I who seek the young fool; the young fool seeks me.” The two positions correspond.
“At the first oracle I answer,” because the position is firm and central.
“If someone asks two or three times, it is importunity. If he importunes, I give no answer.” To importune is folly.
To strengthen what is right in a fool is a holy task.

Imagery.Hexagram:
A spring wells up at the foot of the mountain:
The image Of YOUTH.
Thus the superior man fosters his character
By thoroughness in all that he does.

Lines.L1:
Six at the beginning:
a) To make a fool develop
It furthers one to apply discipline.
The fetters should be removed.
To go on in this way brings humiliation.
b) “It furthers one to apply discipline”—that is, in order to give emphasis to the law.
Lines.L2:
Nine in the second place:
a) To bear with fools in kindliness brings good fortune.
To know how to take women
Brings good fortune.
The son is capable of taking charge of the household.
b) “The son is capable of taking charge of the household,” for firm and yielding are in union.
Lines.L3:
Six in the third place:
a) Take not a maiden who, when she sees a man of bronze,
Loses possession of herself.
Nothing furthers.
b) One should not take the maiden because her conduct is not in accord with order.
Lines.L4:
Six in the fourth place:
a) Entangled youthful folly brings humiliation.
b) The humiliation of entangled youthful folly comes from the fact that it of all things is furthest from what is real.
Lines.L5:
Six in the fifth place:
a) Childlike folly brings good fortune.
b) The good fortune of the childlike fool comes from his being devoted and gentle.
Lines.L6:
Nine at the top:
a) In punishing folly
It does not further one
To commit transgressions.
The only thing that furthers
Is to prevent transgressions.
b) “It furthers to prevent transgressions,” for then those above and those below conform to order.

Exegesis.Miscellaneous: YOUTHFUL FOLLY means confusion and subsequent enlightenment.
Exegesis.Sequence: When, after difficulties at the beginning, things have just been born, they are always wrapped at birth in obtuseness. Hence there follows the hexagram of YOUTHFUL FOLLY. For youthful folly means youthful obtuseness. This is the state of things in their youth.

Scripture.Hexagram: Măng (indicates that in the case which it presupposes) there will be progress and success. I do not (go and) seek the youthful and inexperienced, but he comes and seeks me. When he shows (the sincerity that marks) the first recourse to divination, I instruct him. If he apply a second and third time, that is troublesome; and I do not instruct the troublesome. There will be advantage in being firm and correct.

Lines.L1: 1. The first SIX, divided, (has respect to) the dispelling of ignorance. It will be advantageous to use punishment (for that purpose), and to remove the shackles (from the mind). But going on in that way (of punishment) will give occasion for regret.
Lines.L2: 2. The second NINE, undivided, (shows its subject) exercising forbearance with the ignorant, in which there will be good fortune; and admitting (even the goodness of women, which will also be fortunate). (He may be described also as) a son able to (sustain the burden of) his family.
Lines.L3: 3. The third SIX, divided, (seems to say) that one should not marry a woman whose emblem it might be, for that, when she sees a man of wealth, she will not keep her person from him, and in no wise will advantage come from her.
Lines.L4: 4. The fourth SIX, divided, (shows its subject as if) bound in chains of ignorance. There will be occasion for regret.
Lines.L5: 5. The fifth SIX, divided, shows its subject as a simple lad without experience. There will be good fortune.
Lines.L6: 6. In the topmost NINE, undivided, we see one smiting the ignorant (youth). But no advantage will come from doing him an injury. Advantage would come from warding off injury from him.

Exegesis.Judgment:
IV. 1. In Măng we have (the trigram for) a mountain, and below it that of a rugged defile with a stream in it. The conditions of peril and arrestof progress (suggested by these) give (the idea in) Măng.
2. 'Măng indicates that there will be progress and success:'--for there is development at work in it, and its time of action is exactly what is right. 'I do not seek the youthful and inexperienced; he seeks me:'--so does will respond to will. 'When he shows (the sincerity that marks) the first recourse to divination, I instruct him:'--for possessing the qualities of the undivided line and being in the central place, (the subject of the second line thus speaks). 'A second and third application create annoyance, and I do not instruct so as to create annoyance:'--annoyance (he means) to the ignorant.(The method of dealing with) the young and ignorant is to nourish the correct (nature belonging to them);--this accomplishes the service of the sage.

Imagery.Hexagram: IV. (The trigram representing) a mountain, and beneath it that for a spring issuing forth form Măng. The superior man, in accordance with this, strives to be resolute in his conduct and nourishes his virtue.

Lines.L1: 1. 'It will be advantageous to use punishment:'--the object being to bring under the influence of correcting law.
Lines.L2: 2. 'A son able to (sustain the burden of) his family:'--as appears from the reciprocation between this strong line and the weak (fifth line).
Lines.L3: 3. 'A woman (such as is here represented) should not be taken in marriage:'--her conduct is not agreeable to what is right.
Lines.L4: 4. 'The regret arising from ignorance bound in chains' is due to the special distance of (the subject of this line) from the solidity (shown in lines 2 and 6).
Lines.L5: 5. 'The good fortune belonging to the simple lad without experience' comes from his docility going on to humility.
Lines.L6: 6. 'Advantage will come from warding off injury:'--(the subject of this line) above and (the ignorant) below, all do and are done to in accordance with their nature.

Exegesis.Sequence: 3-6. Kun is descriptive of things on their first production. When so produced, they are sure to be in an undeveloped condition. Hence Kun is followed by Măng. Măng is descriptive of what is undeveloped,--the young of creatures and things. These in that state require to be nourished. Hence Măng is followed by Hsü. Hsü is descriptive of the way in which meat and drink (come to be supplied). Over meat and drink there are sure to be contentions. Hence Hsü is followed by Sung.

Scripture.Hexagram: 需：有孚，光亨，貞吉。利涉大川。

Lines.L1: 初九：需于郊。利用恆，无咎。
Lines.L2: 九二：需于沙。小有言，終吉。
Lines.L3: 九三：需于泥，致寇至。
Lines.L4: 六四：需于血，出自穴。
Lines.L5: 九五：需于酒食，貞吉。
Lines.L6: 上六：入于穴，有不速之客三人來，敬之終吉。

Exegesis.Judgment: 需，須也；險在前也。剛健而不陷，其義不困窮矣。需有孚，光亨，貞吉。位乎天位，以正中也。利涉大川，往有功也。

Imagery.Hexagram: 雲上於天，需；君子以飲食宴樂。

Lines.L1: 需于郊，不犯難行也。利用恆，无咎；未失常也。
Lines.L2: 需于沙，衍在中也。雖小有言，以終吉也。
Lines.L3: 需于泥，災在外也。自我致寇，敬慎不敗也。
Lines.L4: 需于血，順以聽也。
Lines.L5: 酒食貞吉，以中正也。
Lines.L6: 不速之客來，敬之終吉。雖不當位，未大失也。

Scripture.Hexagram: 需：有孚，光亨，贞吉。利涉大川。

Lines.L1: 初九：需于郊。利用恒，无咎。
Lines.L2: 九二：需于沙。小有言，终吉。
Lines.L3: 九三：需于泥，致寇至。
Lines.L4: 六四：需于血，出自穴。
Lines.L5: 九五：需于酒食，贞吉。
Lines.L6: 上六：入于穴，有不速之客三人来，敬之终吉。

Exegesis.Judgment: 需，须也；险在前也。刚健而不陷，其义不困穷矣。需有孚，光亨，贞吉。位乎天位，以正中也。利涉大川，往有功也。

Imagery.Hexagram: 云上于天，需；君子以饮食宴乐。

Lines.L1: 需于郊，不犯难行也。利用恒，无咎；未失常也。
Lines.L2: 需于沙，衍在中也。虽小有言，以终吉也。
Lines.L3: 需于泥，灾在外也。自我致寇，敬慎不败也。
Lines.L4: 需于血，顺以听也。
Lines.L5: 酒食贞吉，以中正也。
Lines.L6: 不速之客来，敬之终吉。虽不当位，未大失也。

Scripture.Hexagram:
WAITING. If you are sincere,
You have light and success.
Perseverance brings good fortune.
It furthers one to cross the great water.

Lines.L1:
Nine at the beginning means:
Waiting in the meadow.
It furthers one to abide in what endures.
No blame.
Lines.L2:
Nine in the second place means:
Waiting on the sand.
There is some gossip.
The end brings good fortune.
Lines.L3:
Nine in the third place means:
Waiting in the mud
Brings about the arrival of the enemy.
Lines.L4:
Six in the fourth place means:
Waiting in blood.
Get out of the pit.
Lines.L5:
Nine in the fifth place means:
Waiting at meat and drink.
Perseverance brings good fortune.
Lines.L6:
Six at the top means:
One falls into the pit.
Three uninvited guests arrive.
Honor them, and in the end there will be good fortune.

Exegesis.Judgment:
WAITING means holding back. Danger lies ahead. Being firm and strong, one does not fall into it. The meaning is that one does not become perplexed or bewildered.
“If you are sincere, you have light and success. Perseverance brings good fortune.” For the ruling line occupies the place of heaven and is central and correct in its behavior.
“It furthers one to cross the great water.” Through progress the work is accomplished.

Imagery.Hexagram:
Clouds rise up to heaven:
The image of WAITING.
Thus the superior man eats and drinks,
Is joyous and of good cheer.

Lines.L1:
Nine at the beginning:
a) Waiting in the meadow.
It furthers one to abide in what endures.
No blame.
b) “Waiting in the meadow.” One does not seek out difficulties overhastily.
“It furthers one to abide in what endures. No blame.” One has not abandoned the general ground.
Lines.L2:
Nine in the second place:
a) Waiting on the sand.
There is some gossip.
The end brings good fortune.
b) “Waiting on the sand.” One is calm, for the line is central. Although this leads to some gossip, the end brings good fortune.
Lines.L3:
Nine in the third place:
a) Waiting in the mud
Brings about the arrival of the enemy.
b) “Waiting in the mud.” The misfortune is outside.1
“Brings about the arrival of the enemy.” Seriousness and caution prevent defeat.
Lines.L4:
Six in the fourth place:
a) Waiting in blood.
Get out of the pit.
b) “Waiting in blood.” He is yielding and obeys.
Lines.L5:
Nine in the fifth place:
a) Waiting at meat and drink.
Perseverance brings good fortune.
b) “Meat and drink. Perseverance brings good fortune,” because of the central and correct character.
Lines.L6:
Six at the top:
a) One falls into the pit.
Three uninvited guests arrive.
Honor them, and in the end there will be good fortune.
b) “Uninvited guests arrive. If they are honored, in the end there will be good fortune.” Although the line is not in its proper place, at least no great mistake is made.

Exegesis.Miscellaneous: WAITING means not advancing.
Exegesis.Sequence: When things are still small, one must not leave them without nourishment. Hence there follows the hexagram Hsü. Hsü means the way to eating and drinking.

Scripture.Hexagram: Hsü intimates that, with the sincerity which is declared in it, there will be brilliant success. With firmness there will be good fortune; and it will be advantageous to cross the great stream.

Lines.L1: 1. The first NINE, undivided, shows its subject waiting in the distant border. It will be well for him constantly to maintain (the purpose thus shown), in which case there will be no error.
Lines.L2: 2. The second NINE, undivided, shows its subject waiting on the sand (of the mountain stream). He will (suffer) the small (injury of) being spoken (against), but in the end there will be good fortune.
Lines.L3: 3. The third NINE, undivided, shows its subject in the mud (close by the stream). He thereby invites the approach of injury.
Lines.L4: 4. The fourth SIX, divided, shows its subject waiting in (the place of) blood. But he will get out of the cavern.
Lines.L5: 5. The fifth NINE, undivided, shows its subject waiting amidst the appliances of a feast. Through his firmness and correctness there will be good fortune.
Lines.L6: 6. The topmost SIX, divided, shows its subject entered into the cavern. (But) there are three guests coming, without being urged, (to his help). If he receive them respectfully, there will be good fortune in the end.

Exegesis.Judgment:
V. 1. Hsü denotes waiting. (The figure) shows peril in front; but notwithstanding the firmness and strength (indicated by the inner trigram), its subject does not allow himself to be involved (in the dangerous defile);--it is right he should not be straitened or reduced to extremity.
2. When it is said that, 'with the sincerity declared in Hsü, there will be brilliant success, and with firmness there will be good fortune,' this is shown by the position (of the fifth line) in the place assigned by Heaven, and its being the correct position for it, and in the centre. 'It will be advantageous to go through the great stream;'--that is, going forward will be followed by meritorious achievement.

Imagery.Hexagram: V. (The trigram for) clouds ascending over thatfor the sky forms Hsü. The superior man, in accordance with this, eats and drinks, feasts and enjoys himself (as if there were nothing else to employ him).

Lines.L1: 1. 'He is waiting in the (distant) border:'--he makes no movement to encounter rashly the difficulties (of the situation). 'It will be advantageous for him constantly to maintain (the purpose thus shown), in which case there will be no error:'--he will not fail to pursue that regular course.
Lines.L2: 2. 'He is waiting on the sand:'--he occupies his position in the centre with a generous forbearance. Though 'he suffer the small injury of being spoken (against),' he will bring things to a good issue.
Lines.L3: 3. 'He is waiting in the mud:'--calamity is (close at hand, and as it were) in the outer (trigram). 'He himself invites the approach of injury:'--if he be reverent and careful, he will not be worsted.
Lines.L4: 4. 'He is waiting in (the place of) blood:'--he accommodates himself (to the circumstances of the time), and hearkens to (its requirements).
Lines.L5: 5. 'The appliances of a feast, and the good fortune through being firm and correct,' are indicated by (the position in) the central and correct place.
Lines.L6: 6. 'Guests come unurged (to give their help), and if (the subject of the line) receive them respectfully, there will be good fortune in the end:'--though the occupant and the place are not suited to each other, there has been no great failure (in what has been done).

Exegesis.Sequence: 3-6. Kun is descriptive of things on their first production. When so produced, they are sure to be in an undeveloped condition. Hence Kun is followed by Măng. Măng is descriptive of what is undeveloped,--the young of creatures and things. These in that state require to be nourished. Hence Măng is followed by Hsü. Hsü is descriptive of the way in which meat and drink (come to be supplied). Over meat and drink there are sure to be contentions. Hence Hsü is followed by Sung.

Scripture.Hexagram: 訟：有孚，窒。惕中吉。終凶。利見大人，不利涉大川。

Lines.L1: 初六：不永所事，小有言，終吉。
Lines.L2: 九二：不克訟，歸而逋，其邑人三百戶，无眚。
Lines.L3: 六三：食舊德，貞厲，終吉，或從王事，无成。
Lines.L4: 九四：不克訟，復即命渝，安貞吉。
Lines.L5: 九五：訟元吉。
Lines.L6: 上九：或錫之鞶帶，終朝三褫之。

Exegesis.Judgment: 訟，上剛下險，險而健訟。訟有孚窒，惕中吉，剛來而得中也。終凶；訟不可成也。利見大人；尚中正也。不利涉大川；入于淵也。

Imagery.Hexagram: 天與水違行，訟；君子以作事謀始。

Lines.L1: 不永所事，訟不可長也。雖有小言，其辯明也。
Lines.L2: 不克訟，歸而逋也。自下訟上，患至掇也。
Lines.L3: 食舊德，從上吉也。
Lines.L4: 復即命，渝安貞；不失也。
Lines.L5: 訟元吉，以中正也。
Lines.L6: 以訟受服，亦不足敬也。

Scripture.Hexagram: 讼：有孚，窒。惕中吉。终凶。利见大人，不利涉大川。

Lines.L1: 初六：不永所事，小有言，终吉。
Lines.L2: 九二：不克讼，归而逋，其邑人三百户，无眚。
Lines.L3: 六三：食旧德，贞厉，终吉，或从王事，无成。
Lines.L4: 九四：不克讼，复即命渝，安贞吉。
Lines.L5: 九五：讼元吉。
Lines.L6: 上九：或锡之鞶带，终朝三褫之。

Exegesis.Judgment: 讼，上刚下险，险而健讼。讼有孚窒，惕中吉，刚来而得中也。终凶；讼不可成也。利见大人；尚中正也。不利涉大川；入于渊也。

Imagery.Hexagram: 天与水违行，讼；君子以作事谋始。

Lines.L1: 不永所事，讼不可长也。虽有小言，其辩明也。
Lines.L2: 不克讼，归而逋也。自下讼上，患至掇也。
Lines.L3: 食旧德，从上吉也。
Lines.L4: 复即命，渝安贞；不失也。
Lines.L5: 讼元吉，以中正也。
Lines.L6: 以讼受服，亦不足敬也。

Scripture.Hexagram:
CONFLICT. You are sincere
And are being obstructed.
A cautious halt halfway brings good fortune.
Going through to the end brings misfortune.
It furthers one to see the great man.
It does not further one to cross the great water.

Lines.L1:
Six at the beginning means:
If one does not perpetuate the affair,
There is a little gossip.
In the end, good fortune comes.
Lines.L2:
Nine in the second place means:
One cannot engage in conflict;
One returns home, gives way.
The people of his town,
Three hundred households,
Remain free of guilt.
Lines.L3:
Six in the third place means:
To nourish oneself on ancient virtue induces perseverance.
Danger. In the end, good fortune comes.
If by chance you are in the service of a king,
Seek not works.
Lines.L4:
Nine in the fourth place means:
One cannot engage in conflict.
One turns back and submits to fate,
Changes one’s attitude,
And finds peace in perseverance.
Good fortune.
Lines.L5:
Nine in the fifth place means:
To contend before him
Brings supreme good fortune.
Lines.L6:
Nine at the top means:
Even if by chance a leather belt is bestowed on one,
By the end of a morning
It will have been snatched away three times.

Exegesis.Judgment:
CONFLICT: strength is above, danger below. Danger and strength produce conflict.
“The contender is sincere and is being obstructed.”
The firm comes and attains the middle.
“Going through to the end brings misfortune. A conflict must not be allowed to become permanent.”
“It furthers one to see the great man”: thus his central and correct position is honored.
“It does not further one to cross the great water,” for this would lead one into the abyss.

Imagery.Hexagram:
Heaven and water go their opposite ways:
The image of CONFLICT.
Thus in all his transactions the superior man
Carefully considers the beginning.

Lines.L1:
Six at the beginning:
a) If one does not perpetuate the affair,
There is a little gossip.
In the end, good fortune comes.
b) Not perpetuating the affair: one must not prolong the conflict.
Although “there is a little gossip,” the matter is finally decided clearly.
Lines.L2:
Nine in the second place:
a) One cannot engage in conflict;
One returns home, gives way.
The people of his town,
Three hundred households,
Remain free of guilt.
b) “One cannot engage in conflict: one returns home, gives way.” Thus one escapes. To contend from a lowly place with someone above brings self-incurred suffering.
Lines.L3:
Six in the third place:
a) To nourish oneself on ancient virtue induces perseverance.
Danger. In the end, good fortune comes.
If by chance you are in the service of a king,
Seek not works.
b) “To nourish oneself on ancient virtue.” To obey the one above brings good fortune.
Lines.L4:
Nine in the fourth place:
a) One cannot engage in conflict.
One turns back and submits to fate,
Changes one’s attitude,
And finds peace in perseverance.
Good fortune.
b) “One turns back and submits to fate, changes one’s attitude, and finds peace in perseverance.” Thus nothing is lost.
Lines.L5:
Nine in the fifth place:
a) To contend before him
Brings supreme good fortune.
b) “To contend before him brings supreme good fortune,” because he is central and correct.
Lines.L6:
Nine at the top:
a) Even if by chance a leather belt is bestowed on one,
By the end of a morning
It will have been snatched away three times.
b) To attain distinction through conflict is, after all, nothing to command respect.

Exegesis.Miscellaneous: CONFLICT means not to love.
Exegesis.Sequence:
Over meat and drink, there is certain to be conflict.
Hence there follows the hexagram of CONFLICT.

Scripture.Hexagram: Sung intimates how, though there is sincerity in one's contention, he will yet meet with opposition and obstruction; but if he cherish an apprehensive caution, there will be good fortune, while, if he must prosecute the contention to the (bitter) end, there will be evil. It will be advantageous to see the great man; it will not be advantageous to cross the great stream.

Lines.L1: 1. The first SIX, divided, shows its subject not perpetuating the matter about which (the contention is). He will suffer the small (injury) of being spoken against, but the end will be fortunate.
Lines.L2: 2. The second NINE, undivided, shows its subject unequal to the contention. If he retire and keep concealed (where) the inhabitants of his city are (only) three hundred families, he will fall into no mistake.
Lines.L3: 3. The third SIX, divided, shows its subject keeping in the old place assigned for his support, and firmly correct. Perilous as the position is, there will be good fortune in the end. Should he perchance engage in the king's business, he will not (claim the merit of) achievement.
Lines.L4: 4. The fourth NINE, undivided, shows its subject unequal to the contention. He returns to (the study of Heaven's) ordinances, changes (his wish to contend), and rests in being firm and correct. There will be good fortune.
Lines.L5: 5. The fifth NINE, undivided, shows its subject contending;--and with great good fortune.
Lines.L6: 6. The topmost NINE, undivided, shows how its subject may have the leathern belt conferred on him (by the sovereign), and thrice it shall be taken from him in a morning.

Exegesis.Judgment:
VI. 1. The upper portion of Sung is (the trigram representing) strength, and the lower (that representing) peril. (The coming together of) strength and peril gives (the idea in) Sung.
2. 'Sung intimates how, though there is sincerity in one's contention, he will yet meet with opposition and obstruction; but if he cherish an apprehensive caution, there will be good fortune:'--a strong (line) has come and got the central place (in the lower trigram).'If he must prosecute the contention to the (bitter) end, there will be evil:'--contention is not a thing to be carried on to extremity.'It will be advantageous to meet with the great man:'--what he sets a value on is the due mean, and the correct place.'It will not be advantageous to cross the great stream:'--one (attempting to do so) would find himself in an abyss.

Imagery.Hexagram: VI. (The trigram representing) heaven and (that representing) water, moving away from each other, form Sung. The superior man, in accordance with this, in the transaction of affairs takes good counsel about his first steps.

Lines.L1: 1. 'He does not perpetuate the matter about which (the contention is):'--contention should not be prolonged. Although 'he may suffer the small (injury) of being spoken against,' his argument is clear.
Lines.L2: 2. 'He is unequal to the contention; he retires and keeps concealed, stealthily withdrawing from it:'--for him from his lower place to contend with (the stronger one) above, would be to (invite) calamity, as if he brought it with his hand to himself.
Lines.L3: 3. 'He confines himself to the support assignedto him of old:'--(thus) following those above him, he will have good fortune.
Lines.L4: 4. 'He returns to (the study of Heaven's) ordinances, changes (his wish to contend), and rests in being firm and correct:'--he does not fail (in doing what is right).
Lines.L5: 5. 'He contends;--and 'with great fortune:--this is shown by his holding the due mean and being in the correct place.
Lines.L6: 6. 'He receives the robe through his contention:'--but still be is not deserving of respect.

Exegesis.Sequence:
3-6. Kun is descriptive of things on their first production. When so produced, they are sure to be in an undeveloped condition. Hence Kun is followed by Măng. Măng is descriptive of what is undeveloped,--the young of creatures and things. These in that state require to be nourished. Hence Măng is followed by Hsü. Hsü is descriptive of the way in which meat and drink (come to be supplied). Over meat and drink there are sure to be contentions. Hence Hsü is followed by Sung.
6-8. Sung is sure to cause the rising up of the multitudes; and hence it is followed by Sze. Sze has the signification of multitudes, and between multitudes there must be some bond of union. Hence it is followed by Pî, which denotes being attached to.

Scripture.Hexagram: 師：貞，丈人，吉无咎。

Lines.L1: 初六：師出以律，否臧凶。
Lines.L2: 九二：在師中吉，无咎，王三錫命。
Lines.L3: 六三：師或輿尸，凶。
Lines.L4: 六四：師左次，无咎。
Lines.L5: 六五：田有禽，利執言，无咎。長子帥師，弟子輿尸，貞凶。
Lines.L6: 上六：大君有命，開國承家，小人勿用。

Exegesis.Judgment: 師，眾也，貞正也，能以眾正，可以王矣。剛中而應，行險而順，以此毒天下，而民從之，吉又何咎矣。

Imagery.Hexagram: 地中有水，師；君子以容民畜眾。

Lines.L1: 師出以律，失律凶也。
Lines.L2: 在師中吉，承天寵也。王三錫命，懷萬邦也。
Lines.L3: 師或輿尸，大无功也。
Lines.L4: 左次无咎，未失常也。
Lines.L5: 長子帥師，以中行也。弟子輿尸，使不當也。
Lines.L6: 大君有命，以正功也。小人勿用，必亂邦也。

Scripture.Hexagram: 师：贞，丈人，吉无咎。

Lines.L1: 初六：师出以律，否臧凶。
Lines.L2: 九二：在师中吉，无咎，王三锡命。
Lines.L3: 六三：师或舆尸，凶。
Lines.L4: 六四：师左次，无咎。
Lines.L5: 六五：田有禽，利执言，无咎。长子帅师，弟子舆尸，贞凶。
Lines.L6: 上六：大君有命，开国承家，小人勿用。

Exegesis.Judgment: 师，众也，贞正也，能以众正，可以王矣。刚中而应，行险而顺，以此毒天下，而民从之，吉又何咎矣。

Imagery.Hexagram: 地中有水，师；君子以容民畜众。

Lines.L1: 师出以律，失律凶也。
Lines.L2: 在师中吉，承天宠也。王三锡命，怀万邦也。
Lines.L3: 师或舆尸，大无功也。
Lines.L4: 左次无咎，未失常也。
Lines.L5: 长子帅师，以中行也。弟子舆尸，使不当也。
Lines.L6: 大君有命，以正功也。小人勿用，必乱邦也。

Scripture.Hexagram:
THE ARMY. The army needs perseverance
And a strong man.
Good fortune without blame.

Lines.L1:
Six at the beginning means:
An army must set forth in proper order.
If the order is not good, misfortune threatens.
Lines.L2:
Nine in the second place means:
In the midst of the army.
Good fortune. No blame.
The king bestows a triple decoration.
Lines.L3:
Six in the third place means:
Perchance the army carries corpses in the wagon.
Misfortune.
Lines.L4:
Six in the fourth place means:
The army retreats. No blame.
Lines.L5:
Six in the fifth place means:
There is game in the field.
It furthers one to catch it.
Without blame.
Let the eldest lead the army.
The younger transports corpses;
Then perseverance brings misfortune.
Lines.L6:
Six at the top means:
The great prince issues commands,
Founds states, vests families with fiefs.
Inferior people should not be employed.

Exegesis.Judgment:
THE ARMY means the masses. Perseverance means discipline.
The man who can effect discipline through the masses may attain mastery of the world.
The strong one is central and finds response.
One does a dangerous thing but finds devotion.
The man who thus leads the world is followed by the people.
Good fortune. How could this be a mistake?

Imagery.Hexagram:
In the middle of the earth is water:
The image of THE ARMY.
Thus the superior man increases his masses
By generosity toward the people.

Lines.L1:
Six at the beginning:
a) An army must set forth in proper order.
If the order is not good, misfortune threatens.
b) “An army must set forth in proper order.”2 Losing order is unfortunate.
Lines.L2:
Nine in the second place:
a) In the midst of the army.
Good fortune. No blame.
The king bestows a triple decoration.
b) “In the midst of the army. Good fortune.” He receives grace from heaven.
“The king bestows a triple decoration.” He has the welfare of all countries at heart.
Lines.L3:
Six in the third place:
a) Perchance the army carries corpses in the wagon.
Misfortune.
b) “Perchance the army carries corpses in the wagon.”
This is quite without merit.
Lines.L4:
Six in the fourth place:
a) The army retreats. No blame.
b) “The army retreats. No blame,” for it does not deviate from the usual way.
Lines.L5:
Six in the fifth place:
a) There is game in the field.
It furthers one to catch it.
Without blame.
Let the eldest lead the army.
The younger transports corpses;
Then perseverance brings misfortune.
b) “Let the eldest lead the army,” because he is central and correct.
“The younger transports corpses.” Thus the right man is not put in charge.
Lines.L6:
Six at the top:
a) The great prince issues commands,
Founds states, vests families with fiefs.
Inferior people should not be employed.
b) “The great prince issues commands,” in order to reward merit properly.
“Inferior people should not be employed,” because they are certain to cause confusion in the country.

Exegesis.Miscellaneous: THE ARMY means mourning.
Exegesis.Sequence: When there is conflict, the masses are sure to rise up. Hence there follows the hexagram of THE ARMY. Army means mass.

Scripture.Hexagram: Sze indicates how, in the case which it supposes, with firmness and correctness, and (a leader of) age and experience, there will be good fortune and no error.

Lines.L1: 1. The first SIX, divided, shows the host going forth according to the rules (for such a movement). If these be not good, there will be evil.
Lines.L2: 2. The second NINE, undivided, shows (the leader) in the midst of the host. There will be good fortune and no error. The king has thrice conveyed to him the orders (of his favour).
Lines.L3: 3. The third SIX, divided, shows how the host may, possibly, have many inefficient leaders. There will be evil.
Lines.L4: 4. The fourth SIX, divided, shows the host in retreat. There is no error.
Lines.L5: 5. The fifth SIX, divided, shows birds in the fields, which it will be advantageous to seize (and destroy). In that case there will be no error. If the oldest son leads the host, and younger men (idly occupy offices assigned to them), however firm and correct he may be, there will be evil.
Lines.L6: 6. The topmost SIX, divided, shows the great ruler delivering his charges, (appointing some) to be rulers of states, and others to undertake the headship of clans; but small men should not be employed (in such positions).

Exegesis.Judgment:
VII. 1. (The name) Sze describes the multitude (of the host). The 'firmness and correctness' (which the hexagram indicates) refer to (moral) correctness (of aim). When (the mover) is able to use the multitude with such correctness, he may attain to the royal sway.
2. There is (the symbol of) strength in the centre (of the trigram below), and it is responded to (by its proper correlate above). The action gives rise to perils, but is in accordance (with the best sentiments of men). (Its mover) may by such action distress all the country, but the people will follow him;--there will be good fortune, and what error should there be?

Imagery.Hexagram: VII. (The trigram representing) the earth and in the midst of it that representing water, form Sze. The superior man, in accordance with this, nourishes and educates the people, and collects (from among them) the multitudes (of the hosts).

Lines.L1: 1. 'The host goes forth according to the rules (for) such a movement:'--if those rules be not observed, there will be evil.
Lines.L2: 2. 'He is in the midst of the host, and there will be good fortune:'--he has received the favour of Heaven. 'The king has thrice conveyed to him the orders (of) his favour:'--(the king) cherishes the myriad regions in his heart.
Lines.L3: 3. 'The host with the possibility of its having many idle leaders:'--great will be its want of success.
Lines.L4: 4. 'The host is in retreat; but there is no error:'--there has been no failure in the regular course.
Lines.L5: 5. 'The oldest son leads the host:'--its movements are directed by him in accordance with his position in the centre. 'Younger men idly occupy their positions:'--the employment of such men is improper.
Lines.L6: 6. 'The great ruler delivers his charges:'--thereby he rightly apportions merit. 'Small men should not be employed:'--they are sure to throw the states into confusion.

Exegesis.Miscellaneous: 8, 7. Pî shows us joy, and Sze the anxious mind.
Exegesis.Sequence: 6-8. Sung is sure to cause the rising up of the multitudes; and hence it is followed by Sze. Sze has the signification of multitudes, and between multitudes there must be some bond of union. Hence it is followed by Pî, which denotes being attached to.

Scripture.Hexagram: 比：吉。原筮元永貞，无咎。不寧方來，後夫凶。

Lines.L1: 初六：有孚，比之，无咎。有孚盈缶，終來有它吉。
Lines.L2: 六二：比之自內，貞吉。
Lines.L3: 六三：比之匪人。
Lines.L4: 六四：外比之，貞吉。
Lines.L5: 九五：顯比，王用三驅，失前禽。邑人不誡，吉。
Lines.L6: 上六：比之无首，凶。

Exegesis.Judgment: 比，吉也，比，輔也，下順從也。原筮元永貞，无咎，以剛中也。不寧方來，上下應也。後夫凶，其道窮也。

Imagery.Hexagram: 地上有水，比；先王以建萬國，親諸侯。

Lines.L1: 比之初六，有他吉也。
Lines.L2: 比之自內，不自失也。
Lines.L3: 比之匪人，不亦傷乎！
Lines.L4: 外比於賢，以從上也。
Lines.L5: 顯比之吉，位正中也。舍逆取順，失前禽也。邑人不誡，上使中也。
Lines.L6: 比之无首，无所終也。

Scripture.Hexagram: 比：吉。原筮元永贞，无咎。不宁方来，后夫凶。

Lines.L1: 初六：有孚，比之，无咎。有孚盈缶，终来有它吉。
Lines.L2: 六二：比之自内，贞吉。
Lines.L3: 六三：比之匪人。
Lines.L4: 六四：外比之，贞吉。
Lines.L5: 九五：显比，王用三驱，失前禽。邑人不诫，吉。
Lines.L6: 上六：比之无首，凶。

Exegesis.Judgment: 比，吉也，比，辅也，下顺从也。原筮元永贞，无咎，以刚中也。不宁方来，上下应也。后夫凶，其道穷也。

Imagery.Hexagram: 地上有水，比；先王以建万国，亲诸侯。

Lines.L1: 比之初六，有他吉也。
Lines.L2: 比之自内，不自失也。
Lines.L3: 比之匪人，不亦伤乎！
Lines.L4: 外比于贤，以从上也。
Lines.L5: 显比之吉，位正中也。舍逆取顺，失前禽也。邑人不诫，上使中也。
Lines.L6: 比之无首，无所终也。

Scripture.Hexagram:
HOLDING TOGETHER brings good fortune.
Inquire of the oracle once again
Whether you possess sublimity, constancy, and perseverance;
Then there is no blame.
Those who are uncertain gradually join.
Whoever comes too late
Meets with misfortune.

Lines.L1:
Six at the beginning means:
Hold to him in truth and loyalty;
This is without blame.
Truth, like a full earthen bowl:
Thus in the end
Good fortune comes from without.
Lines.L2:
Six in the second place means:
Hold to him inwardly.
Perseverance brings good fortune.
Lines.L3:
Six in the third place means:
You hold together with the wrong people.
Lines.L4:
Six in the fourth place means:
Hold to him outwardly also.
Perseverance brings good fortune.
Lines.L5:
Nine in the fifth place means:
Manifestation of holding together.
In the hunt the king uses beaters on three sides only
And foregoes game that runs off in front.
The citizens need no warning.
Good fortune.
Lines.L6:
Six at the top means:
He finds no head for holding together.
Misfortune.

Exegesis.Judgment:
“HOLDING TOGETHER brings good fortune.” Holding together means mutual help. Those below are devoted and obedient.
“Inquire of the oracle once again whether you possess sublimity, constancy, and perseverance. Then there is no blame,” because of the firmness and central position.
“Those who are uncertain gradually join.” Above and below are in correspondence.
“Whoever comes too late meets with misfortune.”
His way is at an end.

Imagery.Hexagram:
On the earth is water:
The image of HOLDING TOGETHER.
Thus the kings of antiquity
Bestowed the different states as fiefs
And cultivated friendly relations
With the feudal lords.

Lines.L1:
Six at the beginning:
a) Hold to him in truth and loyalty;
This is without blame.
Truth, like a full earthen bowl:
Thus in the end
Good fortune comes from without.
b) The six at the beginning of HOLDING TOGETHER encounters good fortune from another quarter.
Lines.L2:
Six in the second place:
a) Hold to him inwardly.
Perseverance brings good fortune.
b) “Hold to him inwardly.” Do not lose yourself.
Lines.L3:
Six in the third place:
a) You hold together with the wrong people.
b) “You hold together with the wrong people.” Is this not injurious?
Lines.L4:
Six in the fourth place:
a) Hold to him outwardly also.
Perseverance brings good fortune.
b) Hold outwardly also to people of worth, in order thus to follow the one above.
Lines.L5:
Nine in the fifth place:
a) Manifestation of holding together.
In the hunt the king uses beaters on three sides only
And foregoes game that runs off in front.
The citizens need no warning.
Good fortune.
b) The good fortune resulting from “manifestation of holding together” inheres in the fact that the position is correct and central.
Discarding those who resist, accepting the devoted: this is the meaning of “foregoes game that runs off in front.”
“The citizens need no warning,” for the one above makes them central.
Lines.L6:
Six at the top:
a) He finds no head for holding together.
Misfortune.
b) “He finds no head for holding together.” Therefore he also fails to find the right end.

Exegesis.Miscellaneous: HOLDING TOGETHER is something joyous.
Exegesis.Sequence: Among the masses there is surely a reason for uniting. Hence there follows the hexagram of HOLDING TOGETHER. Holding together means uniting.

Scripture.Hexagram: Pî indicates that (under the conditions which it supposes) there is good fortune. But let (the principal party intended in it) re-examine himself, (as if) by divination, whether his virtue be great, unintermitting, and firm. If it be so, there will be no error. Those who have not rest will then come to him; and with those who are (too) late in coming it will be ill.

Lines.L1: 1. The first SIX, divided, shows its subject seeking by his sincerity to win the attachment of his object. There will be no error. Let (the breast) be full of sincerity as an earthenware vessel is of its contents, and it will in the end bring other advantages.
Lines.L2: 2. In the second SIX, divided, we see the movement towards union and attachment proceeding from the inward (mind). With firm correctness there will be good fortune.
Lines.L3: 3. In the third SIX, divided, we see its subject seeking for union with such as ought not to be associated with.
Lines.L4: 4. In the fourth SIX, divided, we see its subject seeking for union with the one beyond himself. With firm correctness there will be good fortune.
Lines.L5: 5. The fifth NINE, undivided, affords the most illustrious instance of seeking union and attachment. (We seem to see in it) the king urging his pursuit of the game (only) in three directions, and allowing the escape of all the animals before him, while the people of his towns do not warn one another (to prevent it). There will be good fortune.
Lines.L6: 6. In the topmost SIX, divided, we see one seeking union and attachment without having taken the first step (to such an end). There will be evil.

Exegesis.Judgment:
VIII. 1. 'Pî indicates that there is good fortune:'--(the name) Pî denotes help; (and we see in the figure) inferiors docilely following (their superior).
2. 'Let (the principal party intended in it) reexamine himself, (as if) by divination, whether his virtue be great, unintermitting, and firm;--if it be so, there will be no error:--all this follows from the position of the strong line in the centre (of the upper trigram). 'Those who have not rest will come to him:'--high and low will respond to its subject. 'With those who are (too) late in coming it will be ill:'--(for them) the way (of good fortune here indicated) has been exhausted.

Imagery.Hexagram: VIII. (The trigram representing) the earth, and over it (that representing) water, form Pî. The ancient kings, in accordance with this, established the various states and maintained an affectionate relation to their princes.

Lines.L1: 1. From 'the seeking union with its object' shown in the first SIX, (divided),there will be other advantages.
Lines.L2: 2. 'The movement towards union and attachment proceeds from the inward (mind):'--(the party concerned) does not fail in what is proper to himself
Lines.L3: 3. 'Union is sought with such as ought not to be associated with:'--but will not injury be the result?
Lines.L4: 4. 'Union is sought (by the party intended here) with one beyond himself, and (in this case) with a worthy object:'--he is following (the ruler) above him.
Lines.L5: 5. 'The good fortune belonging to the most illustrious instance of seeking union and attachment' appears in the correct and central position (of the fifth line, undivided).(The king's) neglecting (the animals) confronting him (and then fleeing), and (only) taking those who present themselves as it were obediently, is seen in[paragraph continues] 'his allowing the escape of those in front of him.' 'That the people of his towns do not warn one another (to prevent such escape),' shows how he, in his high eminence, has made them pursue the due course.
Lines.L6: 6. 'He seeks union and attachment without taking the first (step to such an end):'--there is no possibility of a (good) issue.

Exegesis.Miscellaneous: 8, 7. Pî shows us joy, and Sze the anxious mind.
Exegesis.Sequence:
6-8. Sung is sure to cause the rising up of the multitudes; and hence it is followed by Sze. Sze has the signification of multitudes, and between multitudes there must be some bond of union. Hence it is followed by Pî, which denotes being attached to.
8-11. (Multitudes in) union must be subjected to some restraint. Hence Pî is followed by Hsiâo Khû. When things axe subjected to restraint, there come to be rites of ceremony, and hence Hsiâo Khû is followed by Lî. The treading (on what is proper) leads to Thâi, which issues in a state of freedom and repose, and hence Lî is followed by Thâi.

English.WilhelmBaynes: Hsiao Ch’u / The Taming Power of the Small

Scripture.Hexagram: 小畜：亨。密雲不雨，自我西郊。

Lines.L1: 初九：復自道，何其咎，吉。
Lines.L2: 九二：牽復，吉。
Lines.L3: 九三：輿說輻，夫妻反目。
Lines.L4: 六四：有孚，血去惕出，无咎。
Lines.L5: 九五：有孚攣如，富以其鄰。
Lines.L6: 上九：既雨既處，尚德載，婦貞厲。月幾望，君子征凶。

Exegesis.Judgment: 小畜，柔得位，而上下應之，曰小畜。健而巽，剛中而志行，乃亨。密雲不雨，尚往也。自我西郊，施未行也。

Imagery.Hexagram: 風行天上，小畜；君子以懿文德。

Lines.L1: 復自道，其義吉也。
Lines.L2: 牽復在中，亦不自失也。
Lines.L3: 夫妻反目，不能正室也。
Lines.L4: 有孚惕出，上合志也。
Lines.L5: 有孚攣如，不獨富也。
Lines.L6: 既雨既處，德積載也。君子征凶，有所疑也。

Scripture.Hexagram: 小畜：亨。密云不雨，自我西郊。

Lines.L1: 初九：复自道，何其咎，吉。
Lines.L2: 九二：牵复，吉。
Lines.L3: 九三：舆说辐，夫妻反目。
Lines.L4: 六四：有孚，血去惕出，无咎。
Lines.L5: 九五：有孚挛如，富以其邻。
Lines.L6: 上九：既雨既处，尚德载，妇贞厉。月几望，君子征凶。

Exegesis.Judgment: 小畜，柔得位，而上下应之，曰小畜。健而巽，刚中而志行，乃亨。密云不雨，尚往也。自我西郊，施未行也。

Imagery.Hexagram: 风行天上，小畜；君子以懿文德。

Lines.L1: 复自道，其义吉也。
Lines.L2: 牵复在中，亦不自失也。
Lines.L3: 夫妻反目，不能正室也。
Lines.L4: 有孚惕出，上合志也。
Lines.L5: 有孚挛如，不独富也。
Lines.L6: 既雨既处，德积载也。君子征凶，有所疑也。

Scripture.Hexagram:
THE TAMING POWER OF THE SMALL
Has success.
Dense clouds, no rain from our western region.

Lines.L1:
Nine at the beginning means:
Return to the way.
How could there be blame in this?
Good fortune.
Lines.L2:
Nine in the second place means:
He allows himself to be drawn into returning.
Good fortune.
Lines.L3:
Nine in the third place means:
The spokes burst out of the wagon wheels.
Man and wife roll their eyes.
Lines.L4:
Six in the fourth place means:
If you are sincere, blood vanishes and fear gives way.
No blame.
Lines.L5:
Nine in the fifth place means:
If you are sincere and loyally attached,
You are rich in your neighbor.
Lines.L6:
Nine at the top means:
The rain comes, there is rest.
This is due to the lasting effect of character.
Perseverance brings the woman into danger.
The moon is nearly full.
If the superior man persists,
Misfortune comes.

Exegesis.Judgment:
THE TAMING POWER OF THE SMALL. The yielding obtains the decisive place, and those above and those below correspond with it: this is called THE TAMING POWER OF THE SMALL.
Strong and gentle: the strong is central and its will is done, therefore “success.”
“Dense clouds, no rain”: the movement goes still further.
“From our western region”: the influence has not yet set in.

Imagery.Hexagram:
The wind drives across heaven:
The image of THE TAMING POWER OF THE SMALL.
Thus the superior man
Refines the outward aspect of his nature.

Lines.L1:
Nine at the beginning:
a) Return to the way.
How could there be blame in this?
Good fortune.
b) “Return to the way.” This is something that bodes well.
Lines.L2:
Nine in the second place:
a) He allows himself to be drawn into returning.
Good fortune.
b) Being drawn into returning derives from the central position. Also, he does not lose himself.
Lines.L3:
Nine in the third place:
a) The spokes burst out of the wagon wheels.
Man and wife roll their eyes.
b) When “man and wife roll their eyes,” it is a sign that they cannot keep their house in order.
Lines.L4:
Six in the fourth place:
a) If you are sincere, blood vanishes and fear gives way.
No blame.
b) “If you are sincere … fear gives way,” because the one at the top agrees in attitude.
Lines.L5:
Nine in the fifth place:
a) If you are sincere and loyally attached,
You are rich in your neighbor.
b) “If you are sincere and loyally attached,” you will not be alone in your riches.
Lines.L6:
Nine at the top:
a) The rain comes, there is rest.
This is due to the lasting effect of character.
Perseverance brings the woman into danger.
The moon is nearly full.
If the superior man persists,
Misfortune comes.
b) “The rain comes, there is rest.” This is the continuously cumulative effect of character.
“If the superior man persists, misfortune comes,” for there might be doubts.

Exegesis.Miscellaneous: THE TAMING POWER OF THE SMALL is slight.
Exegesis.Sequence: Through holding together, restraint is certain to come about. Hence there follows THE TAMING POWER OF THE SMALL.

Scripture.Hexagram: Hsiâo Khû indicates that (under its conditions) there will be progress and success. (We see) dense clouds, but no rain coming from our borders in the west.

Lines.L1: 1. The first NINE, undivided, shows its subject returning and pursuing his own course. What mistake should he fall into? There will be good fortune.
Lines.L2: 2. The second NINE, undivided, shows its subject, by the attraction (of the former line), returning (to the proper course). There will be good fortune.
Lines.L3: 3. The third NINE, undivided, suggests the idea of a carriage, the strap beneath which has been removed, or of a husband and wife looking on each other with averted eyes.
Lines.L4: 4. The fourth SIX, divided, shows its subject possessed of sincerity. The danger of bloodshed is thereby averted, and his (ground for) apprehension dismissed. There will be no mistake.
Lines.L5: 5. The fifth NINE, undivided, shows its subject possessed of sincerity, and drawing others to unite with him. Rich in resources, he employs his neighbours (in the same cause with himself).
Lines.L6: 6. The topmost NINE, undivided, shows how the rain has fallen, and the (onward progress) is stayed;—(so) must we value the full accumulation of the virtue (represented by the upper trigram). But a wife (exercising restraint), however firm and correct she may be, is in a position of peril, (and like) the moon approaching to the full. If the superior man prosecute his measures (in such circumstances), there will be evil.

Exegesis.Judgment:
IX. 1. In Hsiâo Khû the weak line occupies its (proper) position, and (the lines) above and below respond to it. Hence comes the name of Hsiâo Khû (Small Restraint).
2. (It presents the symbols of) strength and flexibility. Strong lines are in the central places, and the will (of their subjects) will have free course. Thus it indicates that there will be progress and success.
3. 'Dense clouds but no rain' indicate the movement (of the strong lines) still going forward. The'Commencing at our western border' indicates that the (beneficial) influence has not yet been widely displayed.

Imagery.Hexagram: IX. (The trigram representing) the sky, and that representing wind moving above it, form Hsiâo Khû The superior man, in accordance with this, adorns the outward manifestation of his virtue.

Lines.L1: 1. 'He returns and pursues his own path:'--it is right that there should be good fortune.
Lines.L2: 2. 'By the attraction (of the subject of the former line) he returns (to its own course),' and is in the central place:--neither will he err in what is due from him.
Lines.L3: 3. 'Husband and wife look on each other with averted eyes:'--(the subject of line three is like ahusband who) cannot maintain correctly his relations with his wife.
Lines.L4: 4. 'He is possessed of sincerity; his (ground for) apprehension is dismissed:'--(the subjects of the lines) above agree in aim with him.
Lines.L5: 5. 'He is possessed of sincerity, and draws others to unite with him:'--he does not use only his own rich resources.
Lines.L6: 6. 'The rain has fallen and (the onward progress) is stayed:'--the power (denoted in the figure) has accumulated to the full. 'If the superior man prosecute his measures, there will be evil:'--he will find himself obstructed.

Exegesis.Sequence: 8-11. (Multitudes in) union must be subjected to some restraint. Hence Pî is followed by Hsiâo Khû. When things axe subjected to restraint, there come to be rites of ceremony, and hence Hsiâo Khû is followed by Lî. The treading (on what is proper) leads to Thâi, which issues in a state of freedom and repose, and hence Lî is followed by Thâi.

Scripture.Hexagram: 履虎尾，不咥人，亨。

Lines.L1: 初九：素履，往无咎。
Lines.L2: 九二：履道坦坦，幽人貞吉。
Lines.L3: 六三：眇能視，跛能履，履虎尾，咥人，凶。武人為于大君。
Lines.L4: 九四：履虎尾，愬愬，終吉。
Lines.L5: 九五：夬履，貞厲。
Lines.L6: 上九：視履考祥，其旋元吉。

Exegesis.Judgment: 履，柔履剛也。說而應乎乾，是以履虎尾，不咥人，亨。剛中正，履帝位而不疚，光明也。

Imagery.Hexagram: 上天下澤，履；君子以辨上下，安民志。

Lines.L1: 素履之往，獨行愿也。
Lines.L2: 幽人貞吉，中不自亂也。
Lines.L3: 眇能視；不足以有明也。跛能履；不足以與行也，咥人之凶；位不當也。武人為于大君；志剛也。
Lines.L4: 愬愬終吉，志行也。
Lines.L5: 夬履貞厲，位正當也。
Lines.L6: 元吉在上，大有慶也。

Scripture.Hexagram: 履虎尾，不咥人，亨。

Lines.L1: 初九：素履，往无咎。
Lines.L2: 九二：履道坦坦，幽人贞吉。
Lines.L3: 六三：眇能视，跛能履，履虎尾，咥人，凶。武人为于大君。
Lines.L4: 九四：履虎尾，诉诉，终吉。
Lines.L5: 九五：夬履，贞厉。
Lines.L6: 上九：视履考祥，其旋元吉。

Exegesis.Judgment: 履，柔履刚也。说而应乎乾，是以履虎尾，不咥人，亨。刚中正，履帝位而不疚，光明也。

Imagery.Hexagram: 上天下泽，履；君子以辨上下，安民志。

Lines.L1: 素履之往，独行愿也。
Lines.L2: 幽人贞吉，中不自乱也。
Lines.L3: 眇能视；不足以有明也。跛能履；不足以与行也，咥人之凶；位不当也。武人为于大君；志刚也。
Lines.L4: 诉诉终吉，志行也。
Lines.L5: 夬履贞厉，位正当也。
Lines.L6: 元吉在上，大有庆也。

Scripture.Hexagram:
TREADING. Treading upon the tail of the tiger.
It does not bite the man. Success.

Lines.L1:
Nine at the beginning means:
Simple conduct. Progress without blame.
Lines.L2:
Nine in the second place means:
Treading a smooth, level course.
The perseverance of a dark man
Brings good fortune.
Lines.L3:
Six in the third place means:
A one-eyed man is able to see,
A lame man is able to tread.
He treads on the tail of the tiger.
The tiger bites the man.
Misfortune.
Thus does a warrior act on behalf of his great prince.
Lines.L4:
Nine in the fourth place means:
He treads on the tail of the tiger.
Caution and circumspection
Lead ultimately to good fortune.
Lines.L5:
Nine in the fifth place means:
Resolute conduct.
Perseverance with awareness of danger.
Lines.L6:
Nine at the top means:
Look to your conduct and weigh the favorable signs.
When everything is fulfilled, supreme good fortune comes.

Exegesis.Judgment:
TREADING: the yielding treads upon the firm. Joyous, and in the relationship of correspondence to the Creative; hence, “Treading upon the tail of the tiger. It does not bite the man. Success.”
Strong, central, and correct, he treads into the place of the ruler and remains without blame: his light shines bright.

Imagery.Hexagram:
Heaven above, the lake below:
The image of TREADING.
Thus the superior man discriminates between high and low,
And thereby fortifies the thinking of the people.

Lines.L1:
Nine at the beginning:
a) Simple conduct. Progress without blame.
b) The progress of simple conduct follows in solitude its own bent.
Lines.L2:
Nine in the second place:
a) Treading a smooth, level course.
The perseverance of a dark man
Brings good fortune.
b) “The perseverance of a dark man brings good fortune.” He is central and does not get confused.
Lines.L3:
Six in the third place:
a) A one-eyed man is able to see,
A lame man is able to tread.
He treads on the tail of the tiger.
The tiger bites the man.
Misfortune.
Thus does a warrior act on behalf of his great prince.
b) “A one-eyed man is able to see,” but not enough for clarity.
“A lame man is able to tread,” but not enough to tread with others.
The misfortune in the biting of the man is due to the fact that the place is not appropriate.
“Thus does a warrior act on behalf of his great prince,” because his will is firm.
Lines.L4:
Nine in the fourth place:
a) He treads on the tail of the tiger.
Caution and circumspection
Lead ultimately to good fortune.
b) “Caution and circumspection lead ultimately to good fortune,” because what is willed is done.
Lines.L5:
Nine in the fifth place:
a) Resolute conduct.
Perseverance with awareness of danger.
b) “Resolute conduct. Perseverance with awareness of danger.” The place is correct and appropriate.
Lines.L6:
Nine at the top:
a) Look to your conduct and weigh the favorable signs.
When everything is fulfilled, supreme good fortune comes.
b) “Supreme good fortune” in the topmost place carries great blessing.

Exegesis.Miscellaneous: That which treads does not stay.
Exegesis.Sequence: When beings are subjected to restraint the mores arise; hence there follows the hexagram of CONDUCT.
Exegesis.Extracts: TREADING shows the basis of character. It is harmonious and attains its goal. It brings about harmonious conduct.

Scripture.Hexagram: (Lî suggests the idea of) one treading on the tail of a tiger, which does not bite him. There will be progress and success.

Lines.L1: 1. The first NINE, undivided, shows its subject treading his accustomed path. If he go forward, there will be no error.
Lines.L2: 2. The second NINE, undivided, shows its subject treading the path that is level and easy;—a quiet and solitary man, to whom, if he be firm and correct, there will be good fortune.
Lines.L3: 3. The third SIX, divided, shows a one-eyed man (who thinks he) can see; a lame man (who thinks he) can walk well; one who treads on the tail of a tiger and is bitten. (All this indicates) ill fortune. We have a (mere) bravo acting the part of a great ruler.
Lines.L4: 4. The fourth NINE, undivided, shows its subject treading on the tail of a tiger. He becomes full of apprehensive caution, and in the end there will be good fortune.
Lines.L5: 5. The fifth NINE, undivided, shows the resolute tread of its subject. Though he be firm and correct, there will be peril.
Lines.L6: 6. The sixth NINE, undivided, tells us to look at (the whole course) that is trodden, and examine the presage which that gives. If it be complete and without failure, there will be great good fortune.

Exegesis.Judgment:
X. 1. In Lî we have (the symbol of) weakness treading on (that of) strength.
