2. (The lower trigram) indicates pleasure and satisfaction, and responds to (the upper) indicating strength. Hence (it is said), 'He treads on the tail of a tiger, which does not bite him; there will be progress and success.'
3. (The fifth line is) strong, in the centre, and inits correct place. (Its subject) occupies the God-(given) position, and falls into no distress or failure;--(his) action will be brilliant.

Imagery.Hexagram: X. (The trigram representing) the sky above, and below it (that representing the waters of) a marsh, form Lî. The superior man, in accordance with this, discriminates between high and low, and gives settlement to the aims of the people.

Lines.L1: 1. 'He treads his accustomed path and goes forward:'--singly and exclusively he carries out his (long-cherished) wishes.
Lines.L2: 2. 'A quiet and solitary man, to whom, being firm and correct, there will be good fortune:'--holding the due mean, he will not allow himself to be thrown into disorder.
Lines.L3: 3. 'A one-eyed man (who thinks that he) can see:'--he is not fit to see clearly. 'A lame man (who thinks that he can) tread well:'--one cannot walk along with him. 'The ill fortune of being bitten' arises from the place not being the proper one for him. 'A (mere) bravo acting the part of a great ruler:'--this is owing to his aims being (too) violent.
Lines.L4: 4. 'He becomes full of apprehensive caution, and in the end there will be good fortune:'--his aim takes effect.
Lines.L5: 5. 'He treads resolutely; and though he be firm and correct, there is peril:'--this is due to his being in the position that is correct and appropriate to him.
Lines.L6: 6. 'There will be great good fortune,' and that in the occupancy of the topmost line:--this is great matter for congratulation.

Exegesis.Sequence: 8-11. (Multitudes in) union must be subjected to some restraint. Hence Pî is followed by Hsiâo Khû. When things axe subjected to restraint, there come to be rites of ceremony, and hence Hsiâo Khû is followed by Lî. The treading (on what is proper) leads to Thâi, which issues in a state of freedom and repose, and hence Lî is followed by Thâi.

Scripture.Hexagram: 泰：小往大來，吉亨。

Lines.L1: 初九：拔茅茹，以其彙，征吉。
Lines.L2: 九二：包荒，用馮河，不遐遺，朋亡，得尚于中行。
Lines.L3: 九三：无平不陂，无往不復，艱貞无咎。勿恤其孚，于食有福。
Lines.L4: 六四：翩翩，不富，以其鄰，不戒以孚。
Lines.L5: 六五：帝乙歸妹，以祉元吉。
Lines.L6: 上六：城復于隍，勿用師。自邑告命，貞吝。

Exegesis.Judgment: 泰，小往大來，吉亨。則是天地交，而萬物通也；上下交，而其志同也。內陽而外陰，內健而外順，內君子而外小人，君子道長，小人道消也。

Imagery.Hexagram: 天地交泰，后以財成天地之道，輔相天地之宜，以左右民。

Lines.L1: 拔茅征吉，志在外也。
Lines.L2: 包荒，得尚于中行，以光大也。
Lines.L3: 无往不復，天地際也。
Lines.L4: 翩翩不富，皆失實也。不戒以孚，中心願也。
Lines.L5: 以祉元吉，中以行愿也。
Lines.L6: 城復于隍，其命亂也。

Scripture.Hexagram: 泰：小往大来，吉亨。

Lines.L1: 初九：拔茅茹，以其汇，征吉。
Lines.L2: 九二：包荒，用冯河，不遐遗，朋亡，得尚于中行。
Lines.L3: 九三：无平不陂，无往不复，艰贞无咎。勿恤其孚，于食有福。
Lines.L4: 六四：翩翩，不富，以其邻，不戒以孚。
Lines.L5: 六五：帝乙归妹，以祉元吉。
Lines.L6: 上六：城复于隍，勿用师。自邑告命，贞吝。

Exegesis.Judgment: 泰，小往大来，吉亨。则是天地交，而万物通也；上下交，而其志同也。内阳而外阴，内健而外顺，内君子而外小人，君子道长，小人道消也。

Imagery.Hexagram: 天地交泰，后以财成天地之道，辅相天地之宜，以左右民。

Lines.L1: 拔茅征吉，志在外也。
Lines.L2: 包荒，得尚于中行，以光大也。
Lines.L3: 无往不复，天地际也。
Lines.L4: 翩翩不富，皆失实也。不戒以孚，中心愿也。
Lines.L5: 以祉元吉，中以行愿也。
Lines.L6: 城复于隍，其命乱也。

Scripture.Hexagram:
PEACE. The small departs,
The great approaches.
Good fortune. Success.

Lines.L1:
Nine at the beginning means:
When ribbon grass is pulled up, the sod comes with it.
Each according to his kind.
Undertakings bring good fortune.
Lines.L2:
Nine in the second place means:
Bearing with the uncultured in gentleness,
Fording the river with resolution,
Not neglecting what is distant,
Not regarding one’s companions:
Thus one may manage to walk in the middle.
Lines.L3:
Nine in the third place means:
No plain not followed by a slope.
No going not followed by a return.
He who remains persevering in danger
Is without blame.
Do not complain about this truth;
Enjoy the good fortune you still possess.
Lines.L4:
Six in the fourth place means:
He flutters down, not boasting of his wealth,
Together with his neighbor,
Guileless and sincere.
Lines.L5:
Six in the fifth place means:
The sovereign I
Gives his daughter in marriage.
This brings blessing
And supreme good fortune.
Lines.L6:
Six at the top means:
The wall falls back into the moat.
Use no army now.
Make your commands known within your own town.
Perseverance brings humiliation.

Exegesis.Judgment:
PEACE. “The small departs, the great approaches. Good fortune. Success.”
In this way heaven and earth unite, and all beings come into union.
Upper and lower unite, and they are of one will.
The light principle is within, the shadowy without; strength is within and devotion without; the superior man is within, the inferior without.
The way of the superior man is waxing; the way of the inferior man is waning.

Imagery.Hexagram:
Heaven and earth unite: the image of PEACE.
Thus the ruler
Divides and completes the course of heaven and earth;
He furthers and regulates the gifts of heaven and earth,
And so aids the people.

Lines.L1:
Nine at the beginning:
a) When ribbon grass is pulled up, the sod comes with it.
Each according to his kind.
Perseverance brings good fortune and success.
b) “When ribbon grass is pulled up…. Undertakings bring good fortune.” The will is directed outward.
Lines.L2:
Nine in the second place:
a) Bearing with the uncultured in gentleness,
Fording the river with resolution,
Not neglecting what is distant,
Not regarding one’s companions:
Thus one may manage to walk in the middle.
b) “Bearing with the uncultured in gentleness … thus one may manage to walk in the middle,” because the light is great.
Lines.L3:
Nine in the third place:
a) No plain not followed by a slope.
No going not followed by a return.
He who remains persevering in danger
Is without blame.
Do not complain about this truth;
Enjoy the good fortune you still possess.
b) “No going not followed by a return”: this is the boundary of heaven and earth.
Lines.L4:
Six in the fourth place:
a) He flutters down, not boasting of his wealth,
Together with his neighbor,
Guileless and sincere.
b) “He flutters down, not boasting of his wealth”: all of them have lost what is real.
“Guileless and sincere”: he desires it in the depths of his heart.
Lines.L5:
Six in the fifth place:
a) The sovereign I
Gives his daughter in marriage.
This brings blessing
And supreme good fortune.
b) “This brings blessing and supreme good fortune,” because he is central in carrying out what he desires.
Lines.L6:
Six at the top:
a) The wall falls back into the moat.
Use no army now.
Make your commands known within your own town.
Perseverance brings humiliation.
b) “The wall falls back into the moat.” His plans fall into confusion.

Exegesis.Miscellaneous: The hexagrams of STANDSTILL and PEACE stand in natural opposition to each other.
Exegesis.Sequence: Good conduct, then contentment; thus calm prevails. Hence there follows the hexagram of PEACE. Peace means union, interrelation.

Scripture.Hexagram: In Thâi (we see) the little gone and the great come. (It indicates that) there will be good fortune, with progress and success.

Lines.L1: 1. The first NINE, undivided, suggests the idea of grass pulled up, and bringing with it other stalks with whose roots it is connected. Advance (on the part of its subject) will be fortunate.
Lines.L2: 2. The second NINE, undivided, shows one who can bear with the uncultivated, will cross the Ho without a boat, does not forget the distant, and has no (selfish) friendships. Thus does he prove himself acting in accordance with the course of the due Mean.
Lines.L3: 3. The third NINE, undivided, shows that, while there is no state of peace that is not liable to be disturbed, and no departure (of evil men) so that they shall not return, yet when one is firm and correct, as he realises the distresses that may arise, he will commit no error. There is no occasion for sadness at the certainty (of such recurring changes); and in this mood the happiness (of the present) may be (long) enjoyed.
Lines.L4: 4. The fourth SIX, divided, shows its subject fluttering (down);—not relying on his own rich resources, but calling in his neighbours. (They all come) not as having received warning, but in the sincerity (of their hearts).
Lines.L5: 5. The fifth SIX, divided, reminds us of (king) Tî-yî's (rule about the) marriage of his younger sister. By such a course there is happiness and there will be great good fortune.
Lines.L6: 6. The sixth six, divided, shows us the city wall returned into the moat. It is not the time to use the army. (The subject of the line) may, indeed, announce his orders to the people of his own city; but however correct and firm he may be, he will have cause for regret.

Exegesis.Judgment: XI. 'The little come and the great gone in Thâi, and its indication that there will be good fortune with progress and success' show to us heaven and earth in communication with each other, and all things in consequence having free course, and (also) the high and the low, (superiors and inferiors), in communication with one another, and possessed by the same aim. The inner (trigram) is made up of the strong and undivided lines, and the outer of the weak and divided; the inner is (the symbol of) strength, and the outer of docility; the inner (represents) the superior man, and the outer the small man. (Thus) the way ofthe superior man appears increasing, and that of the small man decreasing.

Imagery.Hexagram: XI. (The trigrams for) heaven and earth in communication together form Thâi. The (sage) sovereign, in harmony with this, fashions and completes (his regulations) after the courses of heaven and earth, and assists the application of the adaptations furnished by them,--in order to benefit the people.

Lines.L1: 1. 'The good fortune of advance, (as suggested by the emblem of) the grass pulled up,' arises from the will (of the party intended) being set on what is external to himself.
Lines.L2: 2. 'He bears with the uncultivated, and proves himself acting in accordance with the due mean:'--for (his intelligence is) bright and (his capacity is) great.
Lines.L3: 3. 'There is no going away so that there shall not be a return' refers to this as the point where the interaction of heaven and earth takes place.
Lines.L4: 4. 'He comes fluttering (down), not relying onhis own rich resources:'--both he and his neighbours are out of their real (place where they are). 'They have not received warning, but (come) in the sincerity (of their hearts):'--this is what they have desired in the core of their hearts.
Lines.L5: 5. 'By such a course there is happiness, and there will be great good fortune:'--(the subject of the line) employs the virtue proper to his central position to carry his wishes into effect.
Lines.L6: 6. 'The city wall returned back into the moat' shows how the (governmental) orders have (long) been in disorder.

Exegesis.Miscellaneous: 12, 11. While Phî and Thâi their different scopes prefer,
Exegesis.Sequence:
8-11. (Multitudes in) union must be subjected to some restraint. Hence Pî is followed by Hsiâo Khû. When things axe subjected to restraint, there come to be rites of ceremony, and hence Hsiâo Khû is followed by Lî. The treading (on what is proper) leads to Thâi, which issues in a state of freedom and repose, and hence Lî is followed by Thâi.
11-16. Thâi denotes things having free course. They cannot have that for ever, and hence it is followed by Phî (denoting being shut up and restricted). Things cannot for ever be shut up, and hence Phî is followed by Thung Žân. To him who cultivates union with men, things must come to belong, and hence Thung Žân. is followed by Tâ Yû. Those who, have what is great should not allow in themselves the feeling of being full, and hence Tâ Yû is followed by Khien. When great possessions are associated with humility, there is sure to be pleasure and satisfaction; and hence Khien is followed by Yü.

Scripture.Hexagram: 否之匪人，不利君子貞，大往小來。

Lines.L1: 初六：拔茅茹，以其彙，貞吉亨。
Lines.L2: 六二：包承。小人吉，大人否，亨。
Lines.L3: 六三：包羞。
Lines.L4: 九四：有命，无咎，疇離祉。
Lines.L5: 九五：休否，大人吉。其亡其亡，繫于苞桑。
Lines.L6: 上九：傾否，先否後喜。

Exegesis.Judgment: 否之匪人，不利君子貞。大往小來，則是天地不交，而萬物不通也；上下不交，而天下无邦也。內陰而外陽，內柔而外剛，內小人而外君子。小人道長，君子道消也。

Imagery.Hexagram: 天地不交，否；君子以儉德辟難，不可榮以祿。

Lines.L1: 拔茅貞吉，志在君也。
Lines.L2: 大人否亨，不亂群也。
Lines.L3: 包羞，位不當也。
Lines.L4: 有命无咎，志行也。
Lines.L5: 大人之吉，位正當也。
Lines.L6: 否終則傾，何可長也。

Scripture.Hexagram: 否之匪人，不利君子贞，大往小来。

Lines.L1: 初六：拔茅茹，以其汇，贞吉亨。
Lines.L2: 六二：包承。小人吉，大人否，亨。
Lines.L3: 六三：包羞。
Lines.L4: 九四：有命，无咎，畴离祉。
Lines.L5: 九五：休否，大人吉。其亡其亡，系于苞桑。
Lines.L6: 上九：倾否，先否后喜。

Exegesis.Judgment: 否之匪人，不利君子贞。大往小来，则是天地不交，而万物不通也；上下不交，而天下无邦也。内阴而外阳，内柔而外刚，内小人而外君子。小人道长，君子道消也。

Imagery.Hexagram: 天地不交，否；君子以俭德辟难，不可荣以禄。

Lines.L1: 拔茅贞吉，志在君也。
Lines.L2: 大人否亨，不乱群也。
Lines.L3: 包羞，位不当也。
Lines.L4: 有命无咎，志行也。
Lines.L5: 大人之吉，位正当也。
Lines.L6: 否终则倾，何可长也。

Scripture.Hexagram:
STANDSTILL. Evil people do not further
The perseverance of the superior man.
The great departs; the small approaches.

Lines.L1:
Six at the beginning means:
When ribbon grass is pulled up, the sod comes with it.
Each according to his kind.
Perseverance brings good fortune and success.
Lines.L2:
Six in the second place means:
They bear and endure;
This means good fortune for inferior people.
The standstill serves to help the great man to attain success.
Lines.L3:
Six in the third place means:
They bear shame.
Lines.L4:
Nine in the fourth place means:
He who acts at the command of the highest
Remains without blame.
Those of like mind partake of the blessing.
Lines.L5:
Nine in the fifth place means:
Standstill is giving way.
Good fortune for the great man.
“What if it should fail, what if it should fail?”
In this way he ties it to a cluster of mulberry shoots.
Lines.L6:
Nine at the top means:
The standstill comes to an end.
First standstill, then good fortune.

Exegesis.Judgment:
“Evil people of the time of STANDSTILL do not further the perseverance of the superior man. The great departs; the small approaches.”
Thus heaven and earth do not unite, and all beings fail to achieve union.
Upper and lower do not unite, and in the world, states go down to ruin.
The shadowy is within, the light without; weakness is within, firmness without; the inferior is within, the superior without. The way of the inferior is waxing, the way of the superior is waning.

Imagery.Hexagram:
Heaven and earth do not unite:
The image of STANDSTILL.
Thus the superior man falls back upon his inner worth
In order to escape the difficulties.
He does not permit himself to be honored with revenue.

Lines.L1:
Six at the beginning:
a) When ribbon grass is pulled up, the sod comes with it.
Each according to his kind.
Perseverance brings good fortune and success.
b) “When ribbon grass is pulled up…. Perseverance brings good fortune.” The will is directed to the ruler.
Lines.L2:
Six in the second place:
a) They bear and endure;
This means good fortune for inferior people.
The standstill serves to help the great man to attain success.
b) “The standstill serves to help the great man to attain success.” He does not confuse the masses.
Lines.L3:
Six in the third place:
a) They bear shame.
b) “They bear shame” because the place is not the right one.
Lines.L4:
Nine in the fourth place:
a) He who acts at the command of the highest
Remains without blame.
Those of like mind partake of the blessing.
b) “He who acts at the command of the highest remains without blame.” What is willed is done.
Lines.L5:
Nine in the fifth place:
a) Standstill is giving way.
Good fortune for the great man.
“What if it should fail, what if it should fail?”
In this way he ties it to a cluster of mulberry shoots.
b) The good fortune of the great man consists in the fact that the place is correct and appropriate.
Lines.L6:
Nine at the top:
a) The standstill comes to an end.
First standstill, then good fortune.
b) When the standstill comes to an end, it reverses.
One should not wish to make it permanent.

Exegesis.Miscellaneous: The hexagrams of STANDSTILL and PEACE are opposed in their natures.
Exegesis.Sequence: Things cannot remain forever united; hence there follows the hexagram of STANDSTILL.

Scripture.Hexagram: In Phî there is the want of good understanding between the (different classes of) men, and its indication is unfavourable to the firm and correct course of the superior man. We see in it the great gone and the little come.

Lines.L1: 1. The first SIX, divided, suggests the idea of grass pulled up, and bringing with it other stalks with whose roots it is connected. With firm correctness (on the part of its subject), there will be good fortune and progress.
Lines.L2: 2. The second SIX, divided, shows its subject patient and obedient. To the small man (comporting himself so) there will be good fortune. If the great man (comport himself) as the distress and obstruction require, he will have success.
Lines.L3: 3. The third SIX, divided, shows its subject ashamed of the purpose folded (in his breast).
Lines.L4: 4. The fourth NINE, undivided, shows its subject acting in accordance with the ordination (of Heaven), and committing no error. His companions will come and share in his happiness.
Lines.L5: 5. In the fifth NINE, undivided, we see him who brings the distress and obstruction to a close,—the great man and fortunate. (But let him say), 'We may perish! We may perish!' (so shall the state of things become firm, as if) bound to a clump of bushy mulberry trees.
Lines.L6: 6. The sixth NINE, undivided, shows the overthrow (and removal of) the condition of distress and obstruction. Before this there was that condition. Hereafter there will be joy.

Exegesis.Judgment: XII. 'The want of good understanding between the (different classes of) men in Phî, and its indication as unfavourable to the firm and correct course of the superior man; with the intimation that the great are gone and the little come:'--all this springs from the fact that in it heaven and earth are not in communication with each other, and all things in consequence do not have free course; and that the high and the low (superiors and inferiors) are not in communication with one another, and there are no (well-regulated) states under the sky. The inner (trigram) is made up of the weak and divided lines, and the outer of the strong and undivided: the inner is (the symbol of) weakness, and the outer of strength; the inner (represents) the small man, and the outer the superior man. Thus the way of the small man appears increasing, and that of the superior man decreasing.

Imagery.Hexagram: XII. (The trigrams of) heaven and earth, not in intercommunication, form Phî. The superior man, in accordance with this, restrains (the manifestation) of) his virtue, and avoids the calamities (that threaten him). There is no opportunity of conferring on him the glory of emolument.

Lines.L1: 1. 'The good fortune through firm goodness, (suggested by) the pulling up of the grass,' arises from the will (of the parties intended) being bent on (serving) the ruler.
Lines.L2: 2. 'The great man, comporting himself as the distress and obstruction require, will have success:--'he does not allow himself to be disordered by the herd (of small men).
Lines.L3: 3. That 'his shame is folded in his breast' is owing to the inappropriateness of his position.
Lines.L4: 4. 'He acts in accordance with the ordination (of Heaven), and commits no error:'--the purpose of his mind can be carried into effect.
Lines.L5: 5. The good fortune of the great man' arises from the correctness of his position.
Lines.L6: 6. 'The distress and obstruction having reached its end, it is overthrown and removed:'--how could it be prolonged?

Exegesis.Miscellaneous: 12, 11. While Phî and Thâi their different scopes prefer,
Exegesis.Sequence: 11-16. Thâi denotes things having free course. They cannot have that for ever, and hence it is followed by Phî (denoting being shut up and restricted). Things cannot for ever be shut up, and hence Phî is followed by Thung Žân. To him who cultivates union with men, things must come to belong, and hence Thung Žân. is followed by Tâ Yû. Those who, have what is great should not allow in themselves the feeling of being full, and hence Tâ Yû is followed by Khien. When great possessions are associated with humility, there is sure to be pleasure and satisfaction; and hence Khien is followed by Yü.

Scripture.Hexagram: 同人于野，亨。利涉大川，利君子貞。

Lines.L1: 初九：同人于門，无咎。
Lines.L2: 六二：同人于宗，吝。
Lines.L3: 九三：伏戎于莽，升其高陵，三歲不興。
Lines.L4: 九四：乘其墉，弗克攻，吉。
Lines.L5: 九五：同人，先號咷而後笑。大師克相遇。
Lines.L6: 上九：同人于郊，无悔。

Exegesis.Judgment: 同人，柔得位得中，而應乎乾，曰同人。同人曰，同人于野，亨。利涉大川，乾行也。文明以健，中正而應，君子正也。唯君子為能通天下之志。

Imagery.Hexagram: 天與火，同人；君子以類族辨物。

Lines.L1: 出門同人，又誰咎也。
Lines.L2: 同人于宗，吝道也。
Lines.L3: 伏戎于莽，敵剛也。三歲不興，安行也。
Lines.L4: 乘其墉，義弗克也，其吉，則困而反則也。
Lines.L5: 同人之先，以中直也。大師相遇，言相克也。
Lines.L6: 同人于郊，志未得也。

Scripture.Hexagram: 同人于野，亨。利涉大川，利君子贞。

Lines.L1: 初九：同人于门，无咎。
Lines.L2: 六二：同人于宗，吝。
Lines.L3: 九三：伏戎于莽，升其高陵，三岁不兴。
Lines.L4: 九四：乘其墉，弗克攻，吉。
Lines.L5: 九五：同人，先号啕而后笑。大师克相遇。
Lines.L6: 上九：同人于郊，无悔。

Exegesis.Judgment: 同人，柔得位得中，而应乎乾，曰同人。同人曰，同人于野，亨。利涉大川，乾行也。文明以健，中正而应，君子正也。唯君子为能通天下之志。

Imagery.Hexagram: 天与火，同人；君子以类族辨物。

Lines.L1: 出门同人，又谁咎也。
Lines.L2: 同人于宗，吝道也。
Lines.L3: 伏戎于莽，敌刚也。三岁不兴，安行也。
Lines.L4: 乘其墉，义弗克也，其吉，则困而反则也。
Lines.L5: 同人之先，以中直也。大师相遇，言相克也。
Lines.L6: 同人于郊，志未得也。

Scripture.Hexagram:
FELLOWSHIP WITH MEN in the open.
Success.
It furthers one to cross the great water.
The perseverance of the superior man furthers.

Lines.L1:
Nine at the beginning means:
Fellowship with men at the gate.
No blame.
Lines.L2:
Six in the second place means:
Fellowship with men in the clan.
Humiliation.
Lines.L3:
Nine in the third place means:
He hides weapons in the thicket;
He climbs the high hill in front of it.
For three years he does not rise up.
Lines.L4:
Nine in the fourth place means:
He climbs up on his wall; he cannot attack.
Good fortune.
Lines.L5:
Nine in the fifth place means:
Men bound in fellowship first weep and lament,
But afterward they laugh.
After great struggles they succeed in meeting.
Lines.L6:
Nine at the top means:
Fellowship with men in the meadow.
No remorse.

Exegesis.Judgment:
FELLOWSHIP WITH MEN. The yielding finds its place, finds the middle, and the Creative corresponds with it: this means fellowship with men.
FELLOWSHIP WITH MEN means: “Fellowship with men in the open. Success. It furthers one to cross the great water.”
The Creative acts. Order and clarity, in combination with strength; central, correct, and in the relationship of correspondence: this is the correctness of the superior man. Only the superior man is able to unite the wills of all under heaven.

Imagery.Hexagram:
Heaven together with fire:
The image of FELLOWSHIP WITH MEN.
Thus the superior man organizes the clans
And makes distinctions between things.

Lines.L1:
Nine at the beginning:
a) Fellowship with men at the gate.
No blame.
b) Going out of the gate for fellowship with men—who would find anything to blame in this?
Lines.L2:
Six in the second place:
a) Fellowship with men in the clan.
Humiliation.
b) “Fellowship with men in the clan” is the way to humiliation.
Lines.L3:
Nine in the third place:
a) He hides weapons in the thicket;
He climbs the high hill in front of it.
For three years he does not rise up.
b) “He hides weapons in the thicket” because he had a hard man as opponent.
“For three years he does not rise up.” How could it be done?
Lines.L4:
Nine in the fourth place:
a) He climbs up on his wall; he cannot attack.
Good fortune.
b) “He climbs up on his wall.” The situation means that he can do nothing. His good fortune consists in the fact that he gets into trouble and therefore returns to lawful ways.
Lines.L5:
Nine in the fifth place:
a) Men bound in fellowship first weep and lament,
But afterward they laugh.
After great struggles they succeed in meeting.
b) The beginning of the men bound in fellowship is central and straight.
“After great struggles they succeed in meeting,” that is, they are victorious.
Lines.L6:
Nine at the top:
a) Fellowship with men in the meadow.
No remorse.
b) “Fellowship with men in the meadow.” The will is not yet satisfied.

Exegesis.Miscellaneous: Fellowship with men finds love.
Exegesis.Sequence: Things cannot be at a standstill forever. Hence there follows the hexagram of FELLOWSIDP WITH MEN.

Scripture.Hexagram: Thung Zăn (or 'Union of men') appears here (as we find it) in the (remote districts of the) country, indicating progress and success. It will be advantageous to cross the great stream. It will be advantageous to maintain the firm correctness of the superior man.

Lines.L1: 1. The first NINE, undivided, (shows the representative of) the union of men just issuing from his gate. There will be no error.
Lines.L2: 2. The second SIX, divided, (shows the representative of) the union of men in relation with his kindred. There will be occasion for regret.
Lines.L3: 3. The third NINE, undivided, (shows its subject) with his arms hidden in the thick grass, and at the top of a high mound. (But) for three years he makes no demonstration.
Lines.L4: 4. The fourth NINE, undivided, (shows its subject) mounted on the city wall; but he does not proceed to make the attack (he contemplates). There will be good fortune.
Lines.L5: 5. In the fifth NINE, undivided, (the representative of) the union of men first wails and cries out, and then laughs. His great host conquers, and he (and the subject of the second line) meet together.
Lines.L6: 6. The topmost NINE, undivided, (shows the representative of) the union of men in the suburbs. There will be no occasion for repentance.

Exegesis.Judgment:
XIII. 1. In Thung Zăn the weak (line) has the place (of influence), the central place, and responds to (the corresponding line in) Khien (above); hence comes its name of Thung Zăn (or 'Union of men').
2. Thung Zăn says:--
3. The language, 'Thung Zăn appears here (as we find it) in (the remote districts of) the country, indicating progress and success, and that it will be advantageous to cross the great stream,' is moulded by its containing the strength (symbolled) in Khien. (Then) we have (the trigram indicating) elegance and intelligence, supported by (that indicating) strength; with the line in the central, and its correct, position, and responding (to the corresponding line above):--(all representing) the correct course of the superior man. It is only the superior man who can comprehend and affect the minds of all under the sky.

Imagery.Hexagram: XIII. (The trigrams for) heaven and fire form Thung Zăn. The superior man, in accordance with this), distinguishes things according to their kinds and classes.

Lines.L1: 1. '(The representative of) the union of men is just issuing from his gate:'--who will blame him?
Lines.L2: 2. '(The representative of) the union of men appears in relation with his kindred:'--that is the path to regret.
Lines.L3: 3. 'He hides his arms in the thick grass:'--because of the strength of his opponent. 'For three years he makes no demonstration:'--how can he do anything?
Lines.L4: 4. 'He is mounted on his city-wall;' but yielding to the right, 'he does not proceed to make the attack (he contemplated).' (Where it is said),'There will be good fortune,' (that shows how) he feels the strait he is in, and returns to the rule of law.
Lines.L5: 5. The first action of (the representative of) the union of men (here described) arises from his central position and straightforward character. 'The meeting secured by his great host' intimates that the opponents of it have been overcome.
Lines.L6: 6. '(The representative of) the union of men appears in the suburbs:'--his object has not yet been attained.

Exegesis.Sequence: 11-16. Thâi denotes things having free course. They cannot have that for ever, and hence it is followed by Phî (denoting being shut up and restricted). Things cannot for ever be shut up, and hence Phî is followed by Thung Žân. To him who cultivates union with men, things must come to belong, and hence Thung Žân. is followed by Tâ Yû. Those who, have what is great should not allow in themselves the feeling of being full, and hence Tâ Yû is followed by Khien. When great possessions are associated with humility, there is sure to be pleasure and satisfaction; and hence Khien is followed by Yü.

English.WilhelmBaynes: Ta Yu / Posession in Great Measure

Scripture.Hexagram: 大有：元亨。

Lines.L1: 初九：无交害，匪咎，艱則无咎。
Lines.L2: 九二：大車以載，有攸往，无咎。
Lines.L3: 九三：公用亨于天子，小人弗克。
Lines.L4: 九四：匪其彭，无咎。
Lines.L5: 六五：厥孚交如，威如；吉。
Lines.L6: 上九：自天祐之，吉无不利。

Exegesis.Judgment: 大有，柔得尊位，大中而上下應之，曰大有。其德剛健而文明，應乎天而時行，是以元亨。

Imagery.Hexagram: 火在天上，大有；君子以遏惡揚善，順天休命。

Lines.L1: 大有初九，无交害也。
Lines.L2: 大車以載，積中不敗也。
Lines.L3: 公用亨于天子，小人害也。
Lines.L4: 匪其彭，无咎；明辨晰也。
Lines.L5: 厥孚交如，信以發志也。威如之吉，易而无備也。
Lines.L6: 大有上吉，自天佑也。

Scripture.Hexagram: 大有：元亨。

Lines.L1: 初九：无交害，匪咎，艰则无咎。
Lines.L2: 九二：大车以载，有攸往，无咎。
Lines.L3: 九三：公用亨于天子，小人弗克。
Lines.L4: 九四：匪其彭，无咎。
Lines.L5: 六五：厥孚交如，威如；吉。
Lines.L6: 上九：自天佑之，吉无不利。

Exegesis.Judgment: 大有，柔得尊位，大中而上下应之，曰大有。其德刚健而文明，应乎天而时行，是以元亨。

Imagery.Hexagram: 火在天上，大有；君子以遏恶扬善，顺天休命。

Lines.L1: 大有初九，无交害也。
Lines.L2: 大车以载，积中不败也。
Lines.L3: 公用亨于天子，小人害也。
Lines.L4: 匪其彭，无咎；明辨晰也。
Lines.L5: 厥孚交如，信以发志也。威如之吉，易而无备也。
Lines.L6: 大有上吉，自天佑也。

Scripture.Hexagram:
POSSESSION IN GREAT MEASURE.
Supreme success.

Lines.L1:
Nine at the beginning means:
No relationship with what is harmful;
There is no blame in this.
If one remains conscious of difficulty,
One remains without blame.
Lines.L2:
Nine in the second place means:
A big wagon for loading.
One may undertake something.
No blame.
Lines.L3:
Nine in the third place means:
A prince offers it to the Son of Heaven.
A petty man cannot do this.
Lines.L4:
Nine in the fourth place means:
He makes a difference
Between himself and his neighbor.
No blame.
Lines.L5:
Six in the fifth place means:
He whose truth is accessible, yet dignified,
Has good fortune.
Lines.L6:
Nine at the top means:
He is blessed by heaven.
Good fortune.
Nothing that does not further.

Exegesis.Judgment:
POSSESSION IN GREAT MEASURE: the yielding receives the honored place in the great middle, and upper and lower correspond with it. This is called POSSESSION IN GREAT MEASURE.
His character is firm and strong, ordered and clear; it finds correspondence in heaven and moves with the time; hence the words, “Supreme success.”

Imagery.Hexagram:
Fire in heaven above:
The image of POSSESSION IN GREAT MEASURE.
Thus the superior man curbs evil and furthers good,
And thereby obeys the benevolent will of heaven.

Lines.L1:
Nine at the beginning:
a) No relationship with what is harmful;
There is no blame in this.
If one remains conscious of difficulty,
One remains without blame.
b) If the nine at the beginning in POSSESSION IN GREAT MEASURE has no relationships, this is harmful.
Lines.L2:
Nine in the second place:
a) A big wagon for loading.
One may undertake something.
No blame.
b) “A big wagon for loading.” Accumulating in the middle; thus no harm results.
Lines.L3:
Nine in the third place:
a) A prince offers it to the Son of Heaven.
A petty man cannot do this.
b) “A prince offers it to the Son of Heaven.” A petty man harms himself.
Lines.L4:
Nine in the fourth place:
a) He makes a difference
Between himself and his neighbor.
No blame.
b) “He makes a difference between himself and his neighbor. No blame.” He is clear, discriminating, and intelligent.
Lines.L5:
Six in the fifth place:
a) He whose truth is accessible, yet dignified,
Has good fortune.
b) “He whose truth is accessible”: by his trustworthiness he kindles the will of others. The good fortune of his dignity comes from the fact that he acts easily, without prearrangements.
Lines.L6:
Nine at the top:
a) He is blessed by heaven.
Good fortune.
Nothing that does not further.
b) The place at the top of POSSESSION IN GREAT MEASURE has good fortune. This is because it is blessed by heaven.

Exegesis.Miscellaneous: POSSESSION IN GREAT MEASURE indicates the mass.
Exegesis.Sequence: Through FELLOWSHIP WITH MEN things are sure to fall to one’s lot. Hence there follows the hexagram of POSSESSION IN GREAT MEASURE.

Scripture.Hexagram: Tâ Yû indicates that, (under the circumstances which it implies), there will be great progress and success.

Lines.L1: 1. In the first NINE, undivided, there is no approach to what is injurious, and there is no error. Let there be a realisation of the difficulty (and danger of the position), and there will be no error (to the end).
Lines.L2: 2. In the second NINE, undivided, we have a large waggon with its load. In whatever direction advance is made, there will be no error.
Lines.L3: 3. The third NINE, undivided, shows us a feudal prince presenting his offerings to the Son of Heaven. A small man would be unequal (to such a duty).
Lines.L4: 4. The fourth NINE, undivided, shows its subject keeping his great resources under restraint. There will be no error.
Lines.L5: 5. The fifth SIX, divided, shows the sincerity of its subject reciprocated by that of all the others (represented in the hexagram). Let him display a proper majesty, and there will be good fortune.
Lines.L6: 6. The topmost NINE, undivided, shows its subject with help accorded to him from Heaven. There will be good fortune, advantage in every respect.

Exegesis.Judgment:
XIV. 1. In Tâ Yû the weak (line) has the place of honour, is grandly central, and (the strong lines) above and below respond to it. Hence comes its name of Tâ Yû (Having what is Great).
2. The attributes (of its component trigrams) are strength and vigour with elegance and brightness. (The ruling line in it) responds to (the ruling line in the symbol of) heaven, and (consequently) its action is (all) at the proper times. In this way (it is said to) indicate great progress and success.

Imagery.Hexagram: XIV. (The trigram for) heaven and (that of) fire above it form Tâ Yû The superior man, in accordance with this, represses what is evil and gives distinction to what is good, in sympathy with the excellent Heaven-conferred (nature).

Lines.L1: 1. This first NINE, (undivided),of Tâ Yû shows no approach to what is injurious.
Lines.L2: 2. 'A large waggon with its load' refers to the (virtue) accumulated (in the subject of the line), so that he will suffer no loss (in the conduct of affairs).
Lines.L3: 3. 'A feudal prince presents his offerings to the son of Heaven:'--a small man (in such a position) does (himself) harm.
Lines.L4: 4. 'He keeps his great resources under restraint:'--his wisdom discriminates clearly (what he ought to do).
Lines.L5: 5. 'His sincerity is reciprocated by all the others:'--his sincerity serves to stir and call out what is in their minds. 'The good fortune springing from a display of proper majesty' shows how they might (otherwise) feel too easy, and make no preparation (to serve him).
Lines.L6: 6. 'The good fortune attached to the topmost line of Tâ Yû' arises from the help of Heaven.

Exegesis.Sequence: 11-16. Thâi denotes things having free course. They cannot have that for ever, and hence it is followed by Phî (denoting being shut up and restricted). Things cannot for ever be shut up, and hence Phî is followed by Thung Žân. To him who cultivates union with men, things must come to belong, and hence Thung Žân. is followed by Tâ Yû. Those who, have what is great should not allow in themselves the feeling of being full, and hence Tâ Yû is followed by Khien. When great possessions are associated with humility, there is sure to be pleasure and satisfaction; and hence Khien is followed by Yü.

Scripture.Hexagram: 謙：亨，君子有終。

Lines.L1: 初六：謙謙君子，用涉大川，吉。
Lines.L2: 六二：鳴謙，貞吉。
Lines.L3: 九三：勞謙，君子有終，吉。
Lines.L4: 六四：无不利，撝謙。
Lines.L5: 六五：不富，以其鄰，利用侵伐，无不利。
Lines.L6: 上六：鳴謙，利用行師，征邑國。

Exegesis.Judgment: 謙，亨，天道下濟而光明，地道卑而上行。天道虧盈而益謙，地道變盈而流謙，鬼神害盈而福謙，人道惡盈而好謙。謙尊而光，卑而不可踰，君子之終也。

Imagery.Hexagram: 地中有山，謙；君子以裒多益寡，稱物平施。

Lines.L1: 謙謙君子，卑以自牧也。
Lines.L2: 鳴謙貞吉，中心得也。
Lines.L3: 勞謙君子，萬民服也。
Lines.L4: 无不利，撝謙；不違則也。
Lines.L5: 利用侵伐，征不服也。
Lines.L6: 鳴謙，志未得也。可用行師，征邑國也。

Scripture.Hexagram: 谦：亨，君子有终。

Lines.L1: 初六：谦谦君子，用涉大川，吉。
Lines.L2: 六二：鸣谦，贞吉。
Lines.L3: 九三：劳谦，君子有终，吉。
Lines.L4: 六四：无不利，撝谦。
Lines.L5: 六五：不富，以其邻，利用侵伐，无不利。
Lines.L6: 上六：鸣谦，利用行师，征邑国。

Exegesis.Judgment: 谦，亨，天道下济而光明，地道卑而上行。天道亏盈而益谦，地道变盈而流谦，鬼神害盈而福谦，人道恶盈而好谦。谦尊而光，卑而不可逾，君子之终也。

Imagery.Hexagram: 地中有山，谦；君子以裒多益寡，称物平施。

Lines.L1: 谦谦君子，卑以自牧也。
Lines.L2: 鸣谦贞吉，中心得也。
Lines.L3: 劳谦君子，万民服也。
Lines.L4: 无不利，撝谦；不违则也。
Lines.L5: 利用侵伐，征不服也。
Lines.L6: 鸣谦，志未得也。可用行师，征邑国也。

Scripture.Hexagram:
MODESTY creates success.
The superior man carries things through.

Lines.L1:
Six at the beginning means:
A superior man modest about his modesty
May cross the great water.
Good fortune.
Lines.L2:
Six in the second place means:
Modesty that comes to expression.
Perseverance brings good fortune.
Lines.L3:
Nine in the third place means:
A superior man of modesty and merit
Carries things to conclusion.
Good fortune.
Lines.L4:
Six in the fourth place means:
Nothing that would not further modesty
In movement.
Lines.L5:
Six in the fifth place means:
No boasting of wealth before one’s neighbor.
It is favorable to attack with force.
Nothing that would not further.
Lines.L6:
Six at the top means:
Modesty that comes to expression.
It is favorable to set armies marching
To chastise one’s own city and one’s country.

Exegesis.Judgment:
MODESTY creates success, for it is the way of heaven to shed its influence downward and to create light and radiance. It is the way of the earth to be lowly and to go upward.
It is the way of heaven to make empty what is full and to give increase to what is modest. It is the way of the earth to change the full and to augment the modest. Spirits and gods bring harm to what is, full and prosper what is modest. It is the way of men to hate fullness and to love the modest.
Modesty that is honored spreads radiance. Modesty that is lowly cannot be ignored. This is the end attained by the superior man.

Imagery.Hexagram:
Within the earth, a mountain:
The image of MODESTY.
Thus the superior man reduces that which is too much,
And augments that which is too little.
He weighs things and makes them equal.

Lines.L1:
Six at the beginning:
a) A superior man modest about his modesty
May cross the great water.
Good fortune.
b) “A superior man modest about his modesty” is lowly in order to guard himself well.
Lines.L2:
Six in the second place:
a) Modesty that comes to expression.
Perseverance brings good fortune.
b) “Modesty that comes to expression. Perseverance brings good fortune.” He has it in the depths of his heart.
Lines.L3:
Nine in the third place:
a) A superior man of modesty and merit
Carries things to conclusion.
Good fortune.
b) “A superior man of modesty and merit”: all the people obey him.
Lines.L4:
Six in the fourth place:
a) Nothing that would not further modesty
In movement.
b) “Nothing that would not further modesty in movement.” He does not overstep the rule.
Lines.L5:
Six in the fifth place:
a) No boasting of wealth before one’s neighbor.
It is favorable to attack with force.
Nothing that would not further.
b) “It is favorable to attack with force” in order to chastise the disobedient.
Lines.L6:
Six at the top:
a) Modesty that comes to expression.
It is favorable to set armies marching
To chastise one’s own city and one’s country.
b) “Modesty that comes to expression.” The purpose is not yet attained. One may set armies marching, in order to chastise one’s own city and one’s country.

Exegesis.Miscellaneous: Things are easy for the modest person.
Exegesis.Sequence: He who possesses something great must not make it too full; hence there follows the hexagram of MODESTY.
Exegesis.Extracts: MODESTY shows the handle of character. MODESTY gives honor and shines forth. MODESTY serves to regulate the mores.

Scripture.Hexagram: Kh îen indicates progress and success. The superior man, (being humble as it implies), will have a (good) issue (to his undertakings).

Lines.L1: 1. The first SIX, divided, shows us the superior man who adds humility to humility. (Even) the great stream may be crossed with this, and there will be good fortune.
Lines.L2: 2. The second SIX, divided, shows us humility that has made itself recognised. With firm correctness there will be good fortune.
Lines.L3: 3. The third NINE, undivided, shows the superior man of (acknowledged) merit. He will maintain his success to the end, and have good fortune.
Lines.L4: 4. The fourth SIX, divided, shows one, whose action would be in every way advantageous, stirring up (the more) his humility.
Lines.L5: 5. The fifth SIX, divided, shows one who, without being rich, is able to employ his neighbours. He may advantageously use the force of arms. All his movements will be advantageous.
Lines.L6: 6. The sixth SIX, divided, shows us humility that has made itself recognised. The subject of it will with advantage put his hosts in motion; but (he will only) punish his own towns and state.

Exegesis.Judgment:
XV. 1. Khien indicates progress and success. It is the way of heaven to send down its beneficial influences below, where they are brilliantly displayed. It is the way of earth, lying low, to send its influences upwards and (there) to act.
2. It is the way of heaven to diminish the full and augment the humble. It is the way of earth to overthrow the full and replenish the humble. Spiritual Beings inflict calamity on the full and bless the humble. It is the way of men to hate the full and love the humble. Humility in a position of honour makes that still more brilliant; and in a low position men will not (seek to) pass beyond it. Thus it is that 'the superior man will have a (good) issue (to his undertakings).'

Imagery.Hexagram: XV. (The trigram for) the earth and (that of) a mountain in the midst of it form Khien. The superior man, in accordance with this, diminishes what is excessive (in himself), and increases where there is any defect, bringing about an equality, according to the nature of the case, in his treatment (of himself and others).

Lines.L1: 1. 'The superior man who adds humility to humility' is one who nourishes his (virtue) in lowliness.
Lines.L2: 2. 'The good fortune consequent on being firm and correct, where the humility has made itself recognised, is owing to the possessor's having (the virtue) in the core of his heart.
Lines.L3: 3. 'The superior man of (acknowledged) merit, and yet humble:'--the myriads of the people will submit to him.
Lines.L4: 4. 'One, whose action would be in every way advantageous, stirs up his humility the more:'(but in doing so) he does not act contrary to the (proper) rule.
Lines.L5: 5. 'He may advantageously use the force of arms:'--correcting, that is, those who do not submit.
Lines.L6: 6. 'His humility has made itself recognised:'--(but) all his aims have not yet been attained. He may employ the force of arms, (but only) in correcting (his own) towns and state.'

Exegesis.Miscellaneous: 15, 16. Khien itself, Yü others doth despise.
Exegesis.Sequence: 11-16. Thâi denotes things having free course. They cannot have that for ever, and hence it is followed by Phî (denoting being shut up and restricted). Things cannot for ever be shut up, and hence Phî is followed by Thung Žân. To him who cultivates union with men, things must come to belong, and hence Thung Žân. is followed by Tâ Yû. Those who, have what is great should not allow in themselves the feeling of being full, and hence Tâ Yû is followed by Khien. When great possessions are associated with humility, there is sure to be pleasure and satisfaction; and hence Khien is followed by Yü.

Scripture.Hexagram: 豫：利建侯，行師。

Lines.L1: 初六：鳴豫，凶。
Lines.L2: 六二：介于石，不終日，貞吉。
Lines.L3: 六三：盱豫，悔。遲有悔。
Lines.L4: 九四：由豫，大有得。勿疑。朋盍簪。
Lines.L5: 六五：貞疾，恆不死。
Lines.L6: 上六：冥豫，成有渝，无咎。

Exegesis.Judgment: 豫，剛應而志行，順以動，豫。豫，順以動，故天地如之，而況建侯行師乎？天地以順動，故日月不過，而四時不忒；聖人以順動，則刑罰清而民服。豫之時義大矣哉！

Imagery.Hexagram: 雷出地奮，豫。先王以作樂崇德，殷薦之上帝，以配祖考。

Lines.L1: 初六鳴豫，志窮凶也。
Lines.L2: 不終日，貞吉；以中正也。
Lines.L3: 盱豫有悔，位不當也。
Lines.L4: 由豫，大有得；志大行也。
Lines.L5: 六五貞疾，乘剛也。恆不死，中未亡也。
Lines.L6: 冥豫在上，何可長也。

Scripture.Hexagram: 豫：利建侯，行师。

Lines.L1: 初六：鸣豫，凶。
Lines.L2: 六二：介于石，不终日，贞吉。
Lines.L3: 六三：盱豫，悔。迟有悔。
Lines.L4: 九四：由豫，大有得。勿疑。朋盍簪。
Lines.L5: 六五：贞疾，恒不死。
Lines.L6: 上六：冥豫，成有渝，无咎。

Exegesis.Judgment: 豫，刚应而志行，顺以动，豫。豫，顺以动，故天地如之，而况建侯行师乎？天地以顺动，故日月不过，而四时不忒；圣人以顺动，则刑罚清而民服。豫之时义大矣哉！

Imagery.Hexagram: 雷出地奋，豫。先王以作乐崇德，殷荐之上帝，以配祖考。

Lines.L1: 初六鸣豫，志穷凶也。
Lines.L2: 不终日，贞吉；以中正也。
Lines.L3: 盱豫有悔，位不当也。
Lines.L4: 由豫，大有得；志大行也。
Lines.L5: 六五贞疾，乘刚也。恒不死，中未亡也。
Lines.L6: 冥豫在上，何可长也。

Scripture.Hexagram:
ENTHUSIASM. It furthers one to install helpers
And to set armies marching.

Lines.L1:
Six at the beginning means:
Enthusiasm that expresses itself
Brings misfortune.
Lines.L2:
Six in the second place means:
Firm as a rock. Not a whole day.
Perseverance brings good fortune.
Lines.L3:
Six in the third place means:
Enthusiasm that looks upward creates remorse.
Hesitation brings remorse.
Lines.L4:
Nine in the fourth place means:
The source of enthusiasm.
He achieves great things.
Doubt not.
You gather friends around you
As a hair clasp gathers the hair.
Lines.L5:
Six in the fifth place means:
Persistently ill, and still does not die.
Lines.L6:
Six at the top means:
Deluded enthusiasm.
But if after completion one changes,
There is no blame.

Exegesis.Judgment:
ENTHUSIASM. The firm finds correspondence, and its will is done. Devotion to movement: this is ENTHUSIASM.
Because ENTHUSIASM shows devotion to movement, heaven and earth are at its side. How much the more then is it possible to install helpers and set armies marching!
Heaven and earth move with devotion; therefore sun and moon do not swerve from their courses, and the four seasons do not err.
The holy man moves with devotion; therefore fines and punishments become just, and the people obey. Great indeed is the meaning of the time of ENTHUSIASM.

Imagery.Hexagram:
Thunder comes resounding out of the earth:
The image of ENTHUSIASM.
Thus the ancient kings made music
In order to honor merit,
And offered it with splendor
To the Supreme Deity,
Inviting their ancestors to be present.

Lines.L1:
Six at the beginning:
a) Enthusiasm that expresses itself
Brings misfortune.
b) The six at the beginning expresses its enthusiasm; this leads to the misfortune of having the will obstructed.
Lines.L2:
Six in the second place:
a) Firm as a rock. Not a whole day.
Perseverance brings good fortune.
b) “Not a whole day. Perseverance brings good fortune,” because it is central and correct.
Lines.L3:
Six in the third place:
a) Enthusiasm that looks upward creates remorse.
Hesitation brings remorse.
b) “Enthusiasm that looks upward creates remorse,” because the place is not the appropriate one.
Lines.L4:
Nine in the fourth place:
a) The source of enthusiasm.
He achieves great things.
Doubt not.
You gather friends around you
As a hair clasp gathers the hair.
b) “The source of enthusiasm. He achieves great things.” His will is done in great things.
Lines.L5:
Six in the fifth place:
a) Persistently ill, and still does not die.
b) The persistent illness of the six in the fifth place is due to the fact that it rests upon a hard line. That it nevertheless does not die is due to the fact that the middle has not yet been passed.
Lines.L6:
Six at the top:
a) Deluded enthusiasm.
But if after completion one changes,
There is no blame.
b) Deluded enthusiasm in a high place: how could this last?

Exegesis.Miscellaneous: ENTHUSIASM leads to inertia.
Exegesis.Sequence: When one possesses something great and is modest, there is sure to be enthusiasm. Hence there follows the hexagram of ENTHUSIASM.
Exegesis.Extracts: The heroes of old introduced double gates and night watchmen with clappers, in order to deal with robbers. They probably took this from the hexagram of ENTHUSIASM.

Scripture.Hexagram: Yü indicates that, (in the state which it implies), feudal princes may be set up, and the hosts put in motion, with advantage.

Lines.L1: 1. The first SIX, divided, shows its subject proclaiming his pleasure and satisfaction. There will be evil.
Lines.L2: 2. The second SIX, divided, shows one who is firm as a rock. (He sees a thing) without waiting till it has come to pass; with his firm correctness there will be good fortune.
Lines.L3: 3. The third SIX, divided, shows one looking up (for favours), while he indulges the feeling of pleasure and satisfaction. If he would understand!--If he be late in doing so, there will indeed be occasion for repentance.
Lines.L4: 4. The fourth NINE, undivided, shows him from whom the harmony and satisfaction come. Great is the success which he obtains. Let him not allow suspicions to enter his mind, and thus friends will gather around him.
Lines.L5: 5. The fifth SIX, divided, shows one with a chronic complaint, but who lives on without dying.
Lines.L6: 6. The topmost SIX, divided, shows its subject with darkened mind devoted to the pleasure and satisfaction (of the time); but if he change his course even when (it may be considered as) completed, there will be no error.

Exegesis.Judgment:
XVI. 1. In Yü we see the strong (line) responded to by all the others, and the will (of him whom it represents) being carried out; and (also) docile obedience employing movement (for its purposes). (From these things comes) Yü (the Condition of harmony and satisfaction).
2. In this condition we have docile obedience employing movement (for its purposes), and therefore it is so as between heaven and earth;--how much more will it be so (among men) in 'the setting up of feudal princes and putting the hosts in motion!'
3. Heaven and earth show that docile obedience in connexion with movement, and hence the sun and moon make no error (in time), and the four seasons do not deviate (from their order). The sages show such docile obedience in connexion with their movements, and hence their punishments and penalties are entirely just, and the people acknowledge it by their submission. Great indeed are the time and significance indicated in Yü!

Imagery.Hexagram: XVI. (The trigrams for) the earth and thunder issuing from it with its crashing noise form Yü. The ancient kings, in accordance with this, composed their music and did honour to virtue, presenting it especially and most grandly to God,when they associated with Him (at the service) their highest ancestor and their father.

Lines.L1: 1. 'The (subject of the) first six proclaims his pleasure and satisfaction:'--there will be evil; his wishes have been satisfied to overflowing.
Lines.L2: 2. '(He sees a thing) without waiting till it has come to pass; with his firm correctness there will be good fortune:'--this is shown by the central and correct position (of the line).
Lines.L3: 3. 'He looks up (for favours), while he indulges the feeling of satisfaction; there will be occasion for repentance:'--this is intimated by the position not being the appropriate one.
Lines.L4: 4. 'From him the harmony and satisfaction come; great is the success which he obtains:'--his aims take effect on a grand scale.
Lines.L5: 5. '(The subject of) the fifth six has a chronic complaint:'--this is shown by his being mounted on the strong (line). 'He still lives on without dying:'--he is in the central position, (and its memories of the past) have not yet perished.
Lines.L6: 6. 'With darkened mind devoted to the harmony and satisfaction (of the time),' as shown in the topmost (line):--how can one in such a condition continue long?

Exegesis.Miscellaneous: 15, 16. Khien itself, Yü others doth despise.
Exegesis.Sequence:
11-16. Thâi denotes things having free course. They cannot have that for ever, and hence it is followed by Phî (denoting being shut up and restricted). Things cannot for ever be shut up, and hence Phî is followed by Thung Žân. To him who cultivates union with men, things must come to belong, and hence Thung Žân. is followed by Tâ Yû. Those who, have what is great should not allow in themselves the feeling of being full, and hence Tâ Yû is followed by Khien. When great possessions are associated with humility, there is sure to be pleasure and satisfaction; and hence Khien is followed by Yü.
16-19. Where such complacency is awakened, (he who causes it) is sure to have followers. They who follow another are sure to have services (to perform), and hence Sui is followed by Kû. Kû means (the performance of) services. He who performs such services may afterwards become great, and hence Kû is followed by Lin. Lin means great.

Scripture.Hexagram: 隨：元亨利貞，无咎。

Lines.L1: 初九：官有渝，貞吉。出門交有功。
Lines.L2: 六二：系小子，失丈夫。
Lines.L3: 六三：系丈夫，失小子。隨有求得，利居貞。
Lines.L4: 九四：隨有獲，貞凶。有孚在道，以明，何咎。
Lines.L5: 九五：孚于嘉，吉。
Lines.L6: 上六：拘系之，乃從維之。王用亨于西山。

Exegesis.Judgment: 隨，剛來而下柔，動而說，隨。大亨貞，无咎，而天下隨時，隨時之義大矣哉！

Imagery.Hexagram: 澤中有雷，隨；君子以嚮晦入宴息。

Lines.L1: 官有渝，從正吉也。出門交有功，不失也。
Lines.L2: 係小子，弗兼與也。
Lines.L3: 系丈夫，志舍下也。
Lines.L4: 隨有獲，其義凶也。有孚在道，明功也。
Lines.L5: 孚于嘉，吉；位正中也。
Lines.L6: 拘系之，上窮也。

Scripture.Hexagram: 随：元亨利贞，无咎。

Lines.L1: 初九：官有渝，贞吉。出门交有功。
Lines.L2: 六二：系小子，失丈夫。
Lines.L3: 六三：系丈夫，失小子。随有求得，利居贞。
Lines.L4: 九四：随有获，贞凶。有孚在道，以明，何咎。
Lines.L5: 九五：孚于嘉，吉。
Lines.L6: 上六：拘系之，乃从维之。王用亨于西山。

Exegesis.Judgment: 随，刚来而下柔，动而说，随。大亨贞，无咎，而天下随时，随时之义大矣哉！

Imagery.Hexagram: 泽中有雷，随；君子以向晦入宴息。

Lines.L1: 官有渝，从正吉也。出门交有功，不失也。
Lines.L2: 系小子，弗兼与也。
Lines.L3: 系丈夫，志舍下也。
Lines.L4: 随有获，其义凶也。有孚在道，明功也。
Lines.L5: 孚于嘉，吉；位正中也。
Lines.L6: 拘系之，上穷也。

Scripture.Hexagram:
FOLLOWING has supreme success.
Perseverance furthers. No blame.

Lines.L1:
Nine at the beginning means:
The standard is changing.
Perseverance brings good fortune.
To go out of the door in company
Produces deeds.
Lines.L2:
Six in the second place means:
If one clings to the little boy,
One loses the strong man.
Lines.L3:
Six in the third place means:
If one clings to the strong man,
One loses the little boy.
Through following one finds what one seeks.
It furthers one to remain persevering.
Lines.L4:
Nine in the fourth place means:
Following creates success.
Perseverance brings misfortune.
To go one’s way with sincerity brings clarity.
How could there be blame in this?
Lines.L5:
Nine in the fifth place means:
Sincere in the good. Good fortune.
Lines.L6:
Six at the top means:
He meets with firm allegiance
And is still further bound.
The king introduces him
To the Western Mountain.

Exegesis.Judgment:
FOLLOWING. The firm comes and places itself under the yielding.
Movement and joyousness: FOLLOWING.
Great success and perseverance without blame: thus one is followed by the whole world.
Great indeed is the meaning of the time of FOLLOWING.

Imagery.Hexagram:
Thunder in the middle of the lake:
The image of FOLLOWING.
Thus the superior man at nightfall
Goes indoors for rest and recuperation.
Such resting steels one’s energy for fresh action. Turning inward is suggested by the upper nuclear trigram Sun, which means going into, and rest by the lower nuclear trigram Kên, which means keeping still.

Lines.L1:
Nine at the beginning:
a) The standard is changing.
Perseverance brings good fortune.
To go out of the door in company
Produces deeds.
b) “The standard is changing.” To follow what is correct brings good fortune.
“To go out of the door in company produces deeds.”
One does not lose oneself.
Lines.L2:
Six in the second place:
a) If one clings to the little boy,
One loses the strong man.
b) “If one clings to the little boy”: one cannot be with both at once.
Lines.L3:
Six in the third place:
a) If one clings to the strong man,
One loses the little boy.
Through following one finds what one seeks.
It furthers one to remain persevering.
b) “If one clings to the strong man,” one’s will gives up the one below.
Lines.L4:
Nine in the fourth place:
a) Following creates success.
Perseverance brings misfortune.
To go one’s way with sincerity brings clarity.
How could there be blame in this?
b) “Following creates success”: this bodes misfortune.
“To go one’s way with sincerity”: this brings clear-sighted deeds.
Lines.L5:
Nine in the fifth place:
a) Sincere in the good. Good fortune.
b) “Sincere in the good. Good fortune.” The place is correct and central.
Lines.L6:
Six at the top:
a) He meets with firm allegiance
And is still further bound.
The king introduces him
To the Western Mountain.
b) “He meets with firm allegiance.” At the top it ends.

Exegesis.Miscellaneous: FOLLOWING tolerates no old prejudices.
Exegesis.Sequence: Where there is enthusiasm, there is certain to be following. Hence there follows the hexagram of FOLLOWING.
Exegesis.Extracts: The heroes of old tamed the ox and yoked the horse. Thus heavy loads could be transported and distant regions reached, for the benefit of the world. They probably took this from the hexagram of FOLLOWING.

Scripture.Hexagram: Sui indicates that (under its conditions) there will be great progress and success. But it will be advantageous to be firm and correct. There will (then) be no error.

Lines.L1: 1. The first NINE, undivided, shows us one changing the object of his pursuit; but if he be firm and correct, there will (be) good fortune. Going beyond (his own) gate to find associates, he will achieve merit.
Lines.L2: 2. The second SIX, divided, shows us one who cleaves to the little boy, and lets go the man of age and experience.
Lines.L3: 3. The third SIX, divided, shows us one who cleaves to the man of age and experience, and lets go the little boy. Such following will get what it seeks; but it will be advantageous to adhere to what is firm and correct.
Lines.L4: 4. The fourth NINE, undivided, shows us one followed and obtaining (adherents). Though he be firm and correct, there will be evil. If he be sincere (however) in his course, and make that evident, into what error will he fall?
Lines.L5: 5. The fifth NINE, undivided, shows us (the ruler) sincere in (fostering all) that is excellent. There will be good fortune.
Lines.L6: 6. The topmost SIX, divided, shows us (that sincerity) firmly held and clung to, yea, and bound fast. (We see) the king with it presenting his offerings on the western mountain.

Exegesis.Judgment:
XVII. 1. In Sui we see the strong (trigram) come and place itself under the weak; we see (in the two) the attributes of movement and pleasure:--this gives (the idea of) Sui.
2. 'There will be great progress and success; and through firm correctness no error:'--all under heaven will be found following at such a time.
3. Great indeed are the time and significance indicated in Sui.

Imagery.Hexagram: XVII. (The trigram for the waters of) a marsh and (that for) thunder (hidden) in the midst of it form Sui. The superior man in accordance with this, when it is getting towards dark, enters (his house) and rests.

Lines.L1: 1. 'He is changing the object of his pursuit:'--but if he follow what is correct, there will be good fortune. 'He goes beyond (his own) gate to find associates:'--he will not fail (in the method he pursues).
Lines.L2: 2. 'He cleaves to the little boy:'--he cannot be with the two at the same time.
Lines.L3: 3. 'He cleaves to the man of age and experience:'--by the decision of his will, he abandons (the youth) below.
Lines.L4: 4. 'He is followed and obtains adherents:'--according to the idea (of the hexagram), this is evil. 'He is sincere in his course:'--showing his intelligence, and leading to achievement.
Lines.L5: 5. 'He is sincere in fostering what is excellent:'--his position is correct and in the centre.
Lines.L6: 6. 'The sincerity is firmly held and clung to, as shown in the topmost line:'--(the idea of the hexagram) has reached its extreme development.

Exegesis.Miscellaneous: 17, 18. Sui quits the old; Kû makes a new decree.
Exegesis.Sequence: 16-19. Where such complacency is awakened, (he who causes it) is sure to have followers. They who follow another are sure to have services (to perform), and hence Sui is followed by Kû. Kû means (the performance of) services. He who performs such services may afterwards become great, and hence Kû is followed by Lin. Lin means great.

English.WilhelmBaynes: Ku / Work on What Has Been Spoiled [Decay]

Unicode.Name: Hexagram For Work On The Decayed

Scripture.Hexagram: 蠱：元亨，利涉大川。先甲三日，後甲三日。

Lines.L1: 初六：幹父之蠱，有子，考无咎，厲終吉。
Lines.L2: 九二：幹母之蠱，不可貞。
Lines.L3: 九三：幹父之蠱，小有悔，无大咎。
Lines.L4: 六四：裕父之蠱，往見吝。
Lines.L5: 六五：幹父之蠱，用譽。
Lines.L6: 上九：不事王侯，高尚其事。

Exegesis.Judgment: 蠱，剛上而柔下，巽而止，蠱。蠱，元亨，而天下治也。利涉大川，往有事也。先甲三日，後甲三日，終則有始，天行也。

Imagery.Hexagram: 山下有風，蠱；君子以振民育德。

Lines.L1: 幹父之蠱，意承考也。
Lines.L2: 幹母之蠱，得中道也。
Lines.L3: 幹父之蠱，終无咎也。
Lines.L4: 裕父之蠱，往未得也。
Lines.L5: 干父之蠱；承以德也。
Lines.L6: 不事王侯，志可則也。

Scripture.Hexagram: 蛊：元亨，利涉大川。先甲三日，后甲三日。

Lines.L1: 初六：干父之蛊，有子，考无咎，厉终吉。
Lines.L2: 九二：干母之蛊，不可贞。
Lines.L3: 九三：干父之蛊，小有悔，无大咎。
Lines.L4: 六四：裕父之蛊，往见吝。
Lines.L5: 六五：干父之蛊，用誉。
Lines.L6: 上九：不事王侯，高尚其事。

Exegesis.Judgment: 蛊，刚上而柔下，巽而止，蛊。蛊，元亨，而天下治也。利涉大川，往有事也。先甲三日，后甲三日，终则有始，天行也。

Imagery.Hexagram: 山下有风，蛊；君子以振民育德。

Lines.L1: 干父之蛊，意承考也。
Lines.L2: 干母之蛊，得中道也。
Lines.L3: 干父之蛊，终无咎也。
Lines.L4: 裕父之蛊，往未得也。
Lines.L5: 干父之蛊；承以德也。
Lines.L6: 不事王侯，志可则也。

Scripture.Hexagram:
WORK ON WHAT HAS BEEN SPOILED
Has supreme success.
It furthers one to cross the great water.
Before the starting point, three days.
After the starting point, three days.

Lines.L1:
Six at the beginning means:
Setting right what has been spoiled by the father.
If there is a son,
No blame rests upon the departed father.
Danger. In the end good fortune.
Lines.L2:
Nine in the second place means:
Setting right what has been spoiled by the mother.
One must not be too persevering.
Lines.L3:
Nine in the third place means:
Setting right what has been spoiled by the father.
There will be a little remorse. No great blame.
Lines.L4:
Six in the fourth place means:
Tolerating what has been spoiled by the father.
In continuing one sees humiliation.
Lines.L5:
Six in the fifth place means:
Setting right what has been spoiled by the father.
One meets with praise.
Lines.L6:
Nine at the top means:
He does not serve kings and princes,
Sets himself higher goals.

Exegesis.Judgment:
WORK ON WHAT HAS BEEN SPOILED. The firm is above and the yielding below; gentle and standing still—that which has been spoiled.
“WORK ON WHAT HAS BEEN SPOILED has supreme success,” and order comes into the world.
“It furthers one to cross the great water.” On going one will have things to do.
“Before the starting point, three days. After the starting point, three days.” That a new beginning follows every ending, is the course of heaven.

Imagery.Hexagram:
The wind blows low on the mountain:
The image of DECAY.
Thus the superior man stirs up the people
And strengthens their spirit.

Lines.L1:
Six at the beginning:
a) Setting right what has been spoiled by the father.
If there is a son,
No blame rests upon the departed father.
Danger. In the end good fortune.
b) “Setting right what has been spoiled by the father.”
He receives in his thoughts the deceased father.
Lines.L2:
Nine in the second place:
a) Setting right what has been spoiled by the mother.
One must not be too persevering.
b) “Setting right what has been spoiled by the mother.”
He finds the middle way.
Lines.L3:
Nine in the third place:
a) Setting right what has been spoiled by the father.
There will be a little remorse. No great blame.
b) “Setting right what has been spoiled by the father.”
In the end there is no blame.
Lines.L4:
Six in the fourth place:
a) Tolerating what has been spoiled by the father.
In continuing one sees humiliation.
b) “Tolerating what has been spoiled by the father.” He goes, but as yet finds nothing.
Lines.L5:
Six in the fifth place:
a) Setting right what has been spoiled by the father.
One meets with praise.
b) “Setting right what has been spoiled by the father.
One meets with praise.” He receives him in virtue.
Lines.L6:
Nine at the top:
a) He does not serve kings and princes,
Sets himself higher goals.
b) “He does not serve kings and princes.” Such an attitude may be taken as a model.

Exegesis.Miscellaneous: WORK ON WHAT HAS BEEN SPOILED. Afterward there is order.
Exegesis.Sequence: When one follows others with pleasure, there are certain to be undertakings. Hence there follows the hexagram of WORK ON WHAT HAS BEEN SPOILED. Work on what has been spoiled means undertakings.

Scripture.Hexagram: Kû indicates great progress and success (to him who deals properly with the condition represented by it). There will be advantage in (efforts like that of) crossing the great stream. (He should weigh well, however, the events of) three days before the turning point, and those (to be done) three days after it.

Lines.L1: 1. The first SIX, divided, shows (a son) dealing with the troubles caused by his father. If he be an (able) son, the father will escape the blame of having erred. The position is perilous, but there will be good fortune in the end.
Lines.L2: 2. The second NINE, undivided, shows (a son) dealing with the troubles caused by his mother. He should not (carry) his firm correctness (to the utmost).
Lines.L3: 3. The third NINE, undivided, shows (a son) dealing with the troubles caused by his father. There may be some small occasion for repentance, but there will not be any great error.
Lines.L4: 4. The fourth SIX, divided, shows (a son) viewing indulgently the troubles caused by his father. If he go forward, he will find cause to regret it.
Lines.L5: 5. The fifth SIX, divided, shows (a son) dealing with the troubles caused by his father. He obtains the praise of using (the fit instrument for his work).
Lines.L6: 6. The sixth NINE, undivided, shows us one who does not serve either king or feudal lord, but in a lofty spirit prefers (to attend to) his own affairs.

Exegesis.Judgment:
XVIII. 1. In Kû we have the strong (trigram) above, and the weak one below; we have (below) pliancy, and (above) stopping:--these give the idea of Kû (a Troublous Condition of affairs verging to ruin).
2. 'Kû indicates great progress and success:'--(through the course shown in it), all under heaven, there will be good order. 'There will be advantage in crossing the great stream:'--he who advances will encounter the business to be done. '(He shouldweigh well, however, the events of) three days before (the turning-point), and those (to be done) three days after it:'--the end (of confusion) is the beginning (of order); such is the procedure of Heaven.

Imagery.Hexagram: XVIII. (The trigram for) a mountain, and below it that for wind, form Kû. The superior man, in accordance with this, (addresses himself to) help the people and nourish his own virtue.

Lines.L1: 1. 'He deals with the troubles caused by his father:'--he feels that he has entered into the work of his father.
Lines.L2: 2. 'He deals with the troubles caused by his mother:'--he holds to the course of the due mean.
Lines.L3: 3. 'He deals with the troubles caused by his father:'--in the end there will be no error.
Lines.L4: 4. 'He views indulgently the troubles caused by his father:'--if he go forward, he will not succeed.
Lines.L5: 5. 'He deals with the troubles caused by his father, and obtains praise:'--he is responded to (by the subject of line two) with all his virtue.
Lines.L6: 6. 'He does not serve either king or feudal lord:'--but his aim may be a model (to others).

Exegesis.Miscellaneous: 17, 18. Sui quits the old; Kû makes a new decree.
Exegesis.Sequence: 16-19. Where such complacency is awakened, (he who causes it) is sure to have followers. They who follow another are sure to have services (to perform), and hence Sui is followed by Kû. Kû means (the performance of) services. He who performs such services may afterwards become great, and hence Kû is followed by Lin. Lin means great.

Scripture.Hexagram: 臨：元，亨，利，貞。至于八月有凶。

Lines.L1: 初九：咸臨，貞吉。
Lines.L2: 九二：咸臨，吉无不利。
Lines.L3: 六三：甘臨，无攸利。既憂之，无咎。
Lines.L4: 六四：至臨，无咎。
Lines.L5: 六五：知臨，大君之宜，吉。
Lines.L6: 上六：敦臨，吉无咎。

Exegesis.Judgment: 臨，剛浸而長。說而順，剛中而應，大亨以正，天之道也。至于八月有凶，消不久也。

Imagery.Hexagram: 澤上有地，臨；君子以教思无窮，容保民无疆。

Lines.L1: 咸臨貞吉，志行正也。
Lines.L2: 咸臨，吉无不利；未順命也。
Lines.L3: 甘臨，位不當也。既憂之，咎不長也。
Lines.L4: 至臨无咎，位當也。
Lines.L5: 大君之宜，行中之謂也。
Lines.L6: 敦臨之吉，志在內也。

Scripture.Hexagram: 临：元，亨，利，贞。至于八月有凶。

Lines.L1: 初九：咸临，贞吉。
Lines.L2: 九二：咸临，吉无不利。
Lines.L3: 六三：甘临，无攸利。既忧之，无咎。
Lines.L4: 六四：至临，无咎。
Lines.L5: 六五：知临，大君之宜，吉。
Lines.L6: 上六：敦临，吉无咎。

Exegesis.Judgment: 临，刚浸而长。说而顺，刚中而应，大亨以正，天之道也。至于八月有凶，消不久也。

Imagery.Hexagram: 泽上有地，临；君子以教思无穷，容保民无疆。

Lines.L1: 咸临贞吉，志行正也。
Lines.L2: 咸临，吉无不利；未顺命也。
Lines.L3: 甘临，位不当也。既忧之，咎不长也。
Lines.L4: 至临无咎，位当也。
Lines.L5: 大君之宜，行中之谓也。
Lines.L6: 敦临之吉，志在内也。

Scripture.Hexagram:
APPPROACH has supreme success.
Perseverance furthers.
When the eighth month comes,
There will be misfortune.

Lines.L1:
Nine at the beginning means:
Joint approach.
Perseverance brings good fortune.
Lines.L2:
Nine in the second place means:
Joint approach.
Good fortune.
Everything furthers.
Lines.L3:
Six in the third place means:
Comfortable approach.
Nothing that would further.
If one is induced to grieve over it,
One becomes free of blame.
Lines.L4:
Six in the fourth place means:
Complete approach.
No blame.
Lines.L5:
Six in the fifth place means:
Wise approach.
This is right for a great prince.
Good fortune.
Lines.L6:
Six at the top means:
Greathearted approach.
Good fortune. No blame.

Exegesis.Judgment:
APPROACH. The firm penetrates and grows.
Joyous and devoted. The firm is in the middle and finds correspondence. “Great success through correctness”: this is the course of heaven.
“When the eighth month comes, there will be misfortune.” Recession is not slow in coming.
b) The name of the hexagram is explained through its structure. The firm element that penetrates and grows are the two yang lines. Joyousness and devotion are the attributes of the two trigrams. The firm element in the middle that finds correspondence is the nine in the second place. It is taken as the basis for the explanation of the words of the hexagram. The eighth month is suggested in the fact that the next hexagram, Kuan (CONTEMPLATION, VIEW), in which the retreat of the strong lines parallels their advance here, comes exactly eight months after this hexagram in the cycle of the year.

Imagery.Hexagram:
The earth above the lake:
The image of APPROACH.
Thus the superior man is inexhaustible
In his will to teach,
And without limits
In his tolerance and protection of the people.

Lines.L1:
Nine at the beginning:
a) Joint approach.
Perseverance brings good fortune.
b) “Joint approach. Perseverance brings good fortune.”
His will is to act correctly.
Lines.L2:
Nine in the second place:
a) Joint approach.
Good fortune.
Everything furthers.
b) “Joint approach. Good fortune. Everything furthers.”
One need not yield to fate.
Lines.L3:
Six in the third place:
a) Comfortable approach.
Nothing that would further.
If one is induced to grieve over it,
One becomes free of blame.
b) “Comfortable approach.” The place is not the appropriate one. A fault that induces grief no longer exists.
Lines.L4:
Six in the fourth place:
a) Complete approach.
No blame.
b) “Complete approach. No blame,” for the place is the appropriate one.
Lines.L5:
Six in the fifth place:
a) Wise approach.
This is right for a great prince.
Good fortune.
b) What is right for a great prince—this means that he should walk in the middle.
Lines.L6:
Six at the top:
a) Greathearted approach.
Good fortune. No blame.
b) “Greathearted approach.” The will is directed inward.

Exegesis.Miscellaneous: The meaning of the hexagrams of APPROACH and CONTEMPLATION is that they partly give and partly take.
Exegesis.Sequence: When there are things to do, one can become great. Hence there follows the hexagram of APPROACH. Approach means becoming great.

Scripture.Hexagram: Lin indicates that under the conditions supposed in it there will be great progress and success, while it will be advantageous to be firmly correct. In the eighth month there will be evil.

Lines.L1: 1. The first NINE, undivided, shows its subject advancing in company (with the subject of the second line). Through his firm correctness there will be good fortune.
Lines.L2: 2. The second NINE, undivided, shows its subject advancing in company (with the subject of the first line). There will be good fortune; advancing will be in every way advantageous.
Lines.L3: 3. The third SIX, divided, shows one well pleased (indeed) to advance, (but whose action) will be in no way advantageous. If he become anxious about it (however), there will be no error.
Lines.L4: 4. The fourth SIX, divided, shows one advancing in the highest mode. There will be no error.
Lines.L5: 5. The fifth SIX, divided, shows the advance of wisdom, such as befits the great ruler. There will be good fortune.
Lines.L6: 6. The sixth SIX, divided, shows the advance of honesty and generosity. There will be good fortune, and no error.

Exegesis.Judgment:
XIX. 1. In Lin (we see) the strong (lines) gradually increasing and advancing.
2. (The lower trigram is the symbol of) being pleased, and (the upper of) being compliant. The strong (line) is in the central position, and is properly responded to.
3. 'There is great progress and success, along with firm correctness:'--this is the way of Heaven.
4. 'In the eighth month there will be evil:'--(the advancing power) will decay after no long time.

Imagery.Hexagram: XIX. (The trigram for) the waters of a marsh and that for the earth above it form Lin. The superior man, in accordance with this, has his purposes of instruction that are inexhaustible, and nourishes and supports the people without limit.

Lines.L1: 1. 'The good fortune through the firm correctness of (the subject of the first line) advancing in company (with the subject of the second)' is due to his will being set on doing what is right.
Lines.L2: 2. 'The good fortune and every possible advantage attending the advance (of the subject of the second line), in company (with the subject of the first),' arises from the fact that those (to whom the advance is made) are not yet obedient to the ordinances (of Heaven).
Lines.L3: 3. 'He (shows himself) well pleased to advance:'--his position is not that appropriate to him. 'If he become anxious, however, about his action,' his error will not be continued.
Lines.L4: 4. 'The freedom from error consequent on theadvance in the highest mode' is due to the (various) appropriateness of the position.
Lines.L5: 5. 'What befits the great ruler' means the pursuing the course of the due mean.
Lines.L6: 6. 'The good fortune consequent on the advance of honesty and generosity' is due to the will (of the subject of the line) being set on the subjects of (the first two lines of) the inner (trigram).

Exegesis.Miscellaneous:
19, 20. Lin gives, Kwân seeks;--such are the several themes
Their different figures were to teach designed.
Exegesis.Sequence:
16-19. Where such complacency is awakened, (he who causes it) is sure to have followers. They who follow another are sure to have services (to perform), and hence Sui is followed by Kû. Kû means (the performance of) services. He who performs such services may afterwards become great, and hence Kû is followed by Lin. Lin means great.
19-23. What is great draws forth contemplation, and hence Lin is followed by Kwân. He who attracts contemplation will then bring about the union of others with himself, and hence Kwân is followed by Shih Ho. Shih Ho means union. But things should not be united in a reckless or irregular way, and hence Shih Ho is followed by Pî. Pî denotes adorning. When ornamentation has been carried to the utmost, its progress comes to an end; and hence Pî is followed by Po. Po denotes decay and overthrow.

Scripture.Hexagram: 觀：盥而不薦，有孚顒若。

Lines.L1: 初六：童觀，小人无咎，君子吝。
Lines.L2: 六二：闚觀，利女貞。
Lines.L3: 六三：觀我生，進退。
Lines.L4: 六四：觀國之光，利用賓于王。
Lines.L5: 九五：觀我生，君子无咎。
Lines.L6: 上九：觀其生，君子无咎。

Exegesis.Judgment: 大觀在上，順而巽，中正以觀天下。觀，盥而不薦，有孚顒若，下觀而化也。觀天之神道，而四時不忒，聖人以神道設教，而天下服矣。

Imagery.Hexagram: 風行地上，觀；先王以省方，觀民設教。

Lines.L1: 初六童觀，小人道也。
Lines.L2: 窺觀女貞，亦可醜也。
Lines.L3: 觀我生，進退；未失道也。
Lines.L4: 觀國之光，尚賓也。
Lines.L5: 觀我生，觀民也。
Lines.L6: 觀其生，志未平也。

Scripture.Hexagram: 观：盥而不荐，有孚顒若。

Lines.L1: 初六：童观，小人无咎，君子吝。
Lines.L2: 六二：闚观，利女贞。
Lines.L3: 六三：观我生，进退。
Lines.L4: 六四：观国之光，利用宾于王。
Lines.L5: 九五：观我生，君子无咎。
Lines.L6: 上九：观其生，君子无咎。

Exegesis.Judgment: 大观在上，顺而巽，中正以观天下。观，盥而不荐，有孚顒若，下观而化也。观天之神道，而四时不忒，圣人以神道设教，而天下服矣。

Imagery.Hexagram: 风行地上，观；先王以省方，观民设教。

Lines.L1: 初六童观，小人道也。
Lines.L2: 窥观女贞，亦可丑也。
Lines.L3: 观我生，进退；未失道也。
Lines.L4: 观国之光，尚宾也。
Lines.L5: 观我生，观民也。
Lines.L6: 观其生，志未平也。

Scripture.Hexagram:
CONTEMPLATION. The ablution has been made,
But not yet the offering.
Full of trust they look up to him.

Lines.L1:
Six at the beginning means:
Boylike contemplation.
For an inferior man, no blame.
For a superior man, humiliation.
Lines.L2:
Six in the second place means:
Contemplation through the crack of the door.
Furthering for the perseverance of a woman.
Lines.L3:
Six in the third place means:
Contemplation of my life
Decides the choice
Between advance and retreat.
Lines.L4:
Six in the fourth place means:
Contemplation of the light of the kingdom.
It furthers one to exert influence as the guest of a king.
Lines.L5:
Nine in the fifth place means:
Contemplation of my life.
The superior man is without blame.
Lines.L6:
Nine at the top means:
Contemplation of his life.
The superior man is without blame.

Exegesis.Judgment:
A great view is above. Devoted and gentle. Central and correct, he is something for the world to view.
“Contemplation. The ablution has been made, but not yet the offering. Full of trust they look up to him.”
Those below look toward him and are transformed. He affords them a view of the divine way of heaven, and the four seasons do not deviate from their rule. Thus the holy man uses the divine way to give instruction, and the whole world submits to him.

Imagery.Hexagram:
The wind blows over the earth:
The image of CONTEMPLATION.
Thus the kings of old visited the regions of the world,
Contemplated the people,
And gave them instruction.

Lines.L1:
Six at the beginning:
a) Boylike contemplation.
For an inferior man, no blame.
For a superior man, humiliation.
b) The boylike contemplation of the six at the beginning is the way of inferior people.
Lines.L2:
Six in the second place:
a) Contemplation through the crack of the door.
Furthering for the perseverance of a woman.
b) “Contemplation through the crack of the door” is humiliating even where there is the perseverance of a woman.
Lines.L3:
Six in the third place:
a) Contemplation of my life
Decides the choice
Between advance and retreat.
b) “Contemplation of my life decides the choice between advance and retreat.” The right way is not lost.
Lines.L4:
Six in the fourth place:
a) Contemplation of the light of the kingdom.
It furthers one to exert influence as the guest of a king.
b) “Contemplation of the light of the kingdom.” One is honored as a guest.
Lines.L5:
Nine in the fifth place:
a) Contemplation of my life.
The superior man is without blame.
b) “Contemplation of my life,” that is, contemplation of the people.
Lines.L6:
Nine at the top:
a) Contemplation of his life.
The superior man is without blame.
b) “Contemplation of his life.” The will is not yet pacified.

Exegesis.Miscellaneous: The meaning of the hexagrams of APPROACH and CONTEMPLATION is that they partly give and partly take.
Exegesis.Sequence: When things are great, one can contemplate them. Hence there follows the hexagram of CONTEMPLATION.

Scripture.Hexagram: Kwân shows (how he whom it represents should be like) the worshipper who has washed his hands, but not (yet) presented his offerings;--with sincerity and an appearance of dignity (commanding reverent regard).

Lines.L1: 1. The first SIX, divided, shows the looking of a lad;--not blamable in men of inferior rank, but matter for regret in superior men.
Lines.L2: 2. The second SIX, divided, shows one peeping out from a door. It would be advantageous if it were (merely) the firm correctness of a female.
Lines.L3: 3. The third SIX, divided, shows one looking at (the course of) his own life, to advance or recede (accordingly).
Lines.L4: 4. The fourth SIX, divided, shows one contemplating the glory of the kingdom. It will be advantageous for him, being such as he is, (to seek) to be a guest of the king.
Lines.L5: 5. The fifth NINE, undivided, shows its subject contemplating his own life(-course). A superior man, he will (thus) fall into no error.
