Lines.L6: 6. The sixth NINE, undivided, shows its subject contemplating his character to see if it be indeed that of a superior man. He will not fall into error.

Exegesis.Judgment:
XX. 1. The great Manifester occupies an upper place (in the figure), which consists of (the trigramswhose attributes are) docility and flexibility. He is in the central position and his correct place, and thus exhibits (his lessons) to all under heaven.
2. 'Kwan shows its subject like a worshipper who has washed his hands, but not (yet) presented his offerings;--with sincerity and an appearance of dignity (commanding reverent regard):'--(all) beneath look to him and are transformed.
3. When we contemplate the spirit-like way of Heaven, we see how the four seasons proceed without error. The sages, in accordance with (this) spirit-like way, laid down their instructions, and all under heaven yield submission to them.

Imagery.Hexagram: XX. (The trigram representing) the earth, and that for wind moving above it, form Kwan. The ancient kings, in accordance with this, examined the (different) regions (of the kingdom), to see the (ways of the) people, and set forth their instructions.

Lines.L1: 1. 'The looking of a lad shown by the first six, (divided); indicates the way of the inferior people.
Lines.L2: 2. 'The firm correctness of a woman, in peeping out from a door' is also a thing to be ashamed of (in a superior man).
Lines.L3: 3. 'He looks at (the course of his own life, to advance or recede (accordingly):'--he will not err in the path (to be pursued).
Lines.L4: 4. 'He contemplates the glory of the kingdom:'(thence) arises the wish to be a guest (at court).
Lines.L5: 5. 'He contemplates his own life(-course):'--he should (for this purpose) contemplate (the condition of) the people.
Lines.L6: 6. 'He contemplates his own character:'--he cannot even yet let his mind be at rest.

Exegesis.Miscellaneous:
19, 20. Lin gives, Kwân seeks;--such are the several themes
Their different figures were to teach designed.
Exegesis.Sequence: 19-23. What is great draws forth contemplation, and hence Lin is followed by Kwân. He who attracts contemplation will then bring about the union of others with himself, and hence Kwân is followed by Shih Ho. Shih Ho means union. But things should not be united in a reckless or irregular way, and hence Shih Ho is followed by Pî. Pî denotes adorning. When ornamentation has been carried to the utmost, its progress comes to an end; and hence Pî is followed by Po. Po denotes decay and overthrow.

Scripture.Hexagram: 噬嗑：亨。利用獄。

Lines.L1: 初九：屨校滅趾，无咎。
Lines.L2: 六二：噬膚滅鼻，无咎。
Lines.L3: 六三：噬臘肉，遇毒；小吝，无咎。
Lines.L4: 九四：噬乾胏，得金矢，利艱貞，吉。
Lines.L5: 六五：噬乾肉，得黃金，貞厲，无咎。
Lines.L6: 上九：何校滅耳，凶。

Exegesis.Judgment: 頤中有物，曰噬嗑，噬嗑而亨。剛柔分，動而明，雷電合而章。柔得中而上行，雖不當位，利用獄也。

Imagery.Hexagram: 雷電噬嗑；先王以明罰敕法。

Lines.L1: 屨校滅趾，不行也。
Lines.L2: 噬膚滅鼻，乘剛也。
Lines.L3: 遇毒，位不當也。
Lines.L4: 利艱貞吉，未光也。
Lines.L5: 貞厲无咎，得當也。
Lines.L6: 何校滅耳，聰不明也。

Scripture.Hexagram: 噬嗑：亨。利用狱。

Lines.L1: 初九：屦校灭趾，无咎。
Lines.L2: 六二：噬肤灭鼻，无咎。
Lines.L3: 六三：噬腊肉，遇毒；小吝，无咎。
Lines.L4: 九四：噬乾胏，得金矢，利艰贞，吉。
Lines.L5: 六五：噬乾肉，得黄金，贞厉，无咎。
Lines.L6: 上九：何校灭耳，凶。

Exegesis.Judgment: 颐中有物，曰噬嗑，噬嗑而亨。刚柔分，动而明，雷电合而章。柔得中而上行，虽不当位，利用狱也。

Imagery.Hexagram: 雷电噬嗑；先王以明罚敕法。

Lines.L1: 屦校灭趾，不行也。
Lines.L2: 噬肤灭鼻，乘刚也。
Lines.L3: 遇毒，位不当也。
Lines.L4: 利艰贞吉，未光也。
Lines.L5: 贞厉无咎，得当也。
Lines.L6: 何校灭耳，聪不明也。

Scripture.Hexagram:
BITING THROUGH has success.
It is favorable to let justice be administered.

Lines.L1:
Nine at the beginning means:
His feet are fastened in the stocks,
So that his toes disappear.
No blame.
Lines.L2:
Six in the second place means:
Bites through tender meat,
So that his nose disappears.
No blame.
Lines.L3:
Six in the third place means:
Bites on old dried meat
And strikes on something poisonous.
Slight humiliation. No blame.
Lines.L4:
Nine in the fourth place means:
Bites on dried gristly meat.
Receives metal arrows.
It furthers one to be mindful of difficulties
And to be persevering.
Good fortune.
Lines.L5:
Six in the fifth place means:
Bites on dried lean meat.
Receives yellow gold.
Perseveringly aware of danger.
No blame.
Lines.L6:
Nine at the top means:
His neck is fastened in the wooden cangue,
So that his ears disappear.
Misfortune.

Exegesis.Judgment:
There is something between the corners of the mouth. This is called BITING THROUGH.
“BITING THROUGH, and moreover, success.” For firm and yielding are distinct from each other.
Movement and clarity. Thunder and lightning are united and form lines. The yielding receives the place of honor and goes upward.
Although it is not in the appropriate place, it is favorable to let justice be administered.

Imagery.Hexagram:
Thunder and lightning:
The image of BITING THROUGH.
Thus the kings of former times made firm the laws
Through clearly defined penalties.

Lines.L1:
Nine at the beginning:
a) His feet are fastened in the stocks
So that his toes disappear.
No blame.
b) “His feet are fastened in the stocks, so that his toes disappear. No blame.” He cannot walk.
Lines.L2:
Six in the second place:
a) Bites through tender meat,
So that his nose disappears.
No blame.
b) “Bites through tender meat, so that his nose disappears.” He rests upon a hard line.
Lines.L3:
Six in the third place:
a) Bites on old dried meat
And strikes on something poisonous.
Slight humiliation. No blame.
b) “Strikes on something poisonous.” The place is not the appropriate one.
Lines.L4:
Nine in the fourth place:
a) Bites on dried gristly meat.
Receives metal arrows.
It furthers one to be mindful of difficulties
And to be persevering.
Good fortune.
b) “It furthers one to be mindful of difficulties and to be persevering. Good fortune.” He does not yet give light.
Lines.L5:
Six in the fifth place:
a) Bites on dried lean meat.
Receives yellow gold.
Perseveringly aware of danger.
No blame.
b) “Perseveringly aware of danger. No blame.” He has found what is appropriate.
Lines.L6:
Nine at the top:
a) His neck is fastened in the wooden cangue,
So that his ears disappear.
Misfortune.
b) “His neck is fastened in the wooden cangue, so that his ears disappear.” He does not hear clearly.

Exegesis.Miscellaneous: BITING THROUGH means consuming.
Exegesis.Sequence: When there is something that can be contemplated, there is something that creates union. Hence there follows the hexagram of BITING THROUGH. Biting through means union.
Exegesis.Extracts: When the sun stood at midday, the Divine Husbandman held a market. He caused the people of the earth to come together and collected the wares of the earth. They exchanged these with one another, then returned home, and each thing found its place. Probably he took this from the hexagram of BITING THROUGH.

Scripture.Hexagram: Shih Ho indicates successful progress (in the condition of things which it supposes). It will be advantageous to use legal constraints.

Lines.L1: 1. The first NINE, undivided, shows one with his feet in the stocks and deprived of his toes. There will be no error.
Lines.L2: 2. The second SIX, divided, shows one biting through the soft flesh, and (going on to) bite off the nose. There will be no error.
Lines.L3: 3. The third SIX, divided, shows one gnawing dried flesh, and meeting with what is disagreeable. There will be occasion for some small regret, but no (great) error.
Lines.L4: 4. The fourth NINE, undivided, shows one gnawing the flesh dried on the bone, and getting the pledges of money and arrows. It will be advantageous to him to realise the difficulty of his task and be firm,--in which case there will be good fortune.
Lines.L5: 5. The fifth SIX, divided, shows one gnawing at dried flesh, and finding the yellow gold. Let him be firm and correct, realising the peril (of his position). There will be no error.
Lines.L6: 6. The sixth NINE, undivided, shows one wearing the cangue, and deprived of his ears. There will be evil.

Exegesis.Judgment:
XXI. 1. The existence of something between the jaws gives rise to the name Shih Ho (Union by means of biting through the intervening article).
2. The Union by means of biting through the intervening article indicates 'the successful progress (denoted by the hexagram).'The strong and weak (lines) are equally divided (in the figure). Movement is denoted (by the lower trigram), and bright intelligence (by the upper); thunder and lightning uniting in them, and having brilliant manifestation. The weak (fifth) line is inthe centre, and acts in its high position. Although it is not in its proper position, this is advantageous for the use of legal constraints.

Imagery.Hexagram: XXI. (The trigrams representing) thunder and lightning form Shih Ho. The ancient kings, in accordance with this, framed their penalties with intelligence, and promulgated their laws.

Lines.L1: 1. 'His feet are in the stocks, and he is deprived of his toes:'--there is no walking (to do evil).
Lines.L2: 2. 'He bites through the soft flesh, and (goes on)to bite off the nose:'--(the subject of the line) is mounted on the strong (first line).
Lines.L3: 3. 'He meets with what is disagreeable and hurtful:'--his position is not the proper one for him.
Lines.L4: 4. 'It will be advantageous to him to realise the difficulty of his task and be firm, in which case there will be good fortune:'--his light has not yet been sufficiently displayed.
Lines.L5: 5. 'Let him be firm and correct, realising the peril (of his position), and there will be no error:'--he will possess every quality appropriate (to his position and task).
Lines.L6: 6. 'He wears the cangue and is deprived of his ears:'--he hears, but will not understand.

Exegesis.Miscellaneous:
21, 22. Shih Ho takes eating for its theme; and Pî
Takes what is plain, from ornament quite free.
Exegesis.Sequence: 19-23. What is great draws forth contemplation, and hence Lin is followed by Kwân. He who attracts contemplation will then bring about the union of others with himself, and hence Kwân is followed by Shih Ho. Shih Ho means union. But things should not be united in a reckless or irregular way, and hence Shih Ho is followed by Pî. Pî denotes adorning. When ornamentation has been carried to the utmost, its progress comes to an end; and hence Pî is followed by Po. Po denotes decay and overthrow.

Scripture.Hexagram: 賁：亨。小利有攸往。

Lines.L1: 初九：賁其趾，舍車而徒。
Lines.L2: 六二：賁其須。
Lines.L3: 九三：賁如濡如，永貞吉。
Lines.L4: 六四：賁如皤如，白馬翰如，匪寇婚媾。
Lines.L5: 六五：賁于丘園，束帛戔戔，吝，終吉。
Lines.L6: 上九：白賁，无咎。

Exegesis.Judgment: 賁，亨；柔來而文剛，故亨。分剛上而文柔，故小利有攸往。天文也；文明以止，人文也。觀乎天文，以察時變；觀乎人文，以化成天下。

Imagery.Hexagram: 山下有火，賁；君子以明庶政，无敢折獄。

Lines.L1: 舍車而徒，義弗乘也。
Lines.L2: 賁其須，與上興也。
Lines.L3: 永貞之吉，終莫之陵也。
Lines.L4: 六四，當位疑也。匪寇婚媾，終无尤也。
Lines.L5: 六五之吉，有喜也。
Lines.L6: 白賁无咎，上得志也。

Scripture.Hexagram: 贲：亨。小利有攸往。

Lines.L1: 初九：贲其趾，舍车而徒。
Lines.L2: 六二：贲其须。
Lines.L3: 九三：贲如濡如，永贞吉。
Lines.L4: 六四：贲如皤如，白马翰如，匪寇婚媾。
Lines.L5: 六五：贲于丘园，束帛戋戋，吝，终吉。
Lines.L6: 上九：白贲，无咎。

Exegesis.Judgment: 贲，亨；柔来而文刚，故亨。分刚上而文柔，故小利有攸往。天文也；文明以止，人文也。观乎天文，以察时变；观乎人文，以化成天下。

Imagery.Hexagram: 山下有火，贲；君子以明庶政，无敢折狱。

Lines.L1: 舍车而徒，义弗乘也。
Lines.L2: 贲其须，与上兴也。
Lines.L3: 永贞之吉，终莫之陵也。
Lines.L4: 六四，当位疑也。匪寇婚媾，终无尤也。
Lines.L5: 六五之吉，有喜也。
Lines.L6: 白贲无咎，上得志也。

Scripture.Hexagram:
GRACE has success.
In small matters
It is favorable to undertake something.

Lines.L1:
Nine at the beginning means:
He lends grace to his toes, leaves the carriage, and walks.
Lines.L2:
Six in the second place means:
Lends grace to the beard on his chin.
Lines.L3:
Nine in the third place means:
Graceful and moist.
Constant perseverance brings good fortune.
Lines.L4:
Six in the fourth place means:
Grace or simplicity?
A white horse comes as if on wings.
He is not a robber,
He will woo at the right time.
Lines.L5:
Six in the fifth place means:
Grace in hills and gardens.
The roll of silk is meager and small.
Humiliation, but in the end good fortune.
Lines.L6:
Nine at the top means:
Simple grace. No blame.

Exegesis.Judgment: “GRACE has success.” The yielding comes and gives form to the firm; therefore, “Success.” A detached firm line ascends and gives form to the yielding; therefore, “In small matters it is favorable to undertake something.” This is the form of heaven. Having form, clear and still: this is the form of men. If the form of heaven is contemplated, the changes of time can be discovered. If the forms of men are contemplated, one can shape the world.

Imagery.Hexagram:
Fire at the foot of the mountain:
The image of GRACE.
Thus does the superior man proceed
When clearing up current affairs.
But he dare not decide controversial issues in this way.

Lines.L1:
Nine at the beginning:
a) He lends grace to his toes, leaves the carriage, and walks.
b) “He leaves the carriage and walks,” for it accords with duty not to ride.
Lines.L2:
Six in the second place:
a) Lends grace to the beard on his chin.
b) “Lends grace to the beard on his chin”: that is, he ascends with the one above.
Lines.L3:
Nine in the third place:
a) Graceful and moist.
Constant perseverance brings good fortune.
b) The good fortune of constant perseverance cannot, in the end, be put to shame.
Lines.L4:
Six in the fourth place:
a) Grace or simplicity?
A white horse comes as if on wings.
He is not a robber,
He will woo at the right time.
b) The six in the fourth place is in doubt; this accords with its place.
“He is not a robber, he will woo at the right time.”
In the end, one remains free of blame.
Lines.L5:
Six in the fifth place:
a) Grace in hills and gardens.
The roll of silk is meager and small.
Humiliation, but in the end good fortune.
b) The good fortune of the six in the fifth place has joy.
Lines.L6:
Nine at the top:
a) Simple grace. No blame.
b) “Simple grace. No blame.” The one above attains his will.

Exegesis.Miscellaneous: GRACE means being undyed.
Exegesis.Sequence: Things should not unite abruptly and ruthlessly; hence there follows the hexagram of GRACE. Grace is the same as adornment.

Scripture.Hexagram: Pî indicates that there should be free course (in what it denotes). There will be little advantage (however) if it be allowed to advance (and take the lead).

Lines.L1: 1. The first NINE, undivided, shows one adorning (the way of) his feet. He can discard a carriage and walk on foot.
Lines.L2: 2. The second SIX, divided, shows one adorning his beard.
Lines.L3: 3. The third NINE, undivided, shows its subject with the appearance of being adorned and bedewed (with rich favours). But let him ever maintain his firm correctness, and there will be good fortune.
Lines.L4: 4. The fourth SIX, divided, shows one looking as if adorned, but only in white. As if (mounted on) a white horse, and furnished with wings, (he seeks union with the subject of the first line), while (the intervening third pursues), not as a robber, but intent on a matrimonial alliance.
Lines.L5: 5. The fifth SIX, divided, shows its subject adorned by (the occupants of) the heights and gardens. He bears his roll of silk, small and slight. He may appear stingy; but there will be good fortune in the end.
Lines.L6: 6. The sixth NINE, undivided, shows one with white as his (only) ornament. There will be no error.

Exegesis.Judgment:
XXII. 1. (When it is said that) Pî indicates that there should be free course (in what it denotes):--
2. (We see) the weak line coming and ornamenting the strong lines (of the lower trigram), and hence (it is said that ornament) 'should have free course.' On the other hand, the strong line above ornaments the weak ones (of the upper trigram), and hence (it is said) that 'there will be little advantage, if (ornament) be allowed to advance (and take the lead).' (This is illustrated in the) appearances that ornament the sky.
3. Elegance and intelligence (denoted by the lower trigram) regulated by the arrest (denoted by the upper) suggest the observances that adorn human (society).
4. We look at the ornamental figures of the sky, and thereby ascertain the changes of the seasons. We look at the ornamental observances of society, and understand how the processes of transformation are accomplished all under heaven.

Imagery.Hexagram: XXII. (The trigram representing) a mountain and that for fire under it form Pî. The superior man, in accordance with this, throws a brilliancy around his various processes of government, but does not dare (in a similar way) to decide cases of criminal litigation.

Lines.L1: 1. 'He can discard a carriage and walk on foot:'--righteousness requires that he should not ride.
Lines.L2: 2. 'He adorns his beard:'--he rouses himself to action (only) along with the (subject of the) line above.
Lines.L3: 3. 'The good fortune consequent on his ever maintaining firm correctness' is due to this,--that to the end no one will insult him.
Lines.L4: 4. 'The place occupied by the fourth six, (divided),' affords ground for doubt (as to its subject); but '(as the subject of the third pursues) not as a robber, but as intent on a matrimonial alliance,' he will in the end have no grudge against him.
Lines.L5: 5. 'The good fortune falling to the fifth six, (divided); affords occasion for joy.
Lines.L6: 6. 'The freedom from error attached to (the subject of) the topmost line, with no ornament but the (simple white),' shows how he has attained his aim.

Exegesis.Miscellaneous:
21, 22. Shih Ho takes eating for its theme; and Pî
Takes what is plain, from ornament quite free.
Exegesis.Sequence: 19-23. What is great draws forth contemplation, and hence Lin is followed by Kwân. He who attracts contemplation will then bring about the union of others with himself, and hence Kwân is followed by Shih Ho. Shih Ho means union. But things should not be united in a reckless or irregular way, and hence Shih Ho is followed by Pî. Pî denotes adorning. When ornamentation has been carried to the utmost, its progress comes to an end; and hence Pî is followed by Po. Po denotes decay and overthrow.

Scripture.Hexagram: 剝：不利有攸往。

Lines.L1: 初六：剝床以足，蔑貞凶。
Lines.L2: 六二：剝床以辨，蔑貞凶。
Lines.L3: 六三：剝之，无咎。
Lines.L4: 六四：剝床以膚，凶。
Lines.L5: 六五：貫魚，以宮人寵，无不利。
Lines.L6: 上九：碩果不食，君子得輿，小人剝廬。

Exegesis.Judgment: 剝，剝也，柔變剛也。不利有攸往，小人長也。順而止之，觀象也。君子尚消息盈虛，天行也。

Imagery.Hexagram: 山附地上，剝；上以厚下，安宅。

Lines.L1: 剝床以足，以滅下也。
Lines.L2: 剝床以辨，未有與也。
Lines.L3: 剝之无咎，失上下也。
Lines.L4: 剝床以膚，切近災也。
Lines.L5: 以宮人寵，終无尤也。
Lines.L6: 君子得輿，民所載也。小人剝廬，終不可用也。

Scripture.Hexagram: 剥：不利有攸往。

Lines.L1: 初六：剥床以足，蔑贞凶。
Lines.L2: 六二：剥床以辨，蔑贞凶。
Lines.L3: 六三：剥之，无咎。
Lines.L4: 六四：剥床以肤，凶。
Lines.L5: 六五：贯鱼，以宫人宠，无不利。
Lines.L6: 上九：硕果不食，君子得舆，小人剥庐。

Exegesis.Judgment: 剥，剥也，柔变刚也。不利有攸往，小人长也。顺而止之，观象也。君子尚消息盈虚，天行也。

Imagery.Hexagram: 山附地上，剥；上以厚下，安宅。

Lines.L1: 剥床以足，以灭下也。
Lines.L2: 剥床以辨，未有与也。
Lines.L3: 剥之无咎，失上下也。
Lines.L4: 剥床以肤，切近灾也。
Lines.L5: 以宫人宠，终无尤也。
Lines.L6: 君子得舆，民所载也。小人剥庐，终不可用也。

Scripture.Hexagram:
SPLITTING APART. It does not further one
To go anywhere.

Lines.L1:
Six at the beginning means:
The leg of the bed is split.
Those who persevere are destroyed.
Misfortune.
Lines.L2:
Six in the second place means:
The bed is split at the edge.
Those who persevere are destroyed.
Misfortune.
Lines.L3:
Six in the third place means:
He splits with them. No blame.
Lines.L4:
Six in the fourth place means:
The bed is split up to the skin.
Misfortune.
Lines.L5:
Six in the fifth place means:
A shoal of fishes. Favor comes through the court ladies.
Everything acts to further.
Lines.L6:
Nine at the top means:
There is a large fruit still uneaten.
The superior man receives a carriage.
The house of the inferior man is split apart.

Exegesis.Judgment:
SPLITTING APART means ruin. The yielding changes the firm.
“It does not further one to go anywhere.” Inferior people increase.
Devotion and keeping still result from contemplating the image. The superior man takes heed of the alternation of increase and decrease, fullness and emptiness; for it is the course of heaven.

Imagery.Hexagram:
The mountain rests on the earth:
The image of SPLITTING APART.
Thus those above can ensure their position
Only by giving generously to those below.

Lines.L1:
Six at the beginning:
a) The leg of the bed is split.
Those who persevere are destroyed.
Misfortune.
b) “The leg of the bed is split,” in order to destroy those below.
Lines.L2:
Six in the second place:
a) The bed is split at the edge.
Those who persevere are destroyed.
Misfortune.
b) “The bed is split at the edge,” because one has no comrade.
Lines.L3:
Six in the third place:
a) He splits with them. No blame.
b) “He splits with them. No blame.” He loses the neighbor above and the one below.
Lines.L4:
Six in the fourth place:
a) The bed is split up to the skin.
Misfortune.
b) “The bed is split up to the skin. Misfortune.” This is a serious and immediate misfortune.
Lines.L5:
Six in the fifth place:
a) A shoal of fishes. Favor comes through the court ladies.
Everything acts to further.
b) “Favor comes through the court ladies.” In the end this is not a mistake.
Lines.L6:
Nine at the top:
a) There is a large fruit still uneaten.
The superior man receives a carriage.
The house of the inferior man is split apart.
b) “The superior man receives a carriage.” He is carried by the people.
“The house of the inferior man is split apart”: he ends up as useless.

Exegesis.Miscellaneous: SPLITTING APART means decay.
Exegesis.Sequence: When one goes too far in adornment, success exhausts itself. Hence there follows the hexagram of SPLITTING APART. Splitting apart means ruin.

Scripture.Hexagram: Po indicates that (in the state which it symbolises) it will not be advantageous to make a movement in any direction whatever.

Lines.L1: 1. The first SIX, divided, shows one overturning the couch by injuring its legs. (The injury will go on to) the destruction of (all) firm correctness, and there will be evil.
Lines.L2: 2. The second SIX, divided, shows one overthrowing the couch by injuring its frame. (The injury will go on to) the destruction of (all) firm correctness, and there will be evil.
Lines.L3: 3. The third SIX, divided, shows its subject among the overthrowers; but there will be no error.
Lines.L4: 4. The fourth SIX, divided, shows its subject having overthrown the couch, and (going to injure) the skin (of him who lies on it). There will be evil.
Lines.L5: 5. The fifth SIX, divided, shows (its subject leading on the others like) a string of fishes, and (obtaining for them) the favour that lights on the inmates of the palace. There will be advantage in every way.
Lines.L6: 6. The topmost NINE, undivided, shows its subject (as) a great fruit which has not been eaten. The superior man finds (the people again) as a chariot carrying him. The small men (by their course) overthrow their own dwellings.

Exegesis.Judgment:
XXIII. 1. Po denotes overthrowing or being overthrown. We see (in the figure) the weak lines (threatening to) change the (last) strong line (into one of themselves).
2. That 'it will not be advantageous to make a movement in any direction whatever' appears from the fact that the small men are (now) growing and increasing. The superior man acts according to (the exigency of the time), and stops all forward movement, looking at the (significance of the) symbolic figures (in the hexagram). He values the processes of decrease and increase, of fulness and decadence, (as seen) in the movements of the heavenly bodies.

Imagery.Hexagram: XXIII. (The trigrams representing) the earth, and (above it) that for a mountain, which adheres to the earth, form Po. Superiors, in accordance with this, seek to strengthen those below them, to secure the peace and stability of their own position.

Lines.L1: 1. 'He overthrows the couch by injuring its legs:'--thus (he commences) his work of ruin with what is lowest (in the superior man).
Lines.L2: 2. 'He destroys the couch by injuring its frame:'--(the superior man) has as yet no associates.
Lines.L3: 3. That 'there will be no error on the part of this one among the overthrowers' arises from the difference between him and the others above and below.
Lines.L4: 4. 'He has overthrown the couch, and (proceeds to injure) the skin (of him who lies on it):'--calamity is very near at hand.
Lines.L5: 5. 'He obtains for them the favour that lights on the inmates of the palace:'--in the end there will be no grudge against him.
Lines.L6: 6. 'The superior man finds himself in a carriage:'--he is carried along by the people. 'The small men (by their course) overthrow their own dwellings:'--they can. never again be of use to them.

Exegesis.Sequence:
19-23. What is great draws forth contemplation, and hence Lin is followed by Kwân. He who attracts contemplation will then bring about the union of others with himself, and hence Kwân is followed by Shih Ho. Shih Ho means union. But things should not be united in a reckless or irregular way, and hence Shih Ho is followed by Pî. Pî denotes adorning. When ornamentation has been carried to the utmost, its progress comes to an end; and hence Pî is followed by Po. Po denotes decay and overthrow.
23-26. Things cannot be done away for ever. When decadence and overthrow have completed their work at one end, reintegration commences at the other; and hence Po is followed by Fû. When the return (thus indicated) has taken place, we have not any rash disorder, and Fû. is followed by Wû Wang. Given the freedom from disorder and insincerity (which this name denotes), there may be the accumulation (of virtue), and Wû Wang is followed by Tâ Khû.

Scripture.Hexagram: 復：亨。出入无疾，朋來无咎。反復其道，七日來復，利有攸往。

Lines.L1: 初九：不遠復，无祗悔，元吉。
Lines.L2: 六二：休復，吉。
Lines.L3: 六三：頻復，厲无咎。
Lines.L4: 六四：中行獨復。
Lines.L5: 六五：敦復，无悔。
Lines.L6: 上六：迷復，凶，有災眚。用行師，終有大敗，以其國君，凶；至于十年，不克征。

Exegesis.Judgment: 復亨；剛反，動而以順行，是以出入无疾，朋來无咎。反復其道，七日來復，天行也。利有攸往，剛長也。復其見天地之心乎？

Imagery.Hexagram: 雷在地中，復；先王以至日閉關，商旅不行，后不省方。

Lines.L1: 不遠之復，以修身也。
Lines.L2: 休復之吉，以下仁也。
Lines.L3: 頻復之厲，義无咎也。
Lines.L4: 中行獨復，以從道也。
Lines.L5: 敦復无悔，中以自考也。
Lines.L6: 迷復之凶，反君道也。

Scripture.Hexagram: 复：亨。出入无疾，朋来无咎。反复其道，七日来复，利有攸往。

Lines.L1: 初九：不远复，无祗悔，元吉。
Lines.L2: 六二：休复，吉。
Lines.L3: 六三：频复，厉无咎。
Lines.L4: 六四：中行独复。
Lines.L5: 六五：敦复，无悔。
Lines.L6: 上六：迷复，凶，有灾眚。用行师，终有大败，以其国君，凶；至于十年，不克征。

Exegesis.Judgment: 复亨；刚反，动而以顺行，是以出入无疾，朋来无咎。反复其道，七日来复，天行也。利有攸往，刚长也。复其见天地之心乎？

Imagery.Hexagram: 雷在地中，复；先王以至日闭关，商旅不行，后不省方。

Lines.L1: 不远之复，以修身也。
Lines.L2: 休复之吉，以下仁也。
Lines.L3: 频复之厉，义无咎也。
Lines.L4: 中行独复，以从道也。
Lines.L5: 敦复无悔，中以自考也。
Lines.L6: 迷复之凶，反君道也。

Scripture.Hexagram:
RETURN. Success.
Going out and coming in without error.
Friends come without blame.
To and fro goes the way.
On the seventh day comes return.
It furthers one to have somewhere to go.

Lines.L1:
Nine at the beginning means:
Return from a short distance.
No need for remorse.
Great good fortune.
Lines.L2:
Six in the second place means:
Quiet return. Good fortune.
Lines.L3:
Six in the third place means:
Repeated return. Danger. No blame.
Lines.L4:
Six in the fourth place means:
Walking in the midst of others,
One returns alone.
Lines.L5:
Six in the fifth place means:
Noblehearted return. No remorse.
Lines.L6:
Six at the top means:
Missing the return. Misfortune.
Misfortune from within and without.
If armies are set marching in this way,
One will in the end suffer a great defeat,
Disastrous for the ruler of the country.
For ten years
It will not be possible to attack again.

Exegesis.Judgment:
Movement and action through devotion. Therefore, “Going out and coming in without error.”
“Friends come without blame. To and fro goes the way. On the seventh day comes return.” This is the course of heaven.
“It furthers one to have somewhere to go.” The firm is on the increase.
In the hexagram of RETURN one sees the mind of heaven and earth.

Imagery.Hexagram:
Thunder within the earth:
The image of THE TURNING POINT.
Thus the kings of antiquity closed the passes
At the time of solstice.
Merchants and strangers did not go about,
And the ruler
Did not travel through the provinces.

Lines.L1:
Nine at the beginning:
a) Return from a short distance.
No need for remorse.
Great good fortune.
b) “Return from a short distance”: thus one cultivates one’s character.
Lines.L2:
Six in the second place:
a) Quiet return. Good fortune.
b) The good fortune of a quiet return depends on subordination to a good man.
Lines.L3:
Six in the third place:
a) Repeated return. Danger. No blame.
b) The danger of repeated return is, in its essential meaning, deliverance from blame.
Lines.L4:
Six in the fourth place:
a) Walking in the midst of others,
One returns alone.
b) “Walking in the midst of others, one returns alone,” and so follows the right way.
Lines.L5:
Six in the fifth place:
a) Noblehearted return. No remorse.
b) “Noblehearted return. No remorse.” Central, therefore he is able to test himself.
Lines.L6:
Six at the top:
a) Missing the return. Misfortune.
Misfortune from within and without.
If armies are set marching in this way,
One will in the end suffer a great defeat,
Disastrous for the ruler of the country.
For ten years
It will not be possible to attack again.
b) The misfortune in missing the return lies in opposing the way of the superior man.

Exegesis.Miscellaneous: RETURN means coming back.
Exegesis.Sequence: Things cannot be destroyed once and for all. When what is above is completely split apart, it returns below. Hence there follows the hexagram of RETURN.
Exegesis.Extracts: RETURN is the stem of character. RETURN is small, yet different from external things. RETURN leads to self-knowledge.

Scripture.Hexagram: Fû indicates that there will be free course and progress (in what it denotes). (The subject of it) finds no one to distress him in his exits and entrances; friends come to him, and no error is committed. He will return and repeat his (proper) course. In seven days comes his return. There will be advantage in whatever direction movement is made.

Lines.L1: 1. The first NINE, undivided, shows its subject returning (from an error) of no great extent, which would not proceed to anything requiring repentance. There will be great good fortune.
Lines.L2: 2. The second SIX, divided, shows the admirable return (of its subject). There will be good fortune.
Lines.L3: 3. The third SIX, divided, shows one who has made repeated returns. The position is perilous, but there will be no error.
Lines.L4: 4. The fourth SIX, divided, shows its subject moving right in the centre (among those represented by the other divided lines), and yet returning alone (to his proper path).
Lines.L5: 5. The fifth SIX, divided, shows the noble return of its subject. There will be no ground for repentance.
Lines.L6: 6. The topmost SIX, divided, shows its subject all astray on the subject of returning. There will be evil. There will be calamities and errors. If with his views he put the hosts in motion, the end will be a great defeat, whose issues will extend to the ruler of the state. Even in ten years he will not be able to repair the disaster.

Exegesis.Judgment:
XXIV. 1. 'Fû indicates the free course and progress (of what it denotes):'--it is the coming back of what is intended by the undivided line.
2. (Its subject's) actions show movement directed by accordance with natural order. Hence 'he finds no one to distress him in his exits and entrances,' and 'friends come to him, and no error is committed.'
3. 'He will return and repeat his proper course; in seven days comes his return:'--such is the movement of the heavenly (revolution).
4. 'There will be advantage in whatever direction movement is made:--the strong lines are growing and increasing.
5. Do we not see in Fû the mind of heaven and earth?

Imagery.Hexagram: XXIV. (The trigram representing) the earth and that for thunder in the midst of it form Fû. The ancient kings, in accordance with this, on the day. of the (winter) solstice, shut the gates of the passes (from one state to another), so that the travelling merchants could not (then) pursue their journeys, nor the princes go on with the inspection of their states.

Lines.L1: 1. 'Returning (from an error) of no great extent' is the prelude to the cultivation of the person.
Lines.L2: 2. 'The good fortune attendant on the admirable return (of the subject of the second line)' is due to his condescension to the virtuous (subject of the line) below.
Lines.L3: 3. Notwithstanding 'the perilous position of himwho has made many returns,' there will be no error through (his aiming after righteousness).
Lines.L4: 4. 'He moves right in the centre (among those represented by the other divided lines), and yet returns alone:'--his object is to pursue the (proper) path.
Lines.L5: 5. 'The noble return, giving no ground for repentance,' is due to (the subject of the line) striving to perfect himself in accordance with his central position.
Lines.L6: 6. 'The evil consequent on being all astray on the subject of returning' is because the course pursued is contrary to the proper course for a ruler.

Exegesis.Sequence: 23-26. Things cannot be done away for ever. When decadence and overthrow have completed their work at one end, reintegration commences at the other; and hence Po is followed by Fû. When the return (thus indicated) has taken place, we have not any rash disorder, and Fû. is followed by Wû Wang. Given the freedom from disorder and insincerity (which this name denotes), there may be the accumulation (of virtue), and Wû Wang is followed by Tâ Khû.

Scripture.Hexagram: 无妄：元亨，利貞。其匪正有眚，不利有攸往。

Lines.L1: 初九：无妄，往吉。
Lines.L2: 六二：不耕獲，不菑畬，則利有攸往。
Lines.L3: 六三：无妄之災，或繫之牛，行人之得，邑人之災。
Lines.L4: 九四：可貞，无咎。
Lines.L5: 九五：无妄之疾，勿藥有喜。
Lines.L6: 上九：无妄，行有眚，无攸利。

Exegesis.Judgment: 无妄，剛自外來，而為主於內。動而健，剛中而應，大亨以正，天之命也。其匪正有眚，不利有攸往。无妄之往，何之矣？天命不佑，行矣哉？

Imagery.Hexagram: 天下雷行，物與无妄；先王以茂對時，育萬物。

Lines.L1: 无妄之往，得志也。
Lines.L2: 不耕獲，未富也。
Lines.L3: 行人得牛，邑人災也。
Lines.L4: 可貞无咎，固有之也。
Lines.L5: 无妄之藥，不可試也。
Lines.L6: 无妄之行，窮之災也。

Scripture.Hexagram: 无妄：元亨，利贞。其匪正有眚，不利有攸往。

Lines.L1: 初九：无妄，往吉。
Lines.L2: 六二：不耕获，不灾畲，则利有攸往。
Lines.L3: 六三：无妄之灾，或系之牛，行人之得，邑人之灾。
Lines.L4: 九四：可贞，无咎。
Lines.L5: 九五：无妄之疾，勿药有喜。
Lines.L6: 上九：无妄，行有眚，无攸利。

Exegesis.Judgment: 无妄，刚自外来，而为主于内。动而健，刚中而应，大亨以正，天之命也。其匪正有眚，不利有攸往。无妄之往，何之矣？天命不佑，行矣哉？

Imagery.Hexagram: 天下雷行，物与无妄；先王以茂对时，育万物。

Lines.L1: 无妄之往，得志也。
Lines.L2: 不耕获，未富也。
Lines.L3: 行人得牛，邑人灾也。
Lines.L4: 可贞无咎，固有之也。
Lines.L5: 无妄之药，不可试也。
Lines.L6: 无妄之行，穷之灾也。

Scripture.Hexagram:
INNOCENCE. Supreme success.
Perseverance furthers.
If someone is not as he should be,
He has misfortune,
And it does not further him
To undertake anything.

Lines.L1:
Nine at the beginning means:
Innocent behavior brings good fortune.
Lines.L2:
Six in the second place means:
If one does not count on the harvest while plowing,
Nor on the use of the ground while clearing it,
It furthers one to undertake something.
Lines.L3:
Six in the third place means:
Undeserved misfortune.
The cow that was tethered by someone
Is the wanderer’s gain, the citizen’s loss.
Lines.L4:
Nine in the fourth place means:
He who can be persevering
Remains without blame.
Lines.L5:
Nine in the fifth place means:
Use no medicine in an illness
Incurred through no fault of your own.
It will pass of itself.
Lines.L6:
Nine at the top means:
Innocent action brings misfortune.
Nothing furthers.

Exegesis.Judgment:
INNOCENCE. The firm comes from without and becomes the ruler within. Movement and strength. The firm is in the middle and finds correspondence.
“Great success through correctness”: this is the will of heaven.
“If someone is not as he should be, he has misfortune, and it does not further him to undertake anything.” When innocence is gone, where can one go? When the will of heaven does not protect one, can one do anything?

Imagery.Hexagram:
Under heaven thunder rolls:
All things attain the natural state of innocence.
Thus the kings of old,
Rich in virtue, and in harmony with the time,
Fostered and nourished all beings.
“Rich in virtue” refers to the strength of the Creative. “The time” derives from the trigram Chên (east and spring)—the trigram in which life comes forth. Fostering and nourishing are indicated by the nuclear trigram Kên, mountain. The fact that this influence extends to everything is symbolized by the nuclear trigram Sun, meaning wind and universal penetration.

Lines.L1:
Nine at the beginning:
a) Innocent behavior brings good fortune.
b) Innocent behavior attains its will.
Lines.L2:
Six in the second place:
a) If one does not count on the harvest while plowing,
Nor on the use of the ground while clearing it,
It furthers one to undertake something.
b) Not plowing in order to reap: that is, one does not seek wealth.
Lines.L3:
Six in the third place:
a) Undeserved misfortune.
The cow that was tethered by someone
Is the wanderer’s gain, the citizen’s loss.
b) If the wanderer gets the cow, it is the citizen’s loss.
Lines.L4:
Nine in the fourth place:
a) He who can be persevering
Remains without blame.
b) “He who can be persevering remains without blame,” for he possesses firmly.
Lines.L5:
Nine in the fifth place:
a) Use no medicine in an illness
Incurred through no fault of your own.
It will pass of itself.
b) One should not try an unknown medicine.
Lines.L6:
Nine at the top:
a) Innocent action brings misfortune.
Nothing furthers.
b) Action without reflection brings about the evil of bewilderment.

Exegesis.Miscellaneous: THE UNEXPECTED means misfortune from without.
Exegesis.Sequence: By turning back one is freed of guilt. Hence there follows the hexagram of INNOCENCE.

Scripture.Hexagram: Wû Wang indicates great progress and success, while there will be advantage in being firm and correct. If (its subject and his action) be not correct, he will fall into errors, and it will not be advantageous for him to move in any direction.

Lines.L1: 1. The first NINE, undivided, shows its subject free from all insincerity. His advance will be accompanied with good fortune.
Lines.L2: 2. The second SIX, divided, shows one who reaps without having ploughed (that he might reap), and gathers the produce of his third year's fields without having cultivated them the first year for that end. To such a one there will be advantage in whatever direction he may move.
Lines.L3: 3. The third SIX, divided, shows calamity happening to one who is free from insincerity;—as in the case of an ox that has been tied up. A passer by finds it (and carries it off), while the people in the neighbourhood have the calamity (of being accused and apprehended).
Lines.L4: 4. The fourth NINE, undivided, shows (a case) in which, if its subject can remain firm and correct, there will be no error.
Lines.L5: 5. The fifth NINE, undivided, shows one who is free from insincerity, and yet has fallen ill. Let him not use medicine, and he will have occasion for joy (in his recovery).
Lines.L6: 6. The topmost NINE, undivided, shows its subject free from insincerity, yet sure to fall into error, if he take action. (His action) will not be advantageous in any way.

Exegesis.Judgment: XXV. In Wû Wang we have the strong (first) line come from the outer (trigram), and become in the inner trigram lord (of the whole figure); we have (the attributes of) motive power and strength; we have the strong line (of the fifth place) in thecentral position, and responded to (by the weak second):--there will be 'great progress proceeding from correctness; such is the appointment of Heaven.'If (its subject and his action) be not correct, he will fall into errors, and it will not be advantageous for him to move in any direction:'--whither can he (who thinks he is) free from all insincerity, (and yet is as here described) proceed? Can anything be done (advantageously) by him whom the (will and) appointment of Heaven do not help?

Imagery.Hexagram: XXV. The thunder rolls all under the sky, and to (every)thing there is given (its nature), free from all insincerity. The ancient kings, in accordance with this, (made their regulations) in complete accordance with the seasons, thereby nourishing all things.

Lines.L1: 1. When 'he who is free from insincerity makes any movement,' he will get what he desires.
Lines.L2: 2. 'He reaps without having ploughed:'--(the thought of) riches to be got had not risen (in his mind).
Lines.L3: 3. 'The passer-by gets the ox:'--this proves a calamity to the people of the neighbourhood.
Lines.L4: 4. 'If he can remain firm and correct there will be no error:'--he firmly holds fast (his correctness).
Lines.L5: 5. 'Medicine in the case of one who is free from insincerity!'--it should not be tried (at all).
Lines.L6: 6. 'The action (in this case) of one who is free from insincerity' will occasion the calamity arising from action (when the time for it is) exhausted.

Exegesis.Sequence: 23-26. Things cannot be done away for ever. When decadence and overthrow have completed their work at one end, reintegration commences at the other; and hence Po is followed by Fû. When the return (thus indicated) has taken place, we have not any rash disorder, and Fû. is followed by Wû Wang. Given the freedom from disorder and insincerity (which this name denotes), there may be the accumulation (of virtue), and Wû Wang is followed by Tâ Khû.

English.WilhelmBaynes: Ta Ch’u / The Taming Power of the Great

Scripture.Hexagram: 大畜：利貞，不家食吉，利涉大川。

Lines.L1: 初九：有厲利已。
Lines.L2: 九二：輿說輹。
Lines.L3: 九三：良馬逐，利艱貞。曰閑輿衛，利有攸往。
Lines.L4: 六四：童牛之牿，元吉。
Lines.L5: 六五：豶豕之牙，吉。
Lines.L6: 上九：何天之衢，亨。

Exegesis.Judgment: 大畜，剛健篤實輝光，日新其德，剛上而尚賢。能止健，大正也。不家食吉，養賢也。利涉大川，應乎天也。

Imagery.Hexagram: 天在山中，大畜；君子以多識前言往行，以畜其德。

Lines.L1: 有厲利已，不犯災也。
Lines.L2: 輿說輹，中无尤也。
Lines.L3: 利有攸往，上合志也。
Lines.L4: 六四元吉，有喜也。
Lines.L5: 六五之吉，有慶也。
Lines.L6: 何天之衢，道大行也。

Scripture.Hexagram: 大畜：利贞，不家食吉，利涉大川。

Lines.L1: 初九：有厉利已。
Lines.L2: 九二：舆说輹。
Lines.L3: 九三：良马逐，利艰贞。曰闲舆卫，利有攸往。
Lines.L4: 六四：童牛之牿，元吉。
Lines.L5: 六五：豶豕之牙，吉。
Lines.L6: 上九：何天之衢，亨。

Exegesis.Judgment: 大畜，刚健笃实辉光，日新其德，刚上而尚贤。能止健，大正也。不家食吉，养贤也。利涉大川，应乎天也。

Imagery.Hexagram: 天在山中，大畜；君子以多识前言往行，以畜其德。

Lines.L1: 有厉利已，不犯灾也。
Lines.L2: 舆说輹，中无尤也。
Lines.L3: 利有攸往，上合志也。
Lines.L4: 六四元吉，有喜也。
Lines.L5: 六五之吉，有庆也。
Lines.L6: 何天之衢，道大行也。

Scripture.Hexagram:
THE TAMING POWER OF THE GREAT.
Perseverance furthers.
Not eating at home brings good fortune.
It furthers one to cross the great water.

Lines.L1:
Nine at the beginning means:
Danger is at hand. It furthers one to desist.
Lines.L2:
Nine in the second place means:
The axletrees are taken from the wagon.
Lines.L3:
Nine in the third place means:
A good horse that follows others.
Awareness of danger,
With perseverance, furthers.
Practice chariot driving and armed defense daily.
It furthers one to have somewhere to go.
Lines.L4:
Six in the fourth place means:
The headboard of a young bull.
Great good fortune.
Lines.L5:
Six in the fifth place means:
The tusk of a gelded boar.
Good fortune.
Lines.L6:
Nine at the top means:
One attains the way of heaven. Success.

Exegesis.Judgment:
THE TAMING POWER OF THE GREAT. Firmness and strength. Genuineness and truth. Brilliance and light. Daily he renews his virtue.
The firm ascends and honors the worthy. He is able to keep strength still; this is great correctness.
“Not eating at home brings good fortune,” for people of worth are nourished.
“It furthers one to cross the great water,” because one finds correspondence in heaven.
“It furthers one to cross the great water.” This idea is suggested by the two nuclear trigrams—Chên, which also means wood, over Tui, lake. This dangerous action is possible because the ruler of the hexagram, the six in the fifth place, is in the relationship of correspondence to the nine in the second place, the central line of the lower trigram, heaven (Ch’ien).

Imagery.Hexagram:
Heaven within the mountain:
The image of THE TAMING POWER OF THE GREAT.
Thus the superior man acquaints himself with many sayings of antiquity
And many deeds of the past,
In order to strengthen his character thereby.

Lines.L1:
Nine at the beginning:
a) Danger is at hand. It furthers one to desist.
b) “Danger is at hand. It furthers one to desist.” Thus one does not expose oneself to danger.
Lines.L2:
Nine in the second place:
a) The axletrees are taken from the wagon.
b) “The axletrees are taken from the wagon.” In the middle there is no blame.
Lines.L3:
Nine in the third place:
a) A good horse that follows others.
Awareness of danger,
With perseverance, furthers.
Practice chariot driving and armed defense daily.
It furthers one to have somewhere to go.
b) “It furthers one to have somewhere to go.” The will of the one above is in agreement.
Lines.L4:
Six in the fourth place:
a) The headboard of a young bull.
Great good fortune.
b) The great good fortune of the six in the fourth place consists in the fact that it has joy.
Lines.L5:
Six in the fifth place:
a) The tusk of a gelded boar.
Good fortune.
b) The good fortune of the six in the fifth place consists in the fact that it has blessing.
Lines.L6:
Nine at the top:
a) One attains the way of heaven. Success.
b) “One attains the way of heaven.” Truth works in the great.

Exegesis.Miscellaneous: THE TAMING POWER OF THE GREAT depends on the time.
Exegesis.Sequence: When innocence is present, it is possible to tame. Hence there follows THE TAMING POWER OF THE GREAT.

Scripture.Hexagram: Under the conditions of Tâ Khû it will be advantageous to be firm and correct. (If its subject do not seek to) enjoy his revenues in his own family (without taking service at court), there will be good fortune. It will be advantageous for him to cross the great stream.

Lines.L1: 1. The first NINE, undivided, shows its subject in a position of peril. It will be advantageous for him to stop his advance.
Lines.L2: 2. The second NINE, undivided, shows a carriage with the strap under it removed.
Lines.L3: 3. The third NINE, undivided, shows its subject urging his way with good horses. It will be advantageous for him to realise the difficulty (of his course), and to be firm and correct, exercising himself daily in his charioteering and methods of defence; then there will be advantage in whatever direction he may advance.
Lines.L4: 4. The fourth SIX, divided, shows the young bull, (and yet) having the piece of wood over his horns. There will be great good fortune.
Lines.L5: 5. The fifth SIX, divided, shows the teeth of a castrated hog. There will be good fortune.
Lines.L6: 6. The sixth NINE, undivided, shows its subject (as) in command of the firmament of heaven. There will be progress.

Exegesis.Judgment:
XXVI. 1. In (the trigrams composing) Tâ Khû we have (the attributes) of the greatest strength and of substantial solidity, which emit a brilliant light; and indicate a daily renewal of his virtue (by the subject of it).
2. The strong line is in the highest place, and suggests the value set on talents and virtue; there is power (in the upper trigram) to keep the strongest in restraint:--all this shows 'the great correctness' (required in the hexagram).
3. 'The good fortune attached to the subject's not seeking to enjoy his revenues in his own family' shows how talents and virtue are nourished.
4. 'It will be advantageous to cross the great stream:'--(the fifth line, representing the ruler,) is responded to by (the second, the central line of Khien, representing) Heaven.

Imagery.Hexagram: XXVI. (The trigram representing) a mountain, and in the midst of it that (representing) heaven, form Tâ Khû. The superior man, in accordance with this, stores largely in his memory the words and deeds of former men, to subserve the accumulation of his virtue.

Lines.L1: 1. 'He is in a position of peril; it will be advantageous for him to stop his advance:'--he should not rashly expose himself to calamity.
Lines.L2: 2. '(He is as) a carriage from which the strap under it has been removed:'--being in the central position, he will incur no blame.
Lines.L3: 3. 'There will be advantage in whatever direction he may advance:'--(the subject of) the topmost line is of the same mind with him.
Lines.L4: 4. 'The great good fortune indicated by the fourth six, (divided),' shows that there is occasion for joy.
Lines.L5: 5. 'The good fortune indicated by the fifth six, (divided),' shows that there is occasion for congratulation.
Lines.L6: 6. 'In command of the firmament of heaven:'--the way is grandly open for movement.

Exegesis.Sequence:
23-26. Things cannot be done away for ever. When decadence and overthrow have completed their work at one end, reintegration commences at the other; and hence Po is followed by Fû. When the return (thus indicated) has taken place, we have not any rash disorder, and Fû. is followed by Wû Wang. Given the freedom from disorder and insincerity (which this name denotes), there may be the accumulation (of virtue), and Wû Wang is followed by Tâ Khû.
26-30. Such accumulation having taken place, there will follow the nourishment of it; and hence Tâ Khû is followed by Î. Î denotes nourishing. Without nourishment there could be no movement, and hence Î is followed by Tâ Kwo. Things cannot for ever be in a state of extraordinary (progress); and hence Tâ Kwo is followed by Khân. Khân denotes falling into peril. When one falls into peril, he is sure to attach himself to some person or thing; and hence Khân is followed by Lî. Lî denotes being attached, or adhering, to.

English.WilhelmBaynes: I / The Corners of the Mouth

Scripture.Hexagram: 頤：貞吉。觀頤，自求口實。

Lines.L1: 初九：舍爾靈龜，觀我朵頤，凶。
Lines.L2: 六二：顛頤，拂經，于丘頤，征凶。
Lines.L3: 六三：拂頤，貞凶，十年勿用，无攸利。
Lines.L4: 六四：顛頤，吉，虎視眈眈，其欲逐逐，无咎。
Lines.L5: 六五：拂經，居貞吉，不可涉大川。
Lines.L6: 上九：由頤，厲吉，利涉大川。

Exegesis.Judgment: 頤貞吉，養正則吉也。觀頤，觀其所養也；自求口實，觀其自養也。天地養萬物，聖人養賢，以及萬民；頤之時大矣哉！

Imagery.Hexagram: 山下有雷，頤；君子以慎言語，節飲食。

Lines.L1: 觀我朵頤，亦不足貴也。
Lines.L2: 六二征凶，行失類也。
Lines.L3: 十年勿用，道大悖也。
Lines.L4: 顛頤之吉，上施光也。
Lines.L5: 居貞之吉，順以從上也。
Lines.L6: 由頤厲吉，大有慶也。

Scripture.Hexagram: 颐：贞吉。观颐，自求口实。

Lines.L1: 初九：舍尔灵龟，观我朵颐，凶。
Lines.L2: 六二：颠颐，拂经，于丘颐，征凶。
Lines.L3: 六三：拂颐，贞凶，十年勿用，无攸利。
Lines.L4: 六四：颠颐，吉，虎视眈眈，其欲逐逐，无咎。
Lines.L5: 六五：拂经，居贞吉，不可涉大川。
Lines.L6: 上九：由颐，厉吉，利涉大川。

Exegesis.Judgment: 颐贞吉，养正则吉也。观颐，观其所养也；自求口实，观其自养也。天地养万物，圣人养贤，以及万民；颐之时大矣哉！

Imagery.Hexagram: 山下有雷，颐；君子以慎言语，节饮食。

Lines.L1: 观我朵颐，亦不足贵也。
Lines.L2: 六二征凶，行失类也。
Lines.L3: 十年勿用，道大悖也。
Lines.L4: 颠颐之吉，上施光也。
Lines.L5: 居贞之吉，顺以从上也。
Lines.L6: 由颐厉吉，大有庆也。

Scripture.Hexagram:
THE CORNERS OF THE MOUTH.
Perseverance brings good fortune.
Pay heed to the providing of nourishment
And to what a man seeks
To fill his own mouth with.

If we wish to know whether anyone is superior or not, we need only observe what part of his being he regards as especially important. The body has superior and inferior, important and unimportant parts. We must not injure important parts for the sake of the unimportant, nor must we injure the superior parts for the sake of the inferior. He who cultivates the inferior parts of his nature is an inferior man. He who cultivates the superior parts of his nature is a superior man.

Lines.L1:
Nine at the beginning means:
You let your magic tortoise go,
And look at me with the corners of your mouth drooping.
Misfortune.
Lines.L2:
Six in the second place means:
Turning to the summit for nourishment,
Deviating from the path
To seek nourishment from the hill.
Continuing to do this brings misfortune.
Lines.L3:
Six in the third place means:
Turning away from nourishment.
Perseverance brings misfortune.
Do not act thus for ten years.
Nothing serves to further.
Lines.L4:
Six in the fourth place means:
Turning to the summit
For provision of nourishment
Brings good fortune.
Spying about with sharp eyes
Like a tiger with insatiable craving.
No blame.
Lines.L5:
Six in the fifth place means:
Turning away from the path.
To remain persevering brings good fortune.
One should not cross the great water.
Lines.L6:
Nine at the top means:
The source of nourishment.
Awareness of danger brings good fortune.
It furthers one to cross the great water.

Exegesis.Judgment:
“THE CORNERS OF THE MOUTH. Perseverance brings good fortune.” If one provides nourishment for what is right, good fortune comes.
“Pay heed to the providing of nourishment,” that is, pay heed to what a man provides nourishment for.
“To what he seeks to fill his own mouth with,” that is, pay heed to what a man nourishes himself with.
Heaven and earth provide nourishment for all beings. The holy man provides nourishment for men of worth and thus reaches the whole people. Truly great is the time of PROVIDING NOURISHMENT.

Imagery.Hexagram:
At the foot of the mountain, thunder:
The image of PROVIDING NOURISHMENT.
Thus the superior man is careful of his words
And temperate in eating and drinking.

Lines.L1:
Nine at the beginning:
a) You let your magic tortoise go,
And look at me with the corners of your mouth drooping.
Misfortune.
b) “You … look at me with the corners of your mouth drooping”: this is really not to be respected.
Lines.L2:
Six in the second place:
a) Turning to the summit for nourishment,
Deviating from the path
To seek nourishment from the hill.
Continuing to do this brings misfortune.
b) If the six in the second place continues to do this, it brings misfortune, because in going it loses its place among its kind.
Lines.L3:
Six in the third place:
a) Turning away from nourishment.
Perseverance brings misfortune.
Do not act thus for ten years.
Nothing serves to further.
b) “Do not act thus for ten years,” because it is all too contrary to the right way.
Lines.L4:
Six in the fourth place:
a) Turning to the summit
For provision of nourishment
Brings good fortune.
Spying about with sharp eyes
Like a tiger with insatiable craving.
No blame.
b) The good fortune in turning to the summit to be provided with nourishment inheres in the fact that the one above spreads light.
Lines.L5:
Six in the fifth place:
a) Turning away from the path.
To remain persevering brings good fortune.
One should not cross the great water.
b) The good fortune in remaining persevering comes from following the one above devotedly.
Lines.L6:
Nine at the top:
a) The source of nourishment.
Awareness of danger brings good fortune.
It furthers one to cross the great water.
b) “The source of nourishment. Awareness of danger brings good fortune.” It has great blessing.

Exegesis.Miscellaneous: THE CORNERS OF THE MOUTH means providing nourishment for what is right.
Exegesis.Sequence: When things are held fast, there is provision of nourishment. Hence there follows the hexagram of THE CORNERS OF THE MOUTH. “The corners of the mouth” means the providing of nourishment.

Scripture.Hexagram: Î indicates that with firm correctness there will be good fortune (in what is denoted by it). We must look at what we are seeking to nourish, and by the exercise of our thoughts seek for the proper aliment.

Lines.L1: 1. The first NINE, undivided, (seems to be thus addressed), 'You leave your efficacious tortoise, and look at me till your lower jaw hangs down.' There will be evil.
Lines.L2: 2. The second SIX, divided, shows one looking downwards for nourishment, which is contrary to what is proper; or seeking it from the height (above), advance towards which will lead to evil.
Lines.L3: 3. The third SIX, divided, shows one acting contrary to the method of nourishing. However firm he may be, there will be evil. For ten years let him not take any action, (for) it will not be in any way advantageous.
Lines.L4: 4. The fourth SIX, divided, shows one looking downwards for (the power to) nourish. There will be good fortune. Looking with a tiger's downward unwavering glare, and with his desire that impels him to spring after spring, he will fall into no error.
Lines.L5: 5. The fifth SIX, divided, shows one acting contrary to what is regular and proper; but if he abide in firmness, there will be good fortune. He should not, (however, try to) cross the great stream.
Lines.L6: 6. The sixth NINE, undivided, shows him from whom comes the nourishing. His position is perilous, but there will be good fortune. It will be advantageous to cross the great stream.

Exegesis.Judgment:
XXVII. 1. 'Î indicates that with firm correctness there will be good fortune:'--when the nourishing is correct, there will be good fortune. 'We must look at what we are seeking to nourish:'--we must look at those whom we wish to nourish. 'We must by the exercise of our thoughts seek the proper aliment:'--we must look to our own nourishing of ourselves.
2. Heaven and earth nourish all things. The sages nourish men of talents and virtue, by them to reach to the myriads of the people. Great is (the work intended by this) nourishing in its time!

Imagery.Hexagram: XXVII. (The trigram representing) a mountain and under it that for thunder form Î. The superior man, in accordance with this, (enjoins) watchfulness over our words, and the temperate regulation of our eating and drinking.

Lines.L1: 1. 'You look at me till your (lower) jaw hangs down:'--(the subject of the line) is thus shown unfit to be thought noble.
Lines.L2: 2. 'The evil of advance by the subject of the second SIX, (divided),' is owing to his leaving in his movements his proper associates.
Lines.L3: 3. 'For ten years let him not take any action:'--his course is greatly opposed (to what is right).
Lines.L4: 4. 'The good fortune attached to looking downwards for (the power to) nourish,' shows how brilliant will be the diffusion (of that power) from (the subject of the line's) superior position.
Lines.L5: 5. 'The good fortune from abiding in firmness' is due to the docility (of the subject of the line) in following (the subject of the line) above.
Lines.L6: 6. 'The good fortune, notwithstanding the perilof his position, of him from whom comes the nourishing,' affords great cause for congratulation.

Exegesis.Sequence: 26-30. Such accumulation having taken place, there will follow the nourishment of it; and hence Tâ Khû is followed by Î. Î denotes nourishing. Without nourishment there could be no movement, and hence Î is followed by Tâ Kwo. Things cannot for ever be in a state of extraordinary (progress); and hence Tâ Kwo is followed by Khân. Khân denotes falling into peril. When one falls into peril, he is sure to attach himself to some person or thing; and hence Khân is followed by Lî. Lî denotes being attached, or adhering, to.

English.WilhelmBaynes: Ta Kuo / Preponderance of the Great

Scripture.Hexagram: 大過：棟橈，利有攸往，亨。

Lines.L1: 初六：藉用白茅，无咎。
Lines.L2: 九二：枯楊生稊，老夫得其女妻，无不利。
Lines.L3: 九三：棟橈，凶。
Lines.L4: 九四：棟隆，吉；有它吝。
Lines.L5: 九五：枯楊生華，老婦得士夫，无咎无譽。
Lines.L6: 上六：過涉滅頂，凶，无咎。

Exegesis.Judgment: 大過，大者過也。棟橈，本末弱也。剛過而中，巽而說行，利有攸往，乃亨。大過之時大矣哉！

Imagery.Hexagram: 澤滅木，大過；君子以獨立不懼，遯世无悶。

Lines.L1: 藉用白茅，柔在下也。
Lines.L2: 老夫女妻，過以相與也。
Lines.L3: 棟橈之凶，不可以有輔也。
Lines.L4: 棟隆之吉，不橈乎下也。
Lines.L5: 枯楊生華，何可久也。老婦士夫，亦可醜也。
Lines.L6: 過涉之凶，不可咎也。

Scripture.Hexagram: 大过：栋桡，利有攸往，亨。

Lines.L1: 初六：藉用白茅，无咎。
Lines.L2: 九二：枯杨生稊，老夫得其女妻，无不利。
Lines.L3: 九三：栋桡，凶。
Lines.L4: 九四：栋隆，吉；有它吝。
Lines.L5: 九五：枯杨生华，老妇得士夫，无咎无誉。
Lines.L6: 上六：过涉灭顶，凶，无咎。

Exegesis.Judgment: 大过，大者过也。栋桡，本末弱也。刚过而中，巽而说行，利有攸往，乃亨。大过之时大矣哉！

Imagery.Hexagram: 泽灭木，大过；君子以独立不惧，遯世无闷。

Lines.L1: 藉用白茅，柔在下也。
Lines.L2: 老夫女妻，过以相与也。
Lines.L3: 栋桡之凶，不可以有辅也。
Lines.L4: 栋隆之吉，不桡乎下也。
Lines.L5: 枯杨生华，何可久也。老妇士夫，亦可丑也。
Lines.L6: 过涉之凶，不可咎也。

Scripture.Hexagram:
PREPONDERANCE OF THE GREAT.
The ridgepole sags to the breaking point.
It furthers one to have somewhere to go.
Success.

Lines.L1:
Six at the beginning means:
To spread white rushes underneath.
No blame.
Lines.L2:
Nine in the second place means:
A dry poplar sprouts at the root.
An older man takes a young wife.
Everything furthers.
Lines.L3:
Nine in the third place means:
The ridgepole sags to the breaking point.
Misfortune.
Lines.L4:
Nine in the fourth place means:
The ridgepole is braced. Good fortune.
If there are ulterior motives, it is humiliating.
Lines.L5:
Nine in the fifth place means:
A withered poplar puts forth flowers.
An older woman takes a husband.
No blame. No praise.
Lines.L6:
Six at the top means:
One must go through the water.
It goes over one’s head.
Misfortune. No blame.

Exegesis.Judgment:
PREPONDERANCE OF THE GREAT. The great preponderates. The ridgepole sags to the breaking point because beginning and end are weak.
The firm preponderates and is central. Gentle and joyous in action: then it furthers one to have somewhere to go, then one has success.
Great indeed is the time of PREPONDERANCE OF THE GREAT.

Imagery.Hexagram:
The lake rises above the trees:
The image of PREPONDERANCE OF THE GREAT.
Thus the superior man, when he stands alone,
Is unconcerned,
And if he has to renounce the world,
He is undaunted.

Lines.L1:
Six at the beginning:
a) To spread white rushes underneath.
No blame.
b) “To spread white rushes underneath”: the yielding is underneath.
Lines.L2:
Nine in the second place:
a) A dry poplar sprouts at the root.
An older man takes a young wife.
Everything furthers.
b) “An older man takes a young wife.” The extraordinary thing is their coming together.
Lines.L3:
Nine in the third place:
a) The ridgepole sags to the breaking point.
Misfortune.
b) The misfortune of the sagging and breaking of the ridgepole is due to its finding no support.
Lines.L4:
Nine in the fourth place:
a) The ridgepole is braced. Good fortune.
If there are ulterior motives, it is humiliating.
b) The good fortune of the braced ridgepole lies in the fact that it does not sag downward and break.
Lines.L5:
Nine in the fifth place:
a) A withered poplar puts forth flowers.
An older woman takes a husband.
No blame. No praise.
b) “A withered poplar puts forth flowers.” How could this last long?
“An older woman takes a husband.” It is nevertheless a disgrace.
Lines.L6:
Six at the top:
a) One must go through the water.
It goes over one’s head.
Misfortune. No blame.
b) One should not join blame to the misfortune of going through the water.

Exegesis.Miscellaneous: PREPONDERANCE OF THE GREAT is the peak.
Exegesis.Sequence: Without provision of nourishment one cannot move; hence there follows the hexagram of PREPONDERANCE OF THE GREAT.
Exegesis.Extracts: In ancient times the dead were buried by covering them thickly with brushwood and placing them in the open country, without burial mound or grove of trees. The period of mourning had no definite duration. The holy men of a later time introduced inner and outer coffins instead. They probably took this from—the hexagram of PREPONDERANCE OF THE GREAT.

Scripture.Hexagram: Tâ Kwo suggests to us a beam that is weak. There will be advantage in moving (under its conditions) in any direction whatever; there will be success.

Lines.L1: 1. The first SIX, divided, shows one placing mats of the white mâo grass under things set on the ground. There will be no error.
Lines.L2: 2. The second NINE, undivided, shows a decayed willow producing shoots, or an old husband in possession of his young wife. There will be advantage in every way.
Lines.L3: 3. The third NINE, undivided, shows a beam that is weak. There will be evil.
Lines.L4: 4. The fourth NINE, undivided, shows a beam curving upwards. There will be good fortune. If (the subject of it) looks for other (help but that of line one), there will be cause for regret.
Lines.L5: 5. The fifth NINE, undivided, shows a decayed willow producing flowers, or an old wife in possession of her young husband. There will be occasion neither for blame nor for praise.
Lines.L6: 6. The topmost SIX, divided, shows its subject with extraordinary (boldness) wading through a stream, till the water hides the crown of his head. There will be evil, but no ground for blame.

Exegesis.Judgment:
XXVIII. 1. Tâ Kwo shows the great ones (= the undivided lines) in excess.
2. In 'the beam that is weak' we see weakness both in the lowest and the topmost (lines).
3. The strong lines are in excess, but (two of them) are in the central positions. The action (of the hexagram is represented by the symbols of) flexibility and satisfaction. (Hence it is said), 'There will be advantage in moving in any direction whatever; yea, there will be success. '
4. Great indeed is (the work to be done in) this very extraordinary time.

Imagery.Hexagram: XXVIII. (The trigram representing) trees hidden beneath that for the waters of a marsh forms Tâ Kwo. The superior man, in accordance with this, stands up alone and has no fear, and keeps retired from the world without regret.

Lines.L1: 1. 'He places mats of the white mâo grass under things set on the ground:'--he feels his weakness and his being in the lowest place, (and uses extraordinary care).
Lines.L2: 2. 'An old husband and a young wife:'--such association is extraordinary.
Lines.L3: 3. 'The evil connected with the beam that is weak' arises from this, that no help can be given (to the condition thus represented).
Lines.L4: 4. 'The good fortune connected with the beam curving upwards' arises from this, that it does not bend towards what is below.
Lines.L5: 5. 'A decayed willow produces flowers:'--but how can this secure its long continuance? 'An oldwife and a young husband:'--this also is a thing to be ashamed of.
Lines.L6: 6. 'Evil follows wading with (extraordinary) boldness (through the stream):'--but (the act) affords no ground for blame.

Exegesis.Sequence: 26-30. Such accumulation having taken place, there will follow the nourishment of it; and hence Tâ Khû is followed by Î. Î denotes nourishing. Without nourishment there could be no movement, and hence Î is followed by Tâ Kwo. Things cannot for ever be in a state of extraordinary (progress); and hence Tâ Kwo is followed by Khân. Khân denotes falling into peril. When one falls into peril, he is sure to attach himself to some person or thing; and hence Khân is followed by Lî. Lî denotes being attached, or adhering, to.

Scripture.Hexagram: 坎：習坎，有孚，維心亨，行有尚。

Lines.L1: 初六：習坎，入于坎窞，凶。
Lines.L2: 九二：坎有險，求小得。
Lines.L3: 六三：來之坎坎，險且枕，入于坎窞，勿用。
Lines.L4: 六四：樽酒簋貳，用缶，納約自牖，終无咎。
Lines.L5: 九五：坎不盈，祗既平，无咎。
Lines.L6: 上六：係用徽纆，寘于叢棘，三歲不得，凶。

Exegesis.Judgment: 習坎，重險也。水流而不盈，行險而不失其信。維心亨，乃以剛中也。行有尚，往有功也。天險不可升也，地險山川丘陵也，王公設險以守其國，坎之時用大矣哉！

Imagery.Hexagram: 水洊至，習坎；君子以常德行，習教事。

Lines.L1: 習坎入坎，失道凶也。
Lines.L2: 求小得，未出中也。
Lines.L3: 來之坎坎，終无功也。
Lines.L4: 樽酒簋貳，剛柔際也。
Lines.L5: 坎不盈，中未大也。
Lines.L6: 上六失道，凶三歲也。

Scripture.Hexagram: 坎：习坎，有孚，维心亨，行有尚。

Lines.L1: 初六：习坎，入于坎窞，凶。
Lines.L2: 九二：坎有险，求小得。
Lines.L3: 六三：来之坎坎，险且枕，入于坎窞，勿用。
Lines.L4: 六四：樽酒簋贰，用缶，纳约自牖，终无咎。
Lines.L5: 九五：坎不盈，祗既平，无咎。
Lines.L6: 上六：系用徽纆，置于丛棘，三岁不得，凶。

Exegesis.Judgment: 习坎，重险也。水流而不盈，行险而不失其信。维心亨，乃以刚中也。行有尚，往有功也。天险不可升也，地险山川丘陵也，王公设险以守其国，坎之时用大矣哉！

Imagery.Hexagram: 水洊至，习坎；君子以常德行，习教事。

Lines.L1: 习坎入坎，失道凶也。
Lines.L2: 求小得，未出中也。
Lines.L3: 来之坎坎，终无功也。
Lines.L4: 樽酒簋贰，刚柔际也。
Lines.L5: 坎不盈，中未大也。
Lines.L6: 上六失道，凶三岁也。

Scripture.Hexagram:
The Abysmal repeated.
If you are sincere, you have success in your heart,
And whatever you do succeeds.

Lines.L1:
Six at the beginning means:
Repetition of the Abysmal.
In the abyss one falls into a pit.
Misfortune.
Lines.L2:
Nine in the second place means:
The abyss is dangerous.
One should strive to attain small things only.
Lines.L3:
Six in the third place means:
Forward and backward, abyss on abyss.
In danger like this, pause at first and wait,
Otherwise you will fall into a pit in the abyss.
Do not act in this way.
Lines.L4:
Six in the fourth place means:
A jug of wine, a bowl of rice with it;
Earthen vessels
Simply handed in through the window.
There is certainly no blame in this.
Lines.L5:
Nine in the fifth place means:
The abyss is not filled to overflowing,
It is filled only to the rim.
No blame.
Lines.L6:
Six at the top means:
Bound with cords and ropes,
Shut in between thorn-hedged prison walls:
For three years one does not find the way.
Misfortune.

Exegesis.Judgment:
The Abysmal repeated is twofold danger. Water flows on and nowhere piles up; it goes through dangerous places, never losing its dependability.
“You have success in your heart,” for the firm form the middle.
“Whatever you do succeeds”: advancing brings about achievements.
The danger of heaven lies in the fact that one cannot climb it. The dangers of earth are the mountains and rivers, hills and heights. The kings and princes make use of danger to protect their realms.
The effects of the time of danger are truly great.

Imagery.Hexagram:
Water flows on uninterruptedly and reaches its goal:
The image of the Abysmal repeated.
Thus the superior man walks in lasting virtue
And carries on the business of teaching.

Lines.L1:
Six at the beginning:
a) Repetition of the Abysmal.
In the abyss one falls into a pit.
Misfortune.
b) “Repetition of the Abysmal.” One falls into the abyss because one has lost the way; this brings misfortune.
Lines.L2:
Nine in the second place:
a) The abyss is dangerous.
One should strive to attain small things only.
b) “One should strive to attain small things only.” For the middle has not yet been passed.
Lines.L3:
Six in the third place:
a) Forward and backward, abyss on abyss.
In danger like this, pause at first and wait,
Otherwise you will fall into a pit in the abyss.
Do not act in this way.
b) “Forward and backward, abyss on abyss”: here any effort ends up as impossible.
Lines.L4:
Six in the fourth place:
a) A jug of wine, a bowl of rice with it;
Earthen vessels
Simply handed in through the window.
There is certainly no blame in this.
b) “A jug of wine, a bowl of rice with it.” It is the boundary line between firm and yielding.
Lines.L5:
Nine in the fifth place:
a) The abyss is not filled to overflowing,
It is filled only to the rim.
No blame.
b) “The abyss is not filled to overflowing,” for the central line is not yet great.
Lines.L6:
Six at the top:
a) Bound with cords and ropes,
Shut in between thorn-hedged prison walls:
For three years one does not find the way.
Misfortune.
b) The six at the top has lost the way. This misfortune continues for three years.

Exegesis.Miscellaneous: THE ABYSMAL is directed downward.
Exegesis.Sequence: Things cannot be permanently in an overweighted state. Hence there follows the hexagram of THE ABYSMAL. The Abysmal means a pit.

Scripture.Hexagram: Khan, here repeated, shows the possession of sincerity, through which the mind is penetrating. Action (in accordance with this) will be of high value.

Lines.L1: 1. The first SIX, divided, shows its subject in the double defile, and (yet) entering a cavern within it. There will be evil.
Lines.L2: 2. The second NINE, undivided, shows its subject in all the peril of the defile. He will, however, get a little (of the deliverance) that he seeks.
Lines.L3: 3. The third SIX, divided, shows its subject, whether he comes or goes (descends or ascends), confronted by a defile. All is peril to him and unrest. (His endeavours) will lead him into the cavern of the pit. There should be no action (in such a case).
Lines.L4: 4. The fourth SIX, divided, shows its subject (at a feast), with (simply) a bottle of spirits, and a subsidiary basket of rice, while (the cups and bowls) are (only) of earthenware. He introduces his important lessons (as his ruler's) intelligence admits. There will in the end be no error.
Lines.L5: 5. The fifth NINE, undivided, shows the water of the defile not yet full, (so that it might flow away); but order will (soon) be brought about. There will be no error.
Lines.L6: 6. The topmost SIX, divided, shows its subject bound with cords of three strands or two strands, and placed in the thicket of thorns. But in three years he does not learn the course for him to pursue. There will be evil.

Exegesis.Judgment:
XXIX. 1. Khan repeated shows us one defile succeeding another.
2. This is the nature of water;--it flows on, without accumulating its volume (so as to overflow); it pursues its way through a dangerous defile, without losing its true (nature).
3. That 'the mind is penetrating' is indicated by the strong (line) in the centre. That 'action (in accordance with this) will be of high value' tells us that advance will be followed by achievement.
4. The dangerous (height) of heaven cannot be ascended; the difficult places of the earth are mountains,rivers, hills, and mounds. Kings and princes arrange by means of such strengths, to maintain their territories. Great indeed is the use of (what is here) taught about seasons of peril.

Imagery.Hexagram: XXIX. (The representation of) water flowing on continuously forms the repeated Khan. The superior man, in accordance with this, maintains constantly the virtue (of his heart) and (the integrity of) his conduct, and practises the business of instruction.

Lines.L1: 1. 'In the double defile, he enters a cavern within it:'--he has missed his (proper) way, and there will be evil.
Lines.L2: 2. 'He will get a little (of the deliverance) that he seeks:'--he will not yet escape from his environed position.
Lines.L3: 3. 'Whether he comes or goes, he is confronted by a defile:'--he will never (in such circumstances) achieve any success.
Lines.L4: 4. '(Nothing but) a bottle of spirits and a subsidiary basket of rice:'--(these describe) the meeting at this point of (those who are represented by) the strong and weak lines.
Lines.L5: 5. 'The water in the defile is not full (so as to flow away):'--(the virtue indicated by) the central situation is not yet (sufficiently) great.
Lines.L6: 6. 'The sixth line, divided, shows its subject missing his (proper) course:'--'there will be evil for three years.'

Exegesis.Miscellaneous: 30, 29. Fire mounts in Lî; water in Khân descends.
Exegesis.Sequence: 26-30. Such accumulation having taken place, there will follow the nourishment of it; and hence Tâ Khû is followed by Î. Î denotes nourishing. Without nourishment there could be no movement, and hence Î is followed by Tâ Kwo. Things cannot for ever be in a state of extraordinary (progress); and hence Tâ Kwo is followed by Khân. Khân denotes falling into peril. When one falls into peril, he is sure to attach himself to some person or thing; and hence Khân is followed by Lî. Lî denotes being attached, or adhering, to.

Scripture.Hexagram: 離：利貞，亨。畜牝牛，吉。

Lines.L1: 初九：履錯然，敬之无咎。
Lines.L2: 六二：黃離，元吉。
Lines.L3: 九三：日昃之離，不鼓缶而歌，則大耋之嗟，凶。
Lines.L4: 九四：突如其來如，焚如，死如，棄如。
Lines.L5: 六五：出涕沱若，戚嗟若，吉。
Lines.L6: 上九：王用出征，有嘉折首，獲匪其醜，无咎。

Exegesis.Judgment: 離，麗也；日月麗乎天，百穀草木麗乎土，重明以麗乎正，乃化成天下。柔麗乎中正，故亨；是以畜牝牛吉也。

Imagery.Hexagram: 明兩作離，大人以繼明照于四方。

Lines.L1: 履錯之敬，以辟咎也。
Lines.L2: 黃離元吉，得中道也。
Lines.L3: 日昃之離，何可久也。
Lines.L4: 突如其來如，无所容也。
Lines.L5: 六五之吉，離王公也。
Lines.L6: 王用出征，以正邦也。

Scripture.Hexagram: 离：利贞，亨。畜牝牛，吉。

Lines.L1: 初九：履错然，敬之无咎。
Lines.L2: 六二：黄离，元吉。
Lines.L3: 九三：日昃之离，不鼓缶而歌，则大耋之嗟，凶。
Lines.L4: 九四：突如其来如，焚如，死如，弃如。
Lines.L5: 六五：出涕沱若，戚嗟若，吉。
Lines.L6: 上九：王用出征，有嘉折首，获匪其丑，无咎。

Exegesis.Judgment: 离，丽也；日月丽乎天，百谷草木丽乎土，重明以丽乎正，乃化成天下。柔丽乎中正，故亨；是以畜牝牛吉也。

Imagery.Hexagram: 明两作离，大人以继明照于四方。

Lines.L1: 履错之敬，以辟咎也。
Lines.L2: 黄离元吉，得中道也。
Lines.L3: 日昃之离，何可久也。
Lines.L4: 突如其来如，无所容也。
Lines.L5: 六五之吉，离王公也。
Lines.L6: 王用出征，以正邦也。

Scripture.Hexagram:
THE CLINGING. Perseverance furthers.
It brings success.
Care of the cow brings good fortune.

Lines.L1:
Nine at the beginning means:
The footprints run crisscross.
If one is seriously intent, no blame.
Lines.L2:
Six in the second place means:
Yellow light. Supreme good fortune.
Lines.L3:
Nine in the third place means:
In the light of the setting sun,
Men either beat the pot and sing
Or loudly bewail the approach of old age.
Misfortune.
Lines.L5:
Six in the fifth place means:
Tears in floods, sighing and lamenting.
Good fortune.
Lines.L6:
Nine at the top means:
The king uses him to march forth and chastise.
Then it is best to kill the leaders
And take captive the followers. No blame.

Exegesis.Judgment:
Clinging means resting on something. Sun and moon cling to heaven. Grain, plants, and trees cling to the soil.
Doubled clarity, clinging to what is right, transforms the world and perfects it.
The yielding clings to the middle and to what is right, hence it has success. Therefore it is said: “Care of the cow brings good fortune.”

Imagery.Hexagram:
That which is bright rises twice:
The image of FIRE.
Thus the great man, by perpetuating this brightness,
Illumines the four quarters of the world.

Lines.L1:
Nine at the beginning:
a) The footprints run crisscross.
If one is seriously intent, no blame.
b) Seriousness when footprints run crisscross serves in avoiding blame.
Lines.L2:
Six in the second place:
a) Yellow light. Supreme good fortune.
b) The supreme good fortune of yellow light lies in the fact that one has found the middle way.
Lines.L3:
Nine in the third place:
a) In the light of the setting sun,
Men either beat the pot and sing
Or loudly bewail the approach of old age.
Misfortune.
b) How can one wish to hold for long the light of the setting sun?
Lines.L4:
Nine in the fourth place:
a) Its coming is sudden;
It flames up, dies down, is thrown away.
b) “Its coming is sudden.” Yet in itself it has nothing that would cause it to be accepted.
Lines.L5:
Six in the fifth place:
a) Tears in floods, sighing and lamenting.
Good fortune.
b) The good fortune of the six in the fifth place clings to king and prince.
Lines.L6:
Nine at the top:
a) The king uses him to march forth and chastise.
Then it is best to kill the leaders
And take captive the followers. No blame.
b) “The king uses him to march forth and chastise”: in order to bring the country under discipline.

Exegesis.Miscellaneous: THE CLINGING is directed upward.
Exegesis.Sequence: In a pit there is certain to be something clinging within. Hence there follows the hexagram of THE CLINGING. The Clinging means resting on something.
Exegesis.Extracts: Fu Hsi made knotted cords and used them for nets and baskets in hunting and fishing. He probably took this from the hexagram of THE CLINGING.

Scripture.Hexagram: Lî indicates that, (in regard to what it denotes), it will be advantageous to be firm and correct, and that thus there will be free course and success.

Lines.L1: 1. The first NINE, undivided, shows one ready to move with confused steps. But he treads at the same time reverently, and there will be no mistake.
Lines.L2: 2. The second SIX, divided, shows its subject in his place in yellow. There will be great good fortune.
Lines.L3: 3. The third NINE, undivided, shows its subject in a position like that of the declining sun. Instead of playing on his instrument of earthenware, and singing to it, he utters the groans of an old man of eighty. There will be evil.
Lines.L4: 4. The fourth NINE, undivided, shows the manner of its subject's coming. How abrupt it is, as with fire, with death, to be rejected (by all)!
Lines.L5: 5. The fifth SIX, divided, shows its subject as one with tears flowing in torrents, and groaning in sorrow. There will be good fortune.
Lines.L6: 6. The topmost NINE, undivided, shows the king employing its subject in his punitive expeditions. Achieving admirable (merit), he breaks (only) the chiefs (of the rebels). Where his prisoners were not their associates, he does not punish. There will be no error.

Exegesis.Judgment:
XXX. Lî means being attached to. The sun and moon have their place in the sky. All the grains, grass, and trees have their place on the earth. The double brightness (of the two trigrams) adheres to what is correct, and the result is the transforming and perfecting all under the sky.
2. The weak (second line) occupies the middle and correct position, and gives the indication of 'a free and successful course;' and, moreover, 'nourishing (docility like that of) the cow' will lead to good fortune.

Imagery.Hexagram: XXX. (The trigram for) brightness, repeated, forms Lî. The great man, in accordance with this, cultivates more and more his brilliant (virtue), and diffuses its brightness over the four quarters (of the land).

Lines.L1: 1. 'The reverent attention directed to his confused steps' is the way by which error is avoided.
Lines.L2: 2. 'The great good fortune (from the subject of the second line) occupying his place in yellow' is owing to his holding the course of the due mean.
Lines.L3: 3. 'A position like that of the declining sun:'--how can it continue long?
Lines.L4: 4. 'How abrupt is the manner of his coming!'--none can bear with him.
Lines.L5: 5. 'The good fortune attached to the fifth SIX,divided),' is due to its occupying the place of a king or a prince.
Lines.L6: 6. 'The king employs him in his punitive expeditions:'--the object is to bring the regions to a correct state.

Exegesis.Miscellaneous: 30, 29. Fire mounts in Lî; water in Khân descends.
Exegesis.Sequence: 26-30. Such accumulation having taken place, there will follow the nourishment of it; and hence Tâ Khû is followed by Î. Î denotes nourishing.
