Without nourishment there could be no movement, and hence Î is followed by Tâ Kwo. Things cannot for ever be in a state of extraordinary (progress); and hence Tâ Kwo is followed by Khân. Khân denotes falling into peril. When one falls into peril, he is sure to attach himself to some person or thing; and hence Khân is followed by Lî. Lî denotes being attached, or adhering, to.

Scripture.Hexagram: 咸，亨，利貞，取女吉。

Lines.L1: 初六，咸其拇。
Lines.L2: 六二，咸其腓，凶，居吉。
Lines.L3: 九三，咸其股，執其隨，往吝。
Lines.L4: 九四，貞吉，悔亡，憧憧往來，朋從爾思。
Lines.L5: 九五，咸其脢，无悔。
Lines.L6: 上六，咸其輔頰舌。

Exegesis.Judgment: 咸，感也。柔上而剛下，二氣感應以相與，止而說，男下女，是以亨利貞，取女吉也。天地感而萬物化生，聖人感人心而天下和平，觀其所感，而天地萬物之情可見矣。

Imagery.Hexagram: 山上有澤，咸，君子以虛受人。

Lines.L1: 咸其拇，志在外也。
Lines.L2: 雖凶居吉，順不害也。
Lines.L3: 咸其股，亦不處也。志在隨人，所執下也。
Lines.L4: 貞吉悔亡，未感害也。憧憧往來，未光大也。
Lines.L5: 咸其脢，志末也。
Lines.L6: 咸其輔頰舌，滕口說也。

Scripture.Hexagram: 咸，亨，利贞，取女吉。

Lines.L1: 初六，咸其拇。
Lines.L2: 六二，咸其腓，凶，居吉。
Lines.L3: 九三，咸其股，执其随，往吝。
Lines.L4: 九四，贞吉，悔亡，憧憧往来，朋从尔思。
Lines.L5: 九五，咸其脢，无悔。
Lines.L6: 上六，咸其辅颊舌。

Exegesis.Judgment: 咸，感也。柔上而刚下，二气感应以相与，止而说，男下女，是以亨利贞，取女吉也。天地感而万物化生，圣人感人心而天下和平，观其所感，而天地万物之情可见矣。

Imagery.Hexagram: 山上有泽，咸，君子以虚受人。

Lines.L1: 咸其拇，志在外也。
Lines.L2: 虽凶居吉，顺不害也。
Lines.L3: 咸其股，亦不处也。志在随人，所执下也。
Lines.L4: 贞吉悔亡，未感害也。憧憧往来，未光大也。
Lines.L5: 咸其脢，志末也。
Lines.L6: 咸其辅颊舌，滕口说也。

Scripture.Hexagram:
Influence. Success.
Perseverance furthers.
To take a maiden to wife brings good fortune.

Lines.L1:
Six at the beginning means:
The influence shows itself in the big toe.
Lines.L2:
Six in the second place means:
The influence shows itself in the calves of the legs.
Misfortune.
Tarrying brings good fortune.
Lines.L3:
Nine in the third place means:
The influence shows itself in the thighs.
Holds to that which follows it.
To continue is humiliating.
Lines.L4:
Nine in the fourth place means:
Perseverance brings good fortune.
Remorse disappears.
If a man is agitated in mind,
And his thoughts go hither and thither,
Only those friends
On whom he fixes his conscious thoughts
Will follow.
Lines.L5:
Nine in the fifth place means:
The influence shows itself in the back of the neck.
No remorse.
Lines.L6:
Six at the top means:
The influence shows itself in the jaws, cheeks, and tongue.

Exegesis.Judgment:
INFLUENCE means stimulation. The weak is above, the strong below. The forces of the two stimulate and respond to each other, so that they unite.
Keeping Still and joyousness.1 The masculine subordinates itself to the feminine. Hence it is said:
“Success. Perseverance furthers. To take a maiden to wife brings good fortune.”
Heaven and earth stimulate each other, and all things take shape and come into being. The holy man stimulates the hearts of men, and the world attains peace and rest. If we contemplate the outgoing stimulating influences, we can know the nature of heaven and earth and all beings.

Imagery.Hexagram:
A lake on the mountain:
The image of influence.
Thus the superior man encourages people to approach him
By his readiness to receive them.2

Lines.L1:
Six at the beginning:
a) The influence shows itself in the big toe.
b) Influence in the big toe: the will is directed outward.
Lines.L2:
Six in the second place:
a) The influence shows itself in the calves of the legs.
Misfortune.
Tarrying brings good fortune.
b) Even though misfortune threatens, tarrying brings good fortune. One does not come to harm through devotion.
Lines.L3:
Nine in the third place:
a) The influence shows itself in the thighs.
Holds to that which follows it.
To continue is humiliating.
b) “The influence shows itself in the thighs.” For he cannot keep still.
When the will is directed to things that one’s followers hold to, this is very base.
Lines.L4:
Nine in the fourth place:
a) Perseverance brings good fortune.
Remorse disappears.
If a man is agitated in mind,
And his thoughts go hither and thither,
Only those friends
On whom he fixes his conscious thoughts
Will follow.
b) “Perseverance brings good fortune. Remorse disappears.” Because in this way one does not stir up anything injurious.
Lines.L5:
Nine in the fifth place:
a) The influence shows itself in the back of the neck.
b) “The influence shows itself in the back of the neck.”
The will is directed to the ramifications.
Lines.L6:
Six at the top:
a) The influence shows itself in the jaws, cheeks, and tongue.
b) “The influence shows itself in the jaws, cheeks, and tongue.” He opens his mouth and chatters.

Exegesis.Miscellaneous: INFLUENCE fulfills itself quickly.
Exegesis.Sequence:
After there are heaven and earth, there are the individual things.
After individual things have come into being, there are the two sexes.
After there are male and female, there is the relationship between husband and wife.
After the relationship between husband and wife exists, there is the relationship between father and son.
After the relationship between father and son exists, there is the relationship between prince and servitor.
After the relationship between prince and servitor exists, there is the difference between superior and inferior.
After the difference between superior and inferior exists, the rules of propriety and of right can operate.

Scripture.Hexagram: Hsien indicates that, (on the fulfilment of the conditions implied in it), there will be free course and success. Its advantageousness will depend on being firm and correct, (as) in marrying a young lady. There will be good fortune.

Lines.L1: 1. The first SIX, divided, shows one moving his great toes.
Lines.L2: 2. The second SIX, divided, shows one moving the calves of his leg. There will be evil. If he abide (quiet in his place), there will be good fortune.
Lines.L3: 3. The third NINE, undivided, shows one moving his thighs, and keeping close hold of those whom he follows. Going forward (in this way) will cause regret.
Lines.L4: 4. The fourth NINE, undivided, shows that firm correctness which will lead to good fortune, and prevent all occasion for repentance. If its subject be unsettled in his movements, only his friends will follow his purpose.
Lines.L5: 5. The fifth NINE, undivided, shows one moving the flesh along the spine above the heart. There will be no occasion for repentance.
Lines.L6: 6. The sixth SIX, divided, shows one moving his jaws and tongue.

Exegesis.Judgment:
XXXI. 1. Hsien is here used in the sense of Kan, meaning (mutually) influencing.
2. The weak (trigram) above, and the strong one below; their two influences moving and responding to each other, and thereby forming a union; the repression (of the one) and the satisfaction (of the other); (with their relative position), where the male is placed below the female:--all these things convey the notion of 'a free and successful course (on the fulfilment of the conditions), while the advantage will depend on being firm and correct, as in marrying a young lady, and there will be good fortune.'
3. Heaven and earth exert their influences, and there ensue the transformation and production of all things. The sages influence the minds of men, and the result is harmony and peace all under the sky. If we look at (the method and issues) of those influences, the true character of heaven and earth and of all things can be seen.

Imagery.Hexagram: XXXI. (The trigram representing) a mountain and above it that for (the waters of) a marsh form Hsien. The superior man, in accordance with this, keeps his mind free from pre-occupation, and open to receive (the influences of) others.

Lines.L1: 1. 'He moves his great toe:'--his mind is set on what is beyond (himself).
Lines.L2: 2. Though 'there would be evil; yet, if he abide (quiet) in his place, there will be good fortune:'--through compliance (with the circumstances of his condition and place) there will be no injury.
Lines.L3: 3. 'He moves his thighs:'--he still does not (want to) rest in his place. His will is set on 'following others:'--what he holds in his grasp is low.
Lines.L4: 4. 'Firm correctness will lead to good fortune,and prevent all occasion for repentance:'--there has not yet been any harm from (a selfish wish to) influence. 'He is unsettled in his movements:'(his power to influence) is not yet either brilliant or great.
Lines.L5: 5. 'He (tries to) move the flesh along the spine above the heart:'--his aim is trivial.
Lines.L6: 6. 'He moves his jaws and tongue:'--he (only) talks with loquacious mouth.

Exegesis.Sequence: 31, 32. Heaven and earth existing, all (material) things then got their existence. All (material) things having existence, afterwards there came male and female. From the existence of male and female there came afterwards husband and wife. From husband and wife there came father and son. From father and son there came ruler and minister. From ruler and minister there came high and low. When (the distinction of) high and low had existence, afterwards came the arrangements of propriety and righteousness. The rule for the relation of husband and wife is that it should be long-enduring. Hence Hsien is followed by Hăng. Hăng denotes long enduring.

Scripture.Hexagram: 恆：亨，无咎，利貞，利有攸往。

Lines.L1: 初六：浚恆，貞凶，无攸利。
Lines.L2: 九二：悔亡。
Lines.L3: 九三：不恆其德，或承之羞，貞吝。
Lines.L4: 九四：田无禽。
Lines.L5: 六五：恆其德，貞，婦人吉，夫子凶。
Lines.L6: 上六：振恆，凶。

Exegesis.Judgment: 恆，久也。剛上而柔下，雷風相與，巽而動，剛柔皆應，恆。恆亨无咎，利貞；久於其道也，天地之道，恆久而不已也。利有攸往，終則有始也。日月得天，而能久照，四時變化，而能久成，聖人久於其道，而天下化成；觀其所恆，而天地萬物之情可見矣！

Imagery.Hexagram: 雷風，恆；君子以立不易方。

Lines.L1: 浚恆之凶，始求深也。
Lines.L2: 九二悔亡，能久中也。
Lines.L3: 不恆其德，无所容也。
Lines.L4: 久非其位，安得禽也。
Lines.L5: 婦人貞吉，從一而終也。夫子制義，從婦凶也。
Lines.L6: 振恆在上，大无功也。

Scripture.Hexagram: 恒：亨，无咎，利贞，利有攸往。

Lines.L1: 初六：浚恒，贞凶，无攸利。
Lines.L2: 九二：悔亡。
Lines.L3: 九三：不恒其德，或承之羞，贞吝。
Lines.L4: 九四：田无禽。
Lines.L5: 六五：恒其德，贞，妇人吉，夫子凶。
Lines.L6: 上六：振恒，凶。

Exegesis.Judgment: 恒，久也。刚上而柔下，雷风相与，巽而动，刚柔皆应，恒。恒亨无咎，利贞；久于其道也，天地之道，恒久而不已也。利有攸往，终则有始也。日月得天，而能久照，四时变化，而能久成，圣人久于其道，而天下化成；观其所恒，而天地万物之情可见矣！

Imagery.Hexagram: 雷风，恒；君子以立不易方。

Lines.L1: 浚恒之凶，始求深也。
Lines.L2: 九二悔亡，能久中也。
Lines.L3: 不恒其德，无所容也。
Lines.L4: 久非其位，安得禽也。
Lines.L5: 妇人贞吉，从一而终也。夫子制义，从妇凶也。
Lines.L6: 振恒在上，大无功也。

Scripture.Hexagram:
DURATION. Success. No blame.
Perseverance furthers.
It furthers one to have somewhere to go.

Lines.L1:
Six at the beginning means:
Seeking duration too hastily brings misfortune persistently.
Nothing that would further.
Lines.L2:
Nine in the second place means:
Remorse disappears.
Lines.L3:
Nine in the third place means:
He who does not give duration to his character
Meets with disgrace.
Persistent humiliation.
Lines.L4:
Nine in the fourth place means:
No game in the field.
Lines.L5:
Six in the fifth place means:
Giving duration to one’s character through perseverance.
This is good fortune for a woman, misfortune for a man.
Lines.L6:
Six at the top means:
Restlessness as an enduring condition brings misfortune.

Exegesis.Judgment:
DURATION means that which lasts long. The strong is above, the weak below; thunder and wind work together.
Gentle and in motion. The strong and the weak all correspond: this signifies duration.
“Success. No blame. Perseverance furthers”: this means lasting perseverance in one’s course. The course of heaven and earth is enduring and long and never ends.
“It furthers one to have somewhere to go.” This means that an end is always followed by a new beginning.
Sun and moon have heaven and can therefore shine forever. The four seasons change and transform, and thus can forever bring to completion. The holy man remains forever in his course, and the world reshapes itself to completion. If we meditate on what gives duration to a thing, we can understand the nature of heaven and earth and of all beings.
The organization of the hexagram shows the strong Chên above and the weak Sun below; this is the enduring condition in the world. Here the eldest son and the eldest daughter are united in marriage, in contrast to the situation in the preceding hexagram, which represents entering into marriage.
The images show thunder, which is carried still farther by the power of wind, and wind, which is strengthened by the power of thunder. Their combined action imparts duration to both. The attribute of the trigram Sun is gentleness, that of Chên is movement. The outer movement, supported within by devotion, is likewise such that it is capable of duration.

Imagery.Hexagram:
Thunder and wind: the image of DURATION.
Thus the superior man stands firm
And does not change his direction.

Lines.L1:
Six at the beginning:
a) Seeking duration too hastily brings misfortune persistently.
Nothing that would further.
b) The misfortune of seeking duration too hastily arises from wanting too much immediately at the outset.
Lines.L2:
Nine in the second place:
a) Remorse disappears.
b) Remorse disappears for the nine in the second place, because it is permanently central.
Lines.L3:
Nine in the third place:
a) He who does not give duration to his character
Meets with disgrace.
Persistent humiliation.
b) “He who does not give duration to his character” meets with no toleration.
Lines.L4:
Nine in the fourth place:
a) No game in the field.
b) When one is forever absent from one’s place, how can one find game?
Lines.L5:
Six in the fifth place:
a) Giving duration to one’s character through perseverance.
This is good fortune for a woman, misfortune for a man.
b) Perseverance brings good fortune for a woman, because she follows one man all her life. A man must hold to his duty; if he follows the woman, the results are bad.
Lines.L6:
Six at the top:
a) Restlessness as an enduring condition brings misfortune.
b) Restlessness as an enduring condition in a high position is wholly without merit.

Exegesis.Miscellaneous: DURATION means that which lasts long.
Exegesis.Sequence: The way of husband and wife must not be other than long-lasting. Hence there follows the hexagram of DURATION. Duration means long-lasting.
Exegesis.Extracts: DURATION brings about firmness of character. DURATION shows manifold experiences without satiety. DURATION brings about unity of character.

Scripture.Hexagram: Hăng indicates successful progress and no error (in what it denotes). But the advantage will come from being firm and correct; and movement in any direction whatever will be advantageous.

Lines.L1: 1. The first SIX, divided, shows its subject deeply (desirous) of long continuance. Even with firm correctness there will be evil; there will be no advantage in any way.
Lines.L2: 2. The second NINE, undivided, shows all occasion for repentance disappearing.
Lines.L3: 3. The third NINE, undivided, shows one who does not continuously maintain his virtue. There are those who will impute this to him as a disgrace. However firm he may be, there will be ground for regret.
Lines.L4: 4. The fourth NINE, undivided, shows a field where there is no game.
Lines.L5: 5. The fifth SIX, divided, shows its subject continuously maintaining the virtue indicated by it. In a wife this will be fortunate; in a husband, evil.
Lines.L6: 6. The topmost SIX, divided, shows its subject exciting himself to long continuance. There will be evil.

Exegesis.Judgment:
XXXII. 1. Hăng denotes long continuance. The strong (trigram) is above, and the weak one below; (they are the symbols of) thunder and wind,which are in mutual communication; (they have the qualities of) docility and motive force; their strong and weak (lines) all respond, each to the other:--these things are all found in Hăng.
2. (When it is said that) 'Hăng indicates successful progress and no error (in what it denotes); but the advantage will come from being firm and correct,' this indicates that there must be long continuance in its way of operation. The way of heaven and earth is to be long continued in their operation without stopping.
3. (When it is said that) 'Movement in any direction whatever will be advantageous,' this implies that when (the moving power) is spent, it will begin again.
4. The sun and moon, realising in themselves (the course of Heaven), can perpetuate their shining. The four seasons, by their changing and transforming, can perpetuate their production (of things). The sages persevere long in their course, and all under the sky are transformed and perfect. When we look at what they continue doing long, the natural tendencies of heaven, earth, and all things can be seen.

Imagery.Hexagram: XXXII. (The trigram representing) thunder and that for wind form Hăng. The superior man, in accordance with this, stands firm, and does not change his method (of operation).

Lines.L1: 1. 'The evil attached to the deep desire for long continuance (in the subject of the first line)' arises from the deep seeking for it at the commencement (of things).
Lines.L2: 2. 'All occasion for repentance on the part of the subject of the second NINE, (undivided,), disappears:'--he can abide long in the due mean.
Lines.L3: 3. 'He does not continuously maintain his virtue:'--nowhere will he be borne with.
Lines.L4: 4. (Going) for long to what is not his proper place, how can he get game?
Lines.L5: 5. 'Such firm correctness in a wife will be fortunate:'--it is hers to the end of life to follow with an unchanged mind. The husband must decide what is right, and lay down the rule accordingly:--for him to follow (like) a wife is evil.
Lines.L6: 6. 'The subject of the topmost line is exciting himself to long continuance:'--far will he be from achieving merit.

Exegesis.Sequence:
31, 32. Heaven and earth existing, all (material) things then got their existence. All (material) things having existence, afterwards there came male and female. From the existence of male and female there came afterwards husband and wife. From husband and wife there came father and son. From father and son there came ruler and minister. From ruler and minister there came high and low. When (the distinction of) high and low had existence, afterwards came the arrangements of propriety and righteousness. The rule for the relation of husband and wife is that it should be long-enduring. Hence Hsien is followed by Hăng. Hăng denotes long enduring.
32-37. Things cannot long abide in the same place; and hence Hăng is followed by Thun. Thun denotes withdrawing. Things cannot be for ever withdrawn; and hence Thun is succeeded by Tâ Kwang. Things cannot remain forever (simply) in the state of vigour; and hence Tâ Kwang is succeeded by Žin. Žin denotes advancing. (But) advancing is sure to lead to being wounded; and hence Žin is succeeded by Ming Î. Î denotes being wounded. He who is wounded abroad will return to his home; and hence Ming Î is followed by Kiâ Zăn.

Scripture.Hexagram: 遯：亨，小利貞。

Lines.L1: 初六：遯尾，厲，勿用有攸往。
Lines.L2: 六二：執之用黃牛之革，莫之勝說。
Lines.L3: 九三：係遯，有疾厲，畜臣妾吉。
Lines.L4: 九四：好遯，君子吉，小人否。
Lines.L5: 九五：嘉遯，貞吉。
Lines.L6: 上九：肥遯，无不利。

Exegesis.Judgment: 遯亨，遯而亨也。剛當位而應，與時行也。小利貞，浸而長也。遯之時義大矣哉！

Imagery.Hexagram: 天下有山，遯；君子以遠小人，不惡而嚴。

Lines.L1: 遯尾之厲，不往何災也。
Lines.L2: 執用黃牛，固志也。
Lines.L3: 係遯之厲，有疾憊也。畜臣妾吉，不可大事也。
Lines.L4: 君子好遯，小人否也。
Lines.L5: 嘉遯貞吉，以正志也。
Lines.L6: 肥遯，无不利；无所疑也。

Scripture.Hexagram: 遯：亨，小利贞。

Lines.L1: 初六：遯尾，厉，勿用有攸往。
Lines.L2: 六二：执之用黄牛之革，莫之胜说。
Lines.L3: 九三：系遯，有疾厉，畜臣妾吉。
Lines.L4: 九四：好遯，君子吉，小人否。
Lines.L5: 九五：嘉遯，贞吉。
Lines.L6: 上九：肥遯，无不利。

Exegesis.Judgment: 遯亨，遯而亨也。刚当位而应，与时行也。小利贞，浸而长也。遯之时义大矣哉！

Imagery.Hexagram: 天下有山，遯；君子以远小人，不恶而严。

Lines.L1: 遯尾之厉，不往何灾也。
Lines.L2: 执用黄牛，固志也。
Lines.L3: 系遯之厉，有疾惫也。畜臣妾吉，不可大事也。
Lines.L4: 君子好遯，小人否也。
Lines.L5: 嘉遯贞吉，以正志也。
Lines.L6: 肥遯，无不利；无所疑也。

Scripture.Hexagram:
RETREAT. Success.
In what is small, perseverance furthers.

Lines.L1:
Six at the beginning means:
At the tail in retreat. This is dangerous.
One must not wish to undertake anything.
Lines.L2:
Six in the second place means:
He holds him fast with yellow oxhide.
No one can tear him loose.
Lines.L3:
Nine in the third place means:
A halted retreat
Is nerve-wracking and dangerous.
To retain people as men- and maidservants
Brings good fortune.
Lines.L4:
Nine in the fourth place means:
Voluntary retreat brings good fortune to the superior man
And downfall to the inferior man.
Lines.L5:
Nine in the fifth place means:
Friendly retreat. Perseverance brings good fortune.
Lines.L6:
Nine at the top means:
Cheerful retreat. Everything serves to further.

Exegesis.Judgment:
“RETREAT. Success”: this means that success lies in retreating.
The firm is in the appropriate place and finds correspondence. This means that one is in accord with the time.
“In what is small, perseverance furthers”: this means that it is pressing forward, and on the increase.
Great indeed is the meaning of the time of RETREAT.

Imagery.Hexagram:
Mountain under heaven: the image of RETREAT.
Thus the superior man keeps the inferior man at a distance,
Not angrily but with reserve.

Lines.L1:
Six at the beginning:
a) At the tail in retreat. This is dangerous.
One must not wish to undertake anything.
b) If one undertakes nothing while exposed to the danger of the retreating tail, what misfortune could befall one?
Lines.L2:
Six in the second place:
a) He holds him fast with yellow oxhide.
No one can tear him loose.
b) “He holds him fast with yellow oxhide”: this means a firm will.
Lines.L3:
Nine in the third place:
a) A halted retreat
Is nerve-wracking and dangerous.
To retain people as men- and maidservants
Brings good fortune.
b) The danger of a halted retreat is nerve-wracking; this brings fatigue.
“To retain people as men- and maidservants brings good fortune.” True enough, but one cannot use them in great things.
Lines.L4:
Nine in the fourth place:
a) Voluntary retreat brings good fortune to the superior man
And downfall to the inferior man.
b) The superior man retreats voluntarily; this brings downfall for the inferior man.
Lines.L5:
Nine in the fifth place:
a) Friendly retreat. Perseverance brings good fortune.
b) “Friendly retreat. Perseverance brings good fortune,” because the will thereby reaches a correct decision.
Lines.L6:
Nine at the top:
a) Cheerful retreat. Everything serves to further.
b) “Cheerful retreat. Everything serves to further,” because there is no longer any possibility of doubt.

Exegesis.Miscellaneous: RETREAT means withdrawing.
Exegesis.Sequence: Things cannot abide forever in their place: hence there follows the hexagram of RETREAT. Retreat means withdrawing.

Scripture.Hexagram: Thun indicates successful progress (in its circumstances). To a small extent it will (still) be advantageous to be firm and correct.

Lines.L1: 1. The first SIX, divided, shows a retiring tail. The position is perilous. No movement in any direction should be made.
Lines.L2: 2. The second SIX, divided, shows its subject holding (his purpose) fast as if by a (thong made from the) hide of a yellow ox, which cannot be broken.
Lines.L3: 3. The third NINE, undivided, shows one retiring but bound,--to his distress and peril. (If he were to deal with his binders as in) nourishing a servant or concubine, it would be fortunate for him.
Lines.L4: 4. The fourth NINE, undivided, shows its subject retiring notwithstanding his likings. In a superior man this will lead to good fortune; a small man cannot attain to this.
Lines.L5: 5. The fifth NINE, undivided, shows its subject retiring in an admirable way. With firm correctness there will be good fortune.
Lines.L6: 6. The sixth NINE, undivided, shows its subject retiring in a noble way. It will be advantageous in every respect.

Exegesis.Judgment:
XXXIII. 1. 'Thun indicates successful progress:'--that is, in the very retiring which Thun denotes there is such progress. The strong (line) is in the ruling place, (the fifth), and is properly responded to (by the second line). The action takes place according to (the requirement of) the time.
2. 'To a small extent it will (still) be advantageous to be firm and correct:'--(the small men) are gradually encroaching and advancing.
3. Great indeed is the significance of (what is required to be done in) the time that necessitates retiring.

Imagery.Hexagram: XXXIII. (The trigram representing) the sky and below it that for a mountain form Thun. The superior man, in accordance with this, keeps small men at a distance, not by showing that he hates them, but by his own. dignified gravity.

Lines.L1: 1. There is 'the perilousness of the position shown by the retiring tail:'--but if 'no movement' be made, what disaster can there be?
Lines.L2: 2. 'He holds it as; by (a thong from the hide of) a yellow ox:'--his purpose is firm.
Lines.L3: 3. 'The peril connected with the case of one retiring, though bound,' is due to the (consequent) distress and exhaustion. 'If he were (to deal as in) nourishing a servant or concubine, it would be fortunate for him:'--but a great affair cannot be dealt with in this way.
Lines.L4: 4. 'A superior man retires notwithstanding his likings; a small man cannot attain to this.'
Lines.L5: 5. 'He retires in an admirable way, and with firm correctness there will be good fortune:'--this is due to the rectitude of his purpose.
Lines.L6: 6. 'He retires in a noble way, and his doing so will be advantageous in every respect:'--he who does so has no doubts about his course.

Exegesis.Miscellaneous: 34, 33. Tâ Kwang stops here as right; withdraws Thun there.
Exegesis.Sequence: 32-37. Things cannot long abide in the same place; and hence Hăng is followed by Thun. Thun denotes withdrawing. Things cannot be for ever withdrawn; and hence Thun is succeeded by Tâ Kwang. Things cannot remain forever (simply) in the state of vigour; and hence Tâ Kwang is succeeded by Žin. Žin denotes advancing. (But) advancing is sure to lead to being wounded; and hence Žin is succeeded by Ming Î. Î denotes being wounded. He who is wounded abroad will return to his home; and hence Ming Î is followed by Kiâ Zăn.

English.WilhelmBaynes: Ta Chuang / The Power of the Great

Scripture.Hexagram: 大壯：利貞。

Lines.L1: 初九：壯于趾，征凶，有孚。
Lines.L2: 九二：貞吉。
Lines.L3: 九三：小人用壯，君子用罔，貞厲。羝羊觸藩，羸其角。
Lines.L4: 九四：貞吉悔亡，藩決不羸，壯于大輿之輹。
Lines.L5: 六五：喪羊于易，无悔。
Lines.L6: 上六：羝羊觸藩，不能退，不能遂，无攸利，艱則吉。

Exegesis.Judgment: 大壯，大者壯也。剛以動，故壯。大壯利貞；大者正也。正大而天地之情可見矣！

Imagery.Hexagram: 雷在天上，大壯；君子以非禮勿履。

Lines.L1: 壯于趾，其孚窮也。
Lines.L2: 九二貞吉，以中也。
Lines.L3: 小人用壯，君子罔也。
Lines.L4: 藩決不羸，尚往也。
Lines.L5: 喪羊于易，位不當也。
Lines.L6: 不能退，不能遂，不祥也。艱則吉，咎不長也。

Scripture.Hexagram: 大壮：利贞。

Lines.L1: 初九：壮于趾，征凶，有孚。
Lines.L2: 九二：贞吉。
Lines.L3: 九三：小人用壮，君子用罔，贞厉。羝羊触藩，羸其角。
Lines.L4: 九四：贞吉悔亡，藩决不羸，壮于大舆之輹。
Lines.L5: 六五：丧羊于易，无悔。
Lines.L6: 上六：羝羊触藩，不能退，不能遂，无攸利，艰则吉。

Exegesis.Judgment: 大壮，大者壮也。刚以动，故壮。大壮利贞；大者正也。正大而天地之情可见矣！

Imagery.Hexagram: 雷在天上，大壮；君子以非礼勿履。

Lines.L1: 壮于趾，其孚穷也。
Lines.L2: 九二贞吉，以中也。
Lines.L3: 小人用壮，君子罔也。
Lines.L4: 藩决不羸，尚往也。
Lines.L5: 丧羊于易，位不当也。
Lines.L6: 不能退，不能遂，不祥也。艰则吉，咎不长也。

Scripture.Hexagram: THE POWER OF THE GREAT. Perseverance furthers.

Lines.L1:
Nine at the beginning means:
Power in the toes.
Continuing brings misfortune.
This is certainly true.
Lines.L2:
Nine in the second place means:
Perseverance brings good fortune.
Lines.L3:
Nine in the third place means:
The inferior man works through power.
The superior man does not act thus.
To continue is dangerous.
A goat butts against a hedge
And gets its horns entangled.
Lines.L4:
Nine in the fourth place means:
Perseverance brings good fortune.
Remorse disappears.
The hedge opens; there is no entanglement.
Power depends upon the axle of a big cart.
Lines.L5:
Six in the fifth place means:
Loses the goat with ease.
No remorse.
Lines.L6:
Six at the top means:
A goat butts against a hedge.
It cannot go backward, it cannot go forward.
Nothing serves to further.
If one notes the difficulty, this brings good fortune.

Exegesis.Judgment:
THE POWER OF THE GREAT means that the great are powerful. Strong in movement—this is the basis of power.
“THE POWER OF THE GREAT. Perseverance furthers,” for what is great must be right.
Great and right: thus we can behold the relations of heaven and earth.

Imagery.Hexagram:
Thunder in heaven above:
The image of THE POWER OF THE GREAT.
Thus the superior man does not tread upon paths
That do not accord with established order.

Lines.L1:
Nine at the beginning:
a) Power in the toes.
Continuing brings misfortune.
This is certainly true.
b) “Power in the toes.” This certainly leads to failure.
Lines.L2:
Nine in the second place:
a) Perseverance brings good fortune.
b) The nine in the second place finds good fortune through perseverance because it is in a central place.
Lines.L3:
Nine in the third place:
a) The inferior man works through power.
The superior man does not act thus.
To continue is dangerous.
A goat butts against a hedge
And gets its horns entangled.
b) The inferior man uses his power. This the superior man does not do.
Lines.L4:
Nine in the fourth place:
a) Perseverance brings good fortune.
Remorse disappears.
The hedge opens; there is no entanglement.
Power depends upon the axle of a big cart.
b) “The hedge opens; there is no entanglement.” It can go upward.
Lines.L5:
Six in the fifth place:
a) Loses the goat with ease.
No remorse.
b) “Loses the goat with ease,” because the place is not the appropriate one.
Lines.L6:
Six at the top:
a) A goat butts against a hedge.
It cannot go backward, it cannot go forward.
Nothing serves to further.
If one notes the difficulty, this brings good fortune.
b) “It cannot go backward, it cannot go forward.” This does not bring luck.
“If one notes the difficulty, this brings good fortune.”
The mistake is not lasting.

Exegesis.Miscellaneous: The meaning of THE POWER OF THE GREAT shows itself in the fact that one pauses.
Exegesis.Sequence: Things cannot retreat forever, hence there follows THE POWER OF THE GREAT.
Exegesis.Extracts: In the most ancient times people dwelt in caves and lived in forests. The holy men of a later time made the change to buildings. At the top was a ridgepole, and sloping down from it there was a roof, to keep off wind and rain. They probably took this from the hexagram of THE POWER OF THE GREAT.

Scripture.Hexagram: Tâ Kwang indicates that (under the conditions which it symbolises) it will be advantageous to be firm and correct.

Lines.L1: 1. The first NINE, undivided, shows its subject manifesting his strength in his toes. But advance will lead to evil,--most certainly.
Lines.L2: 2. The second NINE, undivided, shows that with firm correctness there will be good fortune.
Lines.L3: 3. The third NINE, undivided, shows, in the case of a small man, one using all his strength; and in the case of a superior man, one whose rule is not to do so. Even with firm correctness the position would be perilous. (The exercise of strength in it might be compared to the case of) a ram butting against a fence, and getting his horns entangled.
Lines.L4: 4. The fourth NINE, undivided, shows (a case in which) firm correctness leads to good fortune, and occasion for repentance disappears. (We see) the fence opened without the horns being entangled. The strength is like that in the wheel‐spokes of a large waggon.
Lines.L5: 5. The fifth SIX, divided, shows one who loses his ram(‐like strength) in the ease of his position. (But) there will be no occasion for repentance.
Lines.L6: 6. The sixth SIX, divided, shows (one who may be compared to) the ram butting against the fence, and unable either to retreat, or to advance as he would fain do. There will not be advantage in any respect; but if he realise the difficulty (of his position), there will be good fortune.

Exegesis.Judgment:
XXXIV. 1. In Tâ Kwang we see that which is great becoming strong. We have the (trigram) denoting strength directing that which denotes movement, and hence (the whole) is expressive of vigour.
2. 'Tâ Kwang indicates that it will be advantageous to be firm and correct:'--that which is great (should be) correct. Given correctness and greatness (in their highest degree), and the character and tendencies of heaven and earth can be seen.

Imagery.Hexagram: XXXIV. (The trigram representing) heaven and above it that for thunder form Tâ Kwang. The superior man, in accordance with this, does not take a step which is not according to propriety.

Lines.L1: 1. 'He manifests his vigour in his toes:'--this will certainly lead to exhaustion.
Lines.L2: 2. 'The second NINE, (undivided), shows that with firm correctness there will be good fortune:'--this is due to its being in the centre, (and its subject exemplifying the due mean).
Lines.L3: 3. 'The small man uses all his strength; in the case of the superior man it is his rule not to do so.'
Lines.L4: 4. 'The fence is opened and the horns are not entangled:'--(the subject of the line) still advances.
Lines.L5: 5. 'He loses his ram and hardly perceives it:'--he is not in his appropriate place.
Lines.L6: 6. 'He is unable either to retreat or to advance:'--this is owing to his want of care. 'If he realise the difficulty (of his position), there will be good fortune:'--his error will not be prolonged.

Exegesis.Miscellaneous: 34, 33. Tâ Kwang stops here as right; withdraws Thun there.
Exegesis.Sequence: 32-37. Things cannot long abide in the same place; and hence Hăng is followed by Thun. Thun denotes withdrawing. Things cannot be for ever withdrawn; and hence Thun is succeeded by Tâ Kwang. Things cannot remain forever (simply) in the state of vigour; and hence Tâ Kwang is succeeded by Žin. Žin denotes advancing. (But) advancing is sure to lead to being wounded; and hence Žin is succeeded by Ming Î. Î denotes being wounded. He who is wounded abroad will return to his home; and hence Ming Î is followed by Kiâ Zăn.

Scripture.Hexagram: 晉：康侯用錫馬蕃庶，晝日三接。

Lines.L1: 初六：晉如，摧如，貞吉。罔孚，裕无咎。
Lines.L2: 六二：晉如，愁如，貞吉。受茲介福，于其王母。
Lines.L3: 六三：眾允，悔亡。
Lines.L4: 九四：晉如碩鼠，貞厲。
Lines.L5: 六五：悔亡，失得勿恤，往吉，无不利。
Lines.L6: 上九：晉其角，維用伐邑，厲吉无咎，貞吝。

Exegesis.Judgment: 晉，進也。明出地上，順而麗乎大明，柔進而上行。是以康侯用錫馬蕃庶，晝日三接也。

Imagery.Hexagram: 明出地上，晉；君子以自昭明德。

Lines.L1: 晉如，摧如；獨行正也。裕无咎；未受命也。
Lines.L2: 受玆介福，以中正也。
Lines.L3: 眾允之，志上行也。
Lines.L4: 碩鼠貞厲，位不當也。
Lines.L5: 失得勿恤，往有慶也。
Lines.L6: 維用伐邑，道未光也。

Scripture.Hexagram: 晋：康侯用锡马蕃庶，昼日三接。

Lines.L1: 初六：晋如，摧如，贞吉。罔孚，裕无咎。
Lines.L2: 六二：晋如，愁如，贞吉。受兹介福，于其王母。
Lines.L3: 六三：众允，悔亡。
Lines.L4: 九四：晋如硕鼠，贞厉。
Lines.L5: 六五：悔亡，失得勿恤，往吉，无不利。
Lines.L6: 上九：晋其角，维用伐邑，厉吉无咎，贞吝。

Exegesis.Judgment: 晋，进也。明出地上，顺而丽乎大明，柔进而上行。是以康侯用锡马蕃庶，昼日三接也。

Imagery.Hexagram: 明出地上，晋；君子以自昭明德。

Lines.L1: 晋如，摧如；独行正也。裕无咎；未受命也。
Lines.L2: 受兹介福，以中正也。
Lines.L3: 众允之，志上行也。
Lines.L4: 硕鼠贞厉，位不当也。
Lines.L5: 失得勿恤，往有庆也。
Lines.L6: 维用伐邑，道未光也。

Scripture.Hexagram:
PROGRESS. The powerful prince
Is honored with horses in large numbers.
In a single day he is granted audience three times.

Lines.L1:
Six at the beginning means:
Progressing, but turned back.
Perseverance brings good fortune.
If one meets with no confidence, one should remain calm.
No mistake.
Lines.L2:
Six in the second place means:
Progressing, but in sorrow.
Perseverance brings good fortune.
Then one obtains great happiness from one’s ancestress.
Lines.L3:
Six in the third place means:
All are in accord. Remorse disappears.
Lines.L4:
Nine in the fourth place means:
Progress like a hamster.
Perseverance brings danger.
Lines.L5:
Six in the fifth place means:
Remorse disappears.
Take not gain and loss to heart.
Undertakings bring good fortune.
Everything serves to further.
Lines.L6:
Nine at the top means:
Making progress with the horns is permissible
Only for the purpose of punishing one’s own city.
To be conscious of danger brings good fortune.
No blame.
Perseverance brings humiliation.

Exegesis.Judgment: PROGRESS means making advance. Clarity rises high over the earth. Devoted, and clinging to this great clarity, the weak progresses and goes upward. Hence it is said: “The powerful prince is honored with horses in large numbers. In a single day he is granted audience three times.”

Imagery.Hexagram:
The sun rises over the earth:
The image of PROGRESS.
Thus the superior man himself
Brightens his bright virtue.

Lines.L1:
Six at the beginning:
a) Progressing, but turned back.
Perseverance brings good fortune.
If one meets with no confidence, one should remain calm.
No mistake.
b) “Progressing, but turned back.” Solitary, he walks in the right. Composure is not a mistake. One has not yet received the command.
Lines.L2:
Six in the second place:
a) Progressing, but in sorrow.
Perseverance brings good fortune.
Then one obtains great happiness from one’s ancestress.
b) “One obtains great happiness,” because of the central and correct position.
Lines.L3:
Six in the third place:
a) All are in accord. Remorse disappears.
b) “All are in accord,” because there is a will to go upward.
Lines.L4:
Nine in the fourth place:
a) Progress like a hamster.
Perseverance brings danger.
b) A hamster gets into danger through perseverance; the place is not appropriate.
Lines.L5:
Six in the fifth place:
a) Remorse disappears.
Take not gain and loss to heart.
Undertakings bring good fortune.
Everything serves to further.
b) “Take not gain and loss to heart.” Undertaking brings blessing.
Lines.L6:
Nine at the top:
a) Making progress with the horns is permissible
Only for the purpose of punishing one’s own city.
To be conscious of danger brings good fortune.
No blame.
Perseverance brings humiliation.
b) “Permissible only for the purpose of punishing one’s own city.” The way is not yet in the light.

Exegesis.Miscellaneous: PROGRESS means the day.
Exegesis.Sequence: Beings cannot stay forever in a state of power; hence there follows the hexagram of PROGRESS. Progress means expansion.

Scripture.Hexagram: In Žin we see a prince who secures the tranquillity (of the people) presented on that account with numerous horses (by the king), and three times in a day received at interviews.

Lines.L1: 1. The first SIX, divided, shows one wishing to advance, and (at the same time) kept back. Let him be firm and correct, and there will be good fortune. If trust be not reposed in him, let him maintain a large and generous mind, and there will be no error.
Lines.L2: 2. The second SIX, divided, shows its subject with the appearance of advancing, and yet of being sorrowful. If he be firm and correct, there will be good fortune. He will receive this great blessing from his grandmother.
Lines.L3: 3. The third SIX, divided, shows its subject trusted by all (around him). All occasion for repentance will disappear.
Lines.L4: 4. The fourth NINE, undivided, shows its subject with the appearance of advancing, but like a marmot. However firm and correct he may be, the position is one of peril.
Lines.L5: 5. The fifth SIX, divided, shows how all occasion for repentance disappears (from its subject). (But) let him not concern himself about whether he shall fail or succeed. To advance will be fortunate, and in every way advantageous.
Lines.L6: 6. The topmost NINE, undivided, shows one advancing his horns. But he only uses them to punish the (rebellious people of his own) city. The position is perilous, but there will be good fortune. (Yet) however firm and correct he may be, there will be occasion for regret.

Exegesis.Judgment:
XXXV. 1. Žin denotes advancing.
2. (In Žin we have) the bright (sun) appearing above the earth; (the symbol of) docile submission cleaving to that of the Great brightness; and the weak line advanced and moving above:--all these things give us the idea of 'a prince who secures the tranquillity (of the people), presented on that account with numerous horses (by the king), and three times in a day received at interviews.'

Imagery.Hexagram: XXXV. (The trigram representing) the earth and that for the bright (sun) coming forth above it form Žin. The superior man, according to this, gives himself to make more brilliant his bright virtue.

Lines.L1: 1. 'He appears wishing to advance, but (at the same time) being kept back:'--all-alone he pursues the correct course. 'Let him maintain a large and generous mind, and there will be no error:'--he has not yet received an official charge.
Lines.L2: 2. 'He will receive this great blessing:'--for he is in the central place and the correct position for him.
Lines.L3: 3. 'All (around) trust him:'--their (common) aim is to move upwards and act.
Lines.L4: 4. '(He advances like) a marmot. However firm and correct he may be, his position is one of peril:'--his place is not that appropriate for him.
Lines.L5: 5. 'Let him not concern himself whether he fails or succeeds:'--his movement in advance will afford ground for congratulation.
Lines.L6: 6. 'He uses his horns only to punish (the rebellious people of) his city:'--his course of procedure is not yet brilliant.

Exegesis.Sequence: 32-37. Things cannot long abide in the same place; and hence Hăng is followed by Thun. Thun denotes withdrawing. Things cannot be for ever withdrawn; and hence Thun is succeeded by Tâ Kwang. Things cannot remain forever (simply) in the state of vigour; and hence Tâ Kwang is succeeded by Žin. Žin denotes advancing. (But) advancing is sure to lead to being wounded; and hence Žin is succeeded by Ming Î. Î denotes being wounded. He who is wounded abroad will return to his home; and hence Ming Î is followed by Kiâ Zăn.

English.WilhelmBaynes: Ming I / Darkening of the Light

Unicode.Name: Hexagram For Darkening Of The Light

Scripture.Hexagram: 明夷：利艱貞。

Lines.L1: 初九：明夷于飛，垂其翼。君子于行，三日不食，有攸往，主人有言。
Lines.L2: 六二：明夷，夷于左股，用拯馬壯，吉。
Lines.L3: 九三：明夷于南狩，得其大首，不可疾貞。
Lines.L4: 六四：入于左腹，獲明夷之心，出于門庭。
Lines.L5: 六五：箕子之明夷，利貞。
Lines.L6: 上六：不明晦，初登于天，後入于地。

Exegesis.Judgment: 明入地中，明夷。內文明而外柔順，以蒙大難，文王以之。利艱貞，晦其明也，內難而能正其志，箕子以之。

Imagery.Hexagram: 明入地中，明夷；君子以蒞眾，用晦而明。

Lines.L1: 君子于行，義不食也。
Lines.L2: 六二之吉，順以則也。
Lines.L3: 南狩之志，乃大得也。
Lines.L4: 入于左腹，獲心意也。
Lines.L5: 箕子之貞，明不可息也。
Lines.L6: 初登于天，照四國也。後入于地，失則也。

Scripture.Hexagram: 明夷：利艰贞。

Lines.L1: 初九：明夷于飞，垂其翼。君子于行，三日不食，有攸往，主人有言。
Lines.L2: 六二：明夷，夷于左股，用拯马壮，吉。
Lines.L3: 九三：明夷于南狩，得其大首，不可疾贞。
Lines.L4: 六四：入于左腹，获明夷之心，出于门庭。
Lines.L5: 六五：箕子之明夷，利贞。
Lines.L6: 上六：不明晦，初登于天，后入于地。

Exegesis.Judgment: 明入地中，明夷。内文明而外柔顺，以蒙大难，文王以之。利艰贞，晦其明也，内难而能正其志，箕子以之。

Imagery.Hexagram: 明入地中，明夷；君子以莅众，用晦而明。

Lines.L1: 君子于行，义不食也。
Lines.L2: 六二之吉，顺以则也。
Lines.L3: 南狩之志，乃大得也。
Lines.L4: 入于左腹，获心意也。
Lines.L5: 箕子之贞，明不可息也。
Lines.L6: 初登于天，照四国也。后入于地，失则也。

Scripture.Hexagram:
DARKENING OF THE LIGHT. In adversity
It furthers one to be persevering.

Lines.L1:
Nine at the beginning means:
Darkening of the light during flight.
He lowers his wings.
The superior man does not eat for three days
On his wanderings.
But he has somewhere to go.
The host has occasion to gossip about him.
Lines.L2:
Six in the second place means:
Darkening of the light injures him in the left thigh.
He gives aid with the strength of a horse.
Good fortune.
Lines.L3:
Nine in the third place means:
Darkening of the light during the hunt in the south.
Their great leader is captured.
One must not expect perseverance too soon.
Lines.L4:
Six in the fourth place means:
He penetrates the left side of the belly.
One gets at the very heart of the darkening of the light,
And leaves gate and courtyard.
Lines.L5:
Six in the fifth place means:
Darkening of the light as with Prince Chi.
Perseverance furthers.
Lines.L6:
Six at the top means:
Not light but darkness.
First he climbed up to heaven,
Then he plunged into the depths of the earth.

Exegesis.Judgment:
The light has sunk into the earth: DARKENING OF THE LIGHT. Beautiful and clear within, gentle and devoted without, hence exposed to great adversity—thus was King Wên.
“In adversity it furthers one to be persevering”: this means veiling one’s light. Surrounded by difficulties in the midst of his closest kin, nonetheless keeping his will fixed on the right—thus was Prince Chi.

Imagery.Hexagram:
The light has sunk into the earth:
The image of DARKENING OF THE LIGHT.
Thus does the superior man live with the great mass:
He veils his light, yet still shines.

Lines.L1:
Nine at the beginning:
a) Darkening of the light during flight.
He lowers his wings.
The superior man does not eat for three days
On his wanderings.
But he has somewhere to go.
The host has occasion to gossip about him.
b) It is the obligation of the superior man to refrain from eating during his wanderings.
Lines.L2:
Six in the second place:
a) Darkening of the light injures him in the left thigh.
He gives aid with the strength of a horse.
Good fortune.
b) The good fortune of the six in the second place comes from its devotion to the rule.
Lines.L3:
Nine in the third place:
a) Darkening of the light during the hunt in the south.
Their great leader is captured.
One must not expect perseverance too soon.
b) The purpose of the hunt in the south has great success.
Lines.L4:
Six in the fourth place:
a) He penetrates the left side of the belly.
One gets at the very heart of the darkening of the light,
And leaves gate and courtyard.
b) “He penetrates the left side of the belly,” that is, he finds out the inmost sentiment of the heart.
Lines.L5:
Six in the fifth place:
a) Darkening of the light as with Prince Chi.
Perseverance furthers.
b) The perseverance of Prince Chi shows that the light cannot be extinguished.
Lines.L6:
Six at the top:
a) Not light but darkness.
First he climbed up to heaven,
Then he plunged into the depths of the earth.
b) “First he climbed up to heaven.” Thus he might have been able to illumine the lands of all the four quarters of the earth.
“Then he plunged into the depths of the earth,” because he had lost the rule.

Exegesis.Miscellaneous: DARKENING OF THE LIGHT means injury.
Exegesis.Sequence: Expansion will certainly encounter resistance and injury. Hence there follows the hexagram of DARKENING OF THE LIGHT. Darkening means damage, injury.

Scripture.Hexagram: Ming Î indicates that (in the circumstances which it denotes) it will be advantageous to realise the difficulty (of the position), and maintain firm correctness.

Lines.L1: 1. The first NINE, undivided, shows its subject, (in the condition indicated by) Ming Î, flying, but with drooping wings. When the superior man (is revolving) his going away, he may be for three days without eating. Wherever he goes, the people there may speak (derisively of him).
Lines.L2: 2. The second SIX, divided, shows its subject, (in the condition indicated by) Ming Î, wounded in the left thigh. He saves himself by the strength of a (swift) horse; and is fortunate.
Lines.L3: 3. The third NINE, undivided, shows its subject, (in the condition indicated by) Ming Î, hunting in the south, and taking the great chief (of the darkness). He should not be eager to make (all) correct (at once).
Lines.L4: 4. The fourth SIX, divided, shows its subject (just) entered into the left side of the belly (of the dark land). (But) he is able to carry out the mind appropriate (in the condition indicated by) Ming Î, quitting the gate and courtyard (of the lord of darkness).
Lines.L5: 5. The fifth SIX, divided, shows how the count of Kî fulfilled the condition indicated by Ming Î. It will be advantageous to be firm and correct.
Lines.L6: 6. The sixth SIX, divided, shows the case where there is no light, but (only) obscurity. (Its subject) had at first ascended to (the top of) the sky; his future shall be to go into the earth.

Exegesis.Judgment:
XXXVI. 1. (The symbol of) the Earth and that of Brightness entering into the midst of it give the idea of Ming Î (Brightness wounded or obscured).
2. The inner (trigram) denotes being accomplished and bright; the outer, being pliant and submissive. The case of king Wăn was that of onewho with these qualities was yet involved in great difficulties.
3. 'It will be advantageous to realise the difficulty (of the position), and maintain firm correctness:--that is, (the individual concerned) should obscure his brightness. The case of the count of Kî was that of one who, amidst the difficulties of his House, was able (thus) to maintain his aim and mind correct.

Imagery.Hexagram: XXXVI. (The trigram representing) the earth and that for the bright (sun) entering within it form Ming Î. The superior man, in accordance with this, conducts his management of men;--he shows his intelligence by keeping it obscured.

Lines.L1: 1. 'The superior man (is revolving his) going away:'--(in such a case) he feels it right not to eat.
Lines.L2: 2. 'The good fortune of (the subject of) the second SIX, divided,' is due to the proper fashion of his acting according to his circumstances.
Lines.L3: 3. With the aim represented by 'hunting in the south' a great achievement is accomplished.
Lines.L4: 4. 'He has (just) entered into the left side of the belly (of the dark land):'--he is still able to carry out the idea in his (inner) mind.
Lines.L5: 5. 'With the firm correctness of the count of Kî,' his brightness could not be (quite) extinguished.
Lines.L6: 6. 'He had at first ascended to (the top of) the sky:'--he might have enlightened the four quartersof the kingdom. 'His future shall be to go into the earth:'--he has failed to fulfil the model (of a ruler).

Exegesis.Sequence: 32-37. Things cannot long abide in the same place; and hence Hăng is followed by Thun. Thun denotes withdrawing. Things cannot be for ever withdrawn; and hence Thun is succeeded by Tâ Kwang. Things cannot remain forever (simply) in the state of vigour; and hence Tâ Kwang is succeeded by Žin. Žin denotes advancing. (But) advancing is sure to lead to being wounded; and hence Žin is succeeded by Ming Î. Î denotes being wounded. He who is wounded abroad will return to his home; and hence Ming Î is followed by Kiâ Zăn.

Scripture.Hexagram: 家人：利女貞。

Lines.L1: 初九：閑有家，悔亡。
Lines.L2: 六二：无攸遂，在中饋，貞吉。
Lines.L3: 九三：家人嗃嗃，悔厲吉；婦子嘻嘻，終吝。
Lines.L4: 六四：富家，大吉。
Lines.L5: 九五：王假有家，勿恤，往吉。
Lines.L6: 上九：有孚威如，終吉。

Exegesis.Judgment: 家人，女正位乎內，男正位乎外，男女正，天地之大義也。家人有嚴君焉，父母之謂也。父父，子子，兄兄，弟弟，夫夫，婦婦，而家道正；正家而天下定矣。

Imagery.Hexagram: 風自火出，家人；君子以言有物，而行有恆。

Lines.L1: 閑有家，志未變也。
Lines.L2: 六二之吉，順以巽也。
Lines.L3: 家人嗃嗃，未失也；婦子嘻嘻，失家節也。
Lines.L4: 富家大吉，順在位也。
Lines.L5: 王假有家，交相愛也。
Lines.L6: 威如之吉，反身之謂也。

Scripture.Hexagram: 家人：利女贞。

Lines.L1: 初九：闲有家，悔亡。
Lines.L2: 六二：无攸遂，在中馈，贞吉。
Lines.L3: 九三：家人嗃嗃，悔厉吉；妇子嘻嘻，终吝。
Lines.L4: 六四：富家，大吉。
Lines.L5: 九五：王假有家，勿恤，往吉。
Lines.L6: 上九：有孚威如，终吉。

Exegesis.Judgment: 家人，女正位乎内，男正位乎外，男女正，天地之大义也。家人有严君焉，父母之谓也。父父，子子，兄兄，弟弟，夫夫，妇妇，而家道正；正家而天下定矣。

Imagery.Hexagram: 风自火出，家人；君子以言有物，而行有恒。

Lines.L1: 闲有家，志未变也。
Lines.L2: 六二之吉，顺以巽也。
Lines.L3: 家人嗃嗃，未失也；妇子嘻嘻，失家节也。
Lines.L4: 富家大吉，顺在位也。
Lines.L5: 王假有家，交相爱也。
Lines.L6: 威如之吉，反身之谓也。

Scripture.Hexagram: THE FAMILY. The perseverance of the woman furthers.

Lines.L1:
Nine at the beginning means:
Firm seclusion within the family.
Remorse disappears.
Lines.L2:
Six in the second place means:
She should not follow her whims.
She must attend within to the food.
Perseverance brings good fortune.
Lines.L3:
Nine in the third place means:
When tempers flare up in the family,
Too great severity brings remorse.
Good fortune nonetheless.
When woman and child dally and laugh,
It leads in the end to humiliation.
Lines.L4:
Six in the fourth place means:
She is the treasure of the house.
Great good fortune.
Lines.L5:
Nine in the fifth place means:
As a king he approaches his family.
Fear not.
Good fortune.
Lines.L6:
Nine at the top means:
His work commands respect.
In the end good fortune comes.

Exegesis.Judgment:
THE FAMILY. The correct place of the woman is within; the correct place of the man is without. That man and woman have their proper places is the greatest concept in nature.
Among the members of the family there are strict rulers; these are the parents. When the father is in truth a father and the son a son, when the elder brother is an elder brother and the younger brother a younger brother, the husband a husband and the wife a wife, then the house is on the right way.
When the house is set in order, the world is established in a firm course.

Imagery.Hexagram:
The image of THE FAMILY.
Thus the superior man has substance in his words
And duration in his way of life.

Lines.L1:
Nine at the beginning:
a) Firm seclusion within the family.
Remorse disappears.
b) “Firm seclusion within the family”: the will has not yet changed.
Lines.L2:
Six in the second place:
a) She should not follow her whims.
She must attend within to the food.
Perseverance brings good fortune.
b) The good fortune of the six in the second place depends upon devotion and gentleness.
Lines.L3:
Nine in the third place:
a) When tempers flare up in the family,
Too great severity brings remorse.
Good fortune nonetheless.
When woman and child dally and laugh,
It leads in the end to humiliation.
b) “When tempers flare up in the family,” nothing is as yet lost.
“When woman and child dally,” the discipline of the house is lost.
Lines.L4:
Six in the fourth place:
a) She is the treasure of the house.
Great good fortune.
b) “She is the treasure of the house. Great good fortune.”
For she is devoted and in her place.
Lines.L5:
Nine in the fifth place:
a) As a king he approaches his family.
Fear not.
Good fortune.
b) “As a king he approaches his family”: they associate with one another in love.
Lines.L6:
Nine at the top:
a) His work commands respect.
In the end good fortune comes.
b) “Commands respect” and “good fortune”: this indicates that one makes demands first of all upon oneself.

Exegesis.Miscellaneous: THE FAMILY is inside.
Exegesis.Sequence: He who is injured without, of a certainty draws back into his family. Hence there follows the hexagram of THE FAMILY.

Scripture.Hexagram: For (the realisation of what is taught in) Kiâ Zăn, (or for the regulation of the family), what is most advantageous is that the wife be firm and correct.

Lines.L1: 1. The first NINE, undivided, shows its subject establishing restrictive regulations in his household. Occasion for repentance will disappear.
Lines.L2: 2. The second SIX, divided, shows its subject taking nothing on herself, but in her central place attending to the preparation of the food. Through her firm correctness there will be good fortune.
Lines.L3: 3. The third NINE, undivided, shows its subject (treating) the members of the household with stern severity. There will be occasion for repentance, there will be peril, (but) there will (also) be good fortune. If the wife and children were to be smirking and chattering, in the end there would be occasion for regret.
Lines.L4: 4. The fourth SIX, divided, shows its subject enriching the family. There will be great good fortune.
Lines.L5: 5. The fifth NINE, undivided, shows the influence of the king extending to his family. There need be no anxiety; there will be good fortune.
Lines.L6: 6. The topmost NINE, undivided, shows its subject possessed of sincerity and arrayed in majesty. In the end there will be good fortune.

Exegesis.Judgment:
XXXVII. I. In Kiâ Zăn the wife has her correct place in the inner (trigram), and the man his correct place in the outer. That man and woman occupy their correct places is the great righteousness shown (in the relation and positions of) heaven and earth.
2. In Kiâ Zăn we have the idea of an authoritative ruler;--that, namely, represented by the parental authority.
3. Let the father be indeed father, and the son son; let the elder brother be indeed elder brother, and the younger brother younger brother, let the husband be indeed husband, and the wife wife:--then will the family be in its normal state. Bring the family to that state, and all under heaven will be established.

Imagery.Hexagram: XXXVII. (The trigram representing) fire, and that for wind coming forth from it, form Kiâ Zăn. The superior man, in accordance with this, orders his words according to (the truth of) things, and his conduct so that it is uniformly consistent.

Lines.L1: 1. 'He establishes restrictive regulations in his household:--(he does so), before any change has taken place in their wills.
Lines.L2: 2. 'The good fortune attached to the second six, (divided),' is due to the docility (of its subject), operating with humility.
Lines.L3: 3. When 'the members of the household are treated with stern severity,' there has been no (great) failure (in the regulation of the family). When 'wife and children are smirking and chattering,' the (proper) economy of the family has been lost.
Lines.L4: 4. 'The family is enriched, and there is greatgood fortune:'--this is due to the docility (belonging to the subject of the line), and its being in its correct place.
Lines.L5: 5. 'The influence of the king extends to his family:'--the intercourse between them is that of mutual love.
Lines.L6: 6. 'The good fortune connected with the display of majesty' describes (the result of) the recovery of the true character.

Exegesis.Sequence:
32-37. Things cannot long abide in the same place; and hence Hăng is followed by Thun. Thun denotes withdrawing. Things cannot be for ever withdrawn; and hence Thun is succeeded by Tâ Kwang. Things cannot remain forever (simply) in the state of vigour; and hence Tâ Kwang is succeeded by Žin. Žin denotes advancing. (But) advancing is sure to lead to being wounded; and hence Žin is succeeded by Ming Î. Î denotes being wounded. He who is wounded abroad will return to his home; and hence Ming Î is followed by Kiâ Zăn.
37-40. When the right administration of the family is at an end, misunderstanding and division will ensue; and hence Kiâ Zăn is followed by Khwei. Khwei denotes misunderstanding and division; and such a state is sure to give rise to difficulties and complications. Khwei therefore is followed by Kien. Kien denotes difficulties; but things cannot remain for ever in such a state. Kien therefore is followed by Kieh, which denotes relaxation and ease.

Scripture.Hexagram: 睽：小事吉。

Lines.L1: 初九：悔亡，喪馬勿逐，自復；見惡人无咎。
Lines.L2: 九二：遇主于巷，无咎。
Lines.L3: 六三：見輿曳，其牛掣，其人天且劓，无初有終。
Lines.L4: 九四：睽孤，遇元夫，交孚，厲无咎。
Lines.L5: 六五：悔亡，厥宗噬膚，往何咎。
Lines.L6: 上九：睽孤，見豕負塗，載鬼一車，先張之弧，後說之弧，匪寇婚媾，往遇雨則吉。

Exegesis.Judgment: 睽，火動而上，澤動而下；二女同居，其志不同行；說而麗乎明，柔進而上行，得中而應乎剛；是以小事吉。天地睽，而其事同也；男女睽，而其志通也；萬物睽，而其事類也；睽之時用大矣哉！

Imagery.Hexagram: 上火下澤，睽；君子以同而異。

Lines.L1: 見惡人，以辟咎也。
Lines.L2: 遇主于巷，未失道也。
Lines.L3: 見輿曳，位不當也。无初有終，遇剛也。
Lines.L4: 交孚无咎，志行也。
Lines.L5: 厥宗噬膚，往有慶也。
Lines.L6: 遇雨之吉，群疑亡也。

Scripture.Hexagram: 睽：小事吉。

Lines.L1: 初九：悔亡，丧马勿逐，自复；见恶人无咎。
Lines.L2: 九二：遇主于巷，无咎。
Lines.L3: 六三：见舆曳，其牛掣，其人天且劓，无初有终。
Lines.L4: 九四：睽孤，遇元夫，交孚，厉无咎。
Lines.L5: 六五：悔亡，厥宗噬肤，往何咎。
Lines.L6: 上九：睽孤，见豕负涂，载鬼一车，先张之弧，后说之弧，匪寇婚媾，往遇雨则吉。

Exegesis.Judgment: 睽，火动而上，泽动而下；二女同居，其志不同行；说而丽乎明，柔进而上行，得中而应乎刚；是以小事吉。天地睽，而其事同也；男女睽，而其志通也；万物睽，而其事类也；睽之时用大矣哉！

Imagery.Hexagram: 上火下泽，睽；君子以同而异。

Lines.L1: 见恶人，以辟咎也。
Lines.L2: 遇主于巷，未失道也。
Lines.L3: 见舆曳，位不当也。无初有终，遇刚也。
Lines.L4: 交孚无咎，志行也。
Lines.L5: 厥宗噬肤，往有庆也。
Lines.L6: 遇雨之吉，群疑亡也。

Scripture.Hexagram: OPPOSITION. In small matters, good fortune.

Lines.L1:
Nine at the beginning means:
Remorse disappears.
If you lose your horse, do not run after it;
It will come back of its own accord.
When you see evil people,
Guard yourself against mistakes.
Lines.L2:
Nine in the second place means:
One meets his lord in a narrow street.
No blame.
Lines.L3:
Six in the third place means:
One sees the wagon dragged back,
The oxen halted,
A man’s hair and nose cut off.
Not a good beginning, but a good end.
Lines.L4:
Nine in the fourth place means:
Isolated through opposition,
One meets a like-minded man
With whom one can associate in good faith.
Despite the danger, no blame.
Lines.L5:
Six in the fifth place means:
Remorse disappears.
The companion bites his way through the wrappings.
If one goes to him,
How could it be a mistake?
Lines.L6:
Nine at the top means:
Isolated through opposition,
One sees one’s companion as a pig covered with dirt,
As a wagon full of devils.
First one draws a bow against him,
Then one lays the bow aside.
He is not a robber; he will woo at the right time.
As one goes, rain falls; then good fortune comes.

Exegesis.Judgment:
OPPOSITION: fire moves upward, the lake moves downward. Two daughters live together, but their minds are not directed to common concerns.
Joyousness and dependence upon clarity: the yielding progresses and goes upward, attains the middle, and finds correspondence in the firm. This is why there is good fortune in small matters.
Heaven and earth are opposites, but their action is concerted. Man and woman are opposites, but they strive for union. All beings stand in opposition to one another: what they do takes on order thereby. Great indeed is the effect of the time of OPPOSITION.

Imagery.Hexagram:
Above, fire; below, the lake:
The image of OPPOSITION.
Thus amid all fellowship
The superior man retains his individuality.

Lines.L1:
Nine at the beginning:
a) Remorse disappears.
If you lose your horse, do not run after it;
It will come back of its own accord.
When you see evil people,
Guard yourself against mistakes.
b) “When you see evil people,” avoid mistakes.
Lines.L2:
Nine in the second place:
a) One meets his lord in a narrow street.
No blame.
b) If one meets his lord in a narrow street, one has not lost his way.
Lines.L3:
Six in the third place:
a) One sees the wagon dragged back,
The oxen halted,
A man’s hair and nose cut off.
Not a good beginning, but a good end.
b) “One sees the wagon dragged back”: this happens because the place is not the right one.
“Not a good beginning, but a good end”: this happens through meeting one that is firm.
Lines.L4:
Nine in the fourth place:
a) Isolated through opposition,
One meets a like-minded man
With whom one can associate in good faith.
Despite the danger, no blame.
b) Association in good faith, without blame: this means that the will effects its purpose.
Lines.L5:
Six in the fifth place:
a) Remorse disappears.
The companion bites his way through the wrappings.
If one goes to him,
How could it be a mistake?
b) “The companion bites his way through the wrappings.” If one goes to him, it brings blessing.
Lines.L6:
Nine at the top:
a) Isolated through opposition,
One sees one’s companion as a pig covered with dirt,
As a wagon full of devils.
First one draws a bow against him,
Then one lays the bow aside.
He is not a robber; he will woo at the right time.
As one goes, rain falls; then good fortune comes.
b) The good fortune of the rainfall means that all doubts disappear.

Exegesis.Miscellaneous: OPPOSITION means estrangement.
Exegesis.Sequence: When the way of THE FAMILY draws to an end, misunderstandings come. Hence there follows the hexagram of OPPOSITION. Opposition means misunderstandings.
Exegesis.Extracts: The men of ancient times strung a piece of wood for a bow and hardened pieces of wood in the fire for arrows. The use of bow and arrow is to keep the world in fear. They probably took this from the hexagram of OPPOSITION.

Scripture.Hexagram: Khwei indicates that, (notwithstanding the condition of things which it denotes), in small matters there will (still) be good success.

Lines.L1: 1. The first NINE, undivided, shows that (to its subject) occasion for repentance will disappear. He has lost his horses, but let him not seek for them;--they will return of themselves. Should he meet with bad men, he will not err (in communicating with them).
Lines.L2: 2. The second NINE, undivided, shows its subject happening to meet with his lord in a bye‐passage. There will be no error.
Lines.L3: 3. In the third SIX, divided, we see one whose carriage is dragged back, while the oxen in it are pushed back, and he is himself subjected to the shaving of his head and the cutting off of his nose. There is no good beginning, but there will be a good end.
Lines.L4: 4. The fourth NINE, undivided, shows its subject solitary amidst the (prevailing) disunion. (But) he meets with the good man (represented by the first line), and they blend their sincere desires together. The position is one of peril, but there will be no mistake.
Lines.L5: 5. The fifth SIX, divided, shows that (to its subject) occasion for repentance will disappear. With his relative (and minister he unites closely and readily) as if he were biting through a piece of skin. When he goes forward (with this help), what error can there be?
Lines.L6: 6. The topmost NINE, undivided, shows its subject solitary amidst the (prevailing) disunion. (In the subject of the third line, he seems to) see a pig bearing on its back a load of mud, (or fancies) there is a carriage full of ghosts. He first bends his bow against him, and afterwards unbends it, (for he discovers) that he is not an assailant to injure, but a near relative. Going forward, he shall meet with (genial) rain, and there will be good fortune.

Exegesis.Judgment:
XXXVIII. 1. In Khwei we have (the symbol of) Fire, which, when moved, tends upwards, and that of a Marsh, whose waters, when moved, tend downwards. We have (also the symbols of) two sisters living together, but whose wills do not move in the same direction.
2. (We see how the inner trigram expressive of) harmonious satisfaction is attached to (the outer expressive of) bright intelligence; (we see) the weak line advanced and acting above, and how it occupies the central place, and is responded to by the strong (line below). These indications show that 'in small matters there will (still) be good fortune.'
3. Heaven and earth are separate and apart, but the work which they do is the same. Male and female are separate and apart, but with a common will they seek the same object. There is diversity between the myriad classes of beings, but there is an analogy between their several operations. Great indeed are the phenomena and the results of this condition of disunion and separation.

Imagery.Hexagram: XXXVIII. (The trigram representing) fire above, and that for (the waters of) a marsh below, form Khwei. The superior man, in accordance with this, where there is a general agreement, yet admits diversity.

Lines.L1: 1. 'He meets with bad men (and communicates with them):'--(he does so), to avoid the evil of their condemnation.
Lines.L2: 2. 'He happens to meet with his lord in a bye-passage:'--but he has not deviated (for this meeting) from the (proper) course.
Lines.L3: 3. 'We see his carriage dragged back:'--this is indicated by the inappropriateness of the position (of the line).'There is no (good) beginning, but there will be a (good) end:'--this arises from his meeting with the strong (subject of the topmost line).
Lines.L4: 4. 'They blend their sincere desires together, and there will be no error:'--their (common) aim is carried into effect.
Lines.L5: 5. 'With his hereditary minister (he unites closely and easily) as if he were biting through a piece of skin:'--his going forward will afford ground for congratulation.
Lines.L6: 6. 'The good fortune symbolised by meeting with (genial) rain' springs from the passing away of all doubts.

Exegesis.Sequence: 37-40. When the right administration of the family is at an end, misunderstanding and division will ensue; and hence Kiâ Zăn is followed by Khwei. Khwei denotes misunderstanding and division; and such a state is sure to give rise to difficulties and complications. Khwei therefore is followed by Kien. Kien denotes difficulties; but things cannot remain for ever in such a state. Kien therefore is followed by Kieh, which denotes relaxation and ease.

Scripture.Hexagram: 蹇：利西南，不利東北；利見大人，貞吉。

Lines.L1: 初六：往蹇，來譽。
Lines.L2: 六二：王臣蹇蹇，匪躬之故。
Lines.L3: 九三：往蹇來反。
Lines.L4: 六四：往蹇來連。
Lines.L5: 九五：大蹇朋來。
Lines.L6: 上六：往蹇來碩，吉；利見大人。

Exegesis.Judgment: 蹇，難也，險在前也。見險而能止，知矣哉！蹇利西南，往得中也；不利東北，其道窮也。利見大人，往有功也。當位貞吉，以正邦也。蹇之時用大矣哉！

Imagery.Hexagram: 山上有水，蹇；君子以反身修德。

Lines.L1: 往蹇來譽，宜待也。
Lines.L2: 王臣蹇蹇，終无尤也。
Lines.L3: 往蹇來反，內喜之也。
Lines.L4: 往蹇來連，當位實也。
Lines.L5: 大蹇朋來，以中節也。
Lines.L6: 往蹇來碩，志在內也。利見大人，以從貴也。

Scripture.Hexagram: 蹇：利西南，不利东北；利见大人，贞吉。

Lines.L1: 初六：往蹇，来誉。
Lines.L2: 六二：王臣蹇蹇，匪躬之故。
Lines.L3: 九三：往蹇来反。
Lines.L4: 六四：往蹇来连。
Lines.L5: 九五：大蹇朋来。
Lines.L6: 上六：往蹇来硕，吉；利见大人。

Exegesis.Judgment: 蹇，难也，险在前也。见险而能止，知矣哉！蹇利西南，往得中也；不利东北，其道穷也。利见大人，往有功也。当位贞吉，以正邦也。蹇之时用大矣哉！

Imagery.Hexagram: 山上有水，蹇；君子以反身修德。

Lines.L1: 往蹇来誉，宜待也。
Lines.L2: 王臣蹇蹇，终无尤也。
Lines.L3: 往蹇来反，内喜之也。
Lines.L4: 往蹇来连，当位实也。
Lines.L5: 大蹇朋来，以中节也。
Lines.L6: 往蹇来硕，志在内也。利见大人，以从贵也。

Scripture.Hexagram:
OBSTRUCTION. The southwest furthers.
The northeast does not further.
It furthers one to see the great man.
Perseverance brings good fortune.

Lines.L1:
Six at the beginning means:
Going leads to obstructions,
Coming meets with praise.
Lines.L2:
Six in the second place means:
The king’s servant is beset by obstruction upon obstruction,
But it is not his own fault.
Lines.L4:
Six in the fourth place means:
Going leads to obstructions,
Coming leads to union.
Lines.L5:
Nine in the fifth place means:
In the midst of the greatest obstructions,
Friends come.
Lines.L6:
Six at the top means:
Going leads to obstructions,
Coming leads to great good fortune.
It furthers one to see the great man.

Exegesis.Judgment:
OBSTRUCTION means difficulty. The danger is ahead. To see the danger and to know how to stand still, that is wisdom.
In OBSTRUCTION “the southwest furthers,” because he goes and attains the middle.
“The northeast does not further,” because there the way comes to an end.
“It furthers one to see the great man,” because he goes and wins merits.
In the right place, “perseverance brings good fortune,” because through it the country comes into order.
The effect of a time of OBSTRUCTION is great indeed.

Imagery.Hexagram:
Water on the mountain:
The image of OBSTRUCTION.
Thus the superior man turns his attention to himself
And molds his character.

Lines.L1:
Six at the beginning:
a) Going leads to obstructions,
Coming meets with praise.
b) “Going leads to obstructions, coming meets with praise,” because it is right to wait.
Lines.L2:
Six in the second place:
a) The king’s servant is beset by obstruction upon obstruction,
But it is not his own fault.
b) “The king’s servant is beset by obstruction upon obstruction.” But in the end there is no blame in this.
Lines.L3:
Six in the third place:
a) Going leads to obstructions;
Hence he comes back.
b) “Going leads to obstructions; hence he comes back.” Those within rejoice over it.
Lines.L4:
Six in the fourth place:
a) Going leads to obstructions,
Coming leads to union.
b) “Going leads to obstructions, coming leads to union.” In the appropriate place one finds support.
Lines.L5:
Nine in the fifth place:
a) In the midst of the greatest obstructions,
Friends come.
b) “In the midst of the greatest obstructions, friends come.” For they are ruled by the central position.
Lines.L6:
Six at the top:
a) Going leads to obstructions,
Coming leads to great good fortune.
It furthers one to see the great man.
b) “Going leads to obstructions, coming leads to great good fortune,” for the will is directed to inner things.
“It furthers one to see the great man.” For thus does one follow a man of rank.

Exegesis.Miscellaneous: OBSTRUCTION means difficulty.
Exegesis.Sequence: Through opposition difficulties necessarily arise. Hence there follows the hexagram of OBSTRUCTION. Obstruction means difficulty.

Scripture.Hexagram: In (the state indicated by) Kien advantage will be found in the southwest, and the contrary in the northeast. It will be advantageous (also) to meet with the great man. (In these circumstances), with firmness and correctness, there will be good fortune.

Lines.L1: 1. From the first SIX, divided, we learn that advance (on the part of its subject) will lead to (greater) difficulties, while remaining stationary will afford ground for praise.
Lines.L2: 2. The second SIX, divided, shows the minister of the king struggling with difficulty on difficulty, and not with a view to his own advantage.
Lines.L3: 3. The third NINE, undivided, shows its subject advancing, (but only) to (greater) difficulties. He remains stationary, and returns (to his former associates).
Lines.L4: 4. The fourth SIX, divided, shows its subject advancing, (but only) to (greater) difficulties. He remains stationary, and unites (with the subject of the line above).
Lines.L5: 5. The fifth NINE, undivided, shows its subject struggling with the greatest difficulties, while friends are coming to help him.
Lines.L6: 6. The topmost SIX, divided, shows its subject going forward, (only to increase) the difficulties, while his remaining stationary will be (productive of) great (merit). There will be good fortune, and it will be advantageous to meet with the great man.

Exegesis.Judgment:
XXXIX. 1. Kien denotes difficulty. There is (the trigram expressive of) perilousness in front. When one, seeing the peril, can arrest his steps (in accordance with the significance of the lower tri. gram), is he not wise?
2. (The language of) Kien, that 'advantage will be found in the south-west,' refers to the (strong fifth line) advanced and in the central place. That 'there will be no advantage in the north-east,' intimates that the way (of dealing with the Kien state) is exhausted. That 'it will be advantageous to see the great man,' intimates that advance will lead to achievement. That the places (of the different lines after the first) are those appropriate to them indicates firm correctness and good fortune, with which the regions (of the kingdom) are brought to their normal state. Great indeed is the work to be done in the time of Kien!

Imagery.Hexagram: XXXIX. (The trigram representing) a mountain, and above it that for water, form Kien. The superior man, in accordance with this, turns round (and examines) himself, and cultivates his virtue.

Lines.L1: 1. 'Advancing will conduct to (greater) difficulties, while remaining stationary will afford ground for praise:'--the proper course is to wait.
Lines.L2: 2. 'The minister of the king struggles with difficulty on difficulty:'--in the end no blame will be attached to him.
Lines.L3: 3. 'He advances, (but only) to (greater) difficulty; he remains stationary, and returns to his former associates:'--they, (represented in) the inner (trigram), rejoice in him.
Lines.L4: 4. 'To advance will (only be to) encounter (greater) difficulties; he remains stationary, and unites (with the subject of the line above):'--that is in its proper place and has the solidity (due to it in that position).
Lines.L5: 5. 'He struggles with the greatest difficulties, while friends are coming (to help him):'--he is in the central position, and possesses the requisite virtue.
Lines.L6: 6. 'To advance will (only) increase the difficulties, while his remaining stationary will (be productive of) great (merit):'--his aim is to assist the (subject of the line) inside of him.'It will be advantageous to meet the great man:'--by his course he follows that noble (lord of the figure).

Exegesis.Sequence: 37-40. When the right administration of the family is at an end, misunderstanding and division will ensue; and hence Kiâ Zăn is followed by Khwei. Khwei denotes misunderstanding and division; and such a state is sure to give rise to difficulties and complications. Khwei therefore is followed by Kien. Kien denotes difficulties; but things cannot remain for ever in such a state. Kien therefore is followed by Kieh, which denotes relaxation and ease.

Scripture.Hexagram: 解：利西南，无所往，其來復吉。有攸往，夙吉。

Lines.L1: 初六：无咎。
Lines.L2: 九二：田獲三狐，得黃矢，貞吉。
Lines.L3: 六三：負且乘，致寇至，貞吝。
Lines.L4: 九四：解而拇，朋至斯孚。
Lines.L5: 六五：君子維有解，吉；有孚于小人。
Lines.L6: 上六：公用射隼于高墉之上，獲之，无不利。

Exegesis.Judgment: 解，險以動，動而免乎險，解。解利西南，往得眾也。其來復吉，乃得中也。有攸往夙吉，往有功也。天地解，而雷雨作，雷雨作，而百果草木皆甲坼，解之時大矣哉！

Imagery.Hexagram: 雷雨作，解；君子以赦過宥罪。

Lines.L1: 剛柔之際，義无咎也。
Lines.L2: 九二貞吉，得中道也。
Lines.L3: 負且乘，亦可醜也，自我致戎，又誰咎也。
Lines.L4: 解而拇，未當位也。
Lines.L5: 君子有解，小人退也。
Lines.L6: 公用射隼，以解悖也。

Scripture.Hexagram: 解：利西南，无所往，其来复吉。有攸往，夙吉。

Lines.L1: 初六：无咎。
Lines.L2: 九二：田获三狐，得黄矢，贞吉。
Lines.L3: 六三：负且乘，致寇至，贞吝。
Lines.L4: 九四：解而拇，朋至斯孚。
Lines.L5: 六五：君子维有解，吉；有孚于小人。
Lines.L6: 上六：公用射隼于高墉之上，获之，无不利。

Exegesis.Judgment: 解，险以动，动而免乎险，解。解利西南，往得众也。其来复吉，乃得中也。有攸往夙吉，往有功也。天地解，而雷雨作，雷雨作，而百果草木皆甲坼，解之时大矣哉！

Imagery.Hexagram: 雷雨作，解；君子以赦过宥罪。

Lines.L1: 刚柔之际，义无咎也。
Lines.L2: 九二贞吉，得中道也。
Lines.L3: 负且乘，亦可丑也，自我致戎，又谁咎也。
Lines.L4: 解而拇，未当位也。
Lines.L5: 君子有解，小人退也。
Lines.L6: 公用射隼，以解悖也。

Scripture.Hexagram:
DELIVERANCE. The southwest furthers.
If there is no longer anything where one has to go,
Return brings good fortune.
If there is still something where one has to go,
Hastening brings good fortune.

Lines.L1:
Six at the beginning means:
Without blame.
Lines.L2:
Nine in the second place means:
One kills three foxes in the field
And receives a yellow arrow.
Perseverance brings good fortune.
Lines.L3:
Six in the third place means:
If a man carries a burden on his back
And nonetheless rides in a carriage,
He thereby encourages robbers to draw near.
Perseverance leads to humiliation.
Lines.L4:
Nine in the fourth place means:
Deliver yourself from your great toe.
Then the companion comes,
And him you can trust.
Lines.L5:
Six in the fifth place means:
If only the superior man can deliver himself,
It brings good fortune.
Thus he proves to inferior men that he is in earnest.
Lines.L6:
Six at the top means:
The prince shoots at a hawk on a high wall.
He kills it. Everything serves to further.

Exegesis.Judgment:
DELIVERANCE. Danger produces movement. Through movement one escapes danger: this is deliverance.
During deliverance “the southwest furthers”: by going he wins the multitude.
“His return brings good fortune,” because he wins the central position.
“If there is still something where one has to go, hastening brings good fortune.” Then going is meritorious.
When heaven and earth deliver themselves, thunder and rain set in. When thunder and rain set in, the seed pods of all fruits, plants, and trees break open.
The time of DELIVERANCE is great indeed.

Imagery.Hexagram:
Thunder and rain set in:
The image of DELIVERANCE.
Thus the superior man pardons mistakes
And forgives misdeeds.

Lines.L1:
Six at the beginning:
a) Without blame.
b) On the border between firm and yielding there should be no blame.
Lines.L2:
Nine in the second place:
a) One kills three foxes in the field
And receives a yellow arrow.
Perseverance brings good fortune.
b) The good fortune of the perseverance of the nine in the second place is due to its attaining the middle way.
Lines.L3:
Six in the third place:
a) If a man carries a burden on his back
And nonetheless rides in a carriage,
He thereby encourages robbers to draw near.
Perseverance leads to humiliation.
b) “If a man carries a burden on his back and nonetheless rides in a carriage,” he should really be ashamed of himself.
When I myself thus attract robbers, on whom shall I lay the blame?
Lines.L4:
Nine in the fourth place:
a) Deliver yourself from your great toe.
Then the companion comes,
And him you can trust.
b) “Deliver yourself from your great toe”: for the place is not the appropriate one.
Lines.L5:
Six in the fifth place:
a) If only the superior man can deliver himself,
It brings good fortune.
Thus he proves to inferior men that he is in earnest.
b) The superior man delivers himself, because inferior men then retreat.
Lines.L6:
Six at the top:
a) The prince shoots at a hawk on a high wall.
He kills it. Everything serves to further.
b) “The prince shoots at a hawk”: thereby he delivers himself from those who resist.

Exegesis.Miscellaneous: DELIVERANCE means release from tension.
Exegesis.Sequence: Things cannot be permanently amid obstructions. Hence there follows the hexagram of DELIVERANCE. Deliverance means release from tension.

Scripture.Hexagram: In (the state indicated by) K ieh advantage will be found in the southwest. If no (further) operations be called for, there will be good fortune in coming back (to the old conditions). If some operations be called for, there will be good fortune in the early conducting of them.

Lines.L1: 1. The first SIX, divided, shows that its subject will commit no error.
Lines.L2: 2. The second NINE, undivided, shows its subject catch, in hunting, three foxes, and obtain the yellow (= golden) arrows. With firm correctness there will be good fortune.
Lines.L3: 3. The third SIX, divided, shows a porter with his burden, (yet) riding in a carriage. He will (only) tempt robbers to attack him. However firm and correct he may (try to) be, there will be cause for regret.
Lines.L4: 4. (To the subject of) the fourth NINE, undivided, (it is said), 'Remove your toes. Friends will (then) come, between you and whom there will be mutual confidence.'
Lines.L5: 5. The fifth SIX, divided, shows (its subject), the superior man (= the ruler), executing his function of removing (whatever is injurious to the idea of the hexagram), in which case there will be good fortune, and confidence in him will be shown even by the small men.
